reviews.review: Chocolate Workshop was great. We had a great time at the Choco Museo's chocolate-making workshop, and this review is for that experience. There are several locations in Cusco and Lima, some offering different workshops, but the basic course that my group did was approximately 2 hours for about 70 PEN (Peru Soles). It started with a introduction to the bean production, moved into basic production methods like using special tools to roast the beans, using a mortar and pestle to grind the beans into a paste, etc. The entire process takes 24 hours, so after guests finish with the steps leading up to the cooking, they are given pre-made chocolate (dark or milk) to mix with ingredients and place into plastic molds for refrigeration. The final step is to return an hour or so later and pick up the final product, which was delicious! The host spoke fluent English and Spanish and kept the class interesting for everyone.

Fantastic workshop and museum. We started with a free tour of the museum which was really interesting and had so many free samples we had to refuse some of the liquors as it wasn't even 10am and we were already feeling tipsy! Oscar who gave us the tour was really friendly! We then signed up for chocolate making workshop from coco bean to actual chocolates we got to take home. Again lots of free samples my husband won some chocolate tea and the chocolatier Jill who taught us was a real character then class was fun, informative and light hearted. Couldn't recommend it enough!

Try the chocolate, it's delicious!. We went here on an off day from hiking, and it was lovely. We took the tour, which only lasted about 15 minutes. The tour is offered in Spanish and English. On said tour they will take you in a small room where they will talk about the history of chocolate in Peru. This is interesting, but the best part is they let you sample the chocolate. We also sampled their hot chocolate and jams. Delicious! The gift shop has many chocolate treats one can buy, and there is a lovely adjoining cafe with many tantalizing treats that are not too expensive. For people who are looking to get more of a chocolate experience, they offer chocolate workshops. My group did not partake in this but it looked like fun. Overall it was an enjoyable experience, and it was a nice way to kill an hour.

Stocked up on souvenirs here. So many varieties to choose from.. Great selection of very high quality chocolate and chocolate themed gifts. They even have chocolate condoms - I kid you not! I visited several times during my stay here.

Sweet cafe. We only went for the cafe which is tiny but has a charming menu of delicious treats and some savories too. A fun place to visit The brownie lives up to all the prior reviews Also there is a shop around the corner To find the cafe and class location look for the courtyard its on the 2nd floor but not so hard to find We will be back in Cusco towards the end of our stay in Peru and plan on returning here That's the highest compliment!

Really fun two hour chocolate workshop. There were 4 of us who attended the workshop together with a group of 15 people total. Our guide, Gil, was very entertaining and informative. He gave us a briefing on the cocoa industry in Peru and then moved us all to the kitchen workshop. Our group included everyone from a 10 year old to a 60 year old and everyone enjoyed the session. We roasted beans, made 3 different versions of hot chocolate and then used the already tempered chocolate to make molds of our choice with favors and additional fillings of our choice. You pick up your finished chocolate 50 minutes to an hour after the class. The cost was S/70 each.

Nice Short Tour to see how the chocolate process. This is a quick 30 minute tour. It was well done. We first bought some chocolate and they let us go in the museum for free. Very nice and they sell some very nice tasting chocolate

Most Interesting History of Chocolate in Peru. We enjoyed the tour by the museum and store staff. They were fun and energetic. We did not like the chocolate so much as we do European or American chocolate. But, when you've got to have chocolate, this is a good place. :-)

A brilliant way to spend two hours. We booked a workshop and had the best experience. The guide was engaging and hilarious. We tasted different sorts of hot chocolate and made our own chocolate to take home. Informative and lots and lots of fun.
UNO MAS POR FAVOR. IF YOU GO YOU CAN TASTE EVERYTHING! get the hot chocolate conquistador and the all chocolate ice cream.chocolate caliente conquistador y healodo de chocolate es RICO!
Don't bother. If you want to buy from a limited selection, OK. Otherwise not a museum. Just a store. And not worth a special visit.
The best chocolate and coffe.. One of the things that can get in the city of Cusco is chocolate and coffee sale is this establishment, which by the way, the best chocolate and coffee I ever tasted.

Excellent way to discover the history of chocolate!. We had some time to fill in so our hotel suggested a visit to the Choco Museo. So glad we did! Jose was our guide and he did an excellent job describing everything to us. Heaps to sample; generous serves and a fantastic gift shop with very well-priced goodies. An absolute must when in Cusco.
Nice place to stop by. There is a large variety of chocolate-related products. One can learn about the process of manufacturing Peruvian chocolate and taste from samples

Get the brownie...unreal!. It was lashing rain out so all we wanted was a hot drink so we went into the Café part of the museum. I got the brownie and a mocha and both were amazing. Definitely the best brownie I've had in South America. I would definitely go back and visit the museum next time, but we skipped it this time in order to stuff our faces with chocolate items!! The shop has some great chocolates for sale and also has chocolate body lotions!!

Interesting museum and shop. Very nice museum with all information about how chocolate is made. Great staff who telled us everything and gave us some samples to try. You can also buy different chocolates, licores and other things made of chocolate. Can recommend it.

Tricky to find but worth it. I love chocolate so this was a must for me. It took a while to find as the entrance is in the doorway of a courtyard, but it is exactly where the map says it is. The cafe is really nice and the hot chocolate lovely. The chocolate is quite expensive but really nice and there is a good selection.

Chocolate is really good. We toured the museum, and it was informative. We wished we'd know about the chocolate cooking class, as we would have participated. The chocolate is very good, and they give you lots of samples, including chocolate tea, hot chocolate, chocolate liquor, etc...

Amazing time!. After having been to the one in Lima I must say I went back for more. This one is much busier and for good reason because it's great fun. Tried lots of yummy things including alcohol and had chocolate strawberry crepes after which were really nice. The hot chocolate that you make yourself (willy wonka) was OK, but they don't have the milk hot enough and the choc doesn't melt well. Still a great day

Tricky to find but worth it. I found the location easy enough but the Museum/cafe is actually on the first floor and access is via a courtyard off the side street which was not that well signed. Once inside the cafe menu is great, all the hot chocolate drinks were fantastic, over the course of 3 visits my wife and I worked our way through the menu. Prices were reasonable and service good, it was never that busy but again that may be because it was hard to locate!

Delectable chocolate overload!. Very touristy little café stop, with wee narrow balcony too, for delicious overload of chocolate drinks and food, along with specialty shop selling chocolate products. The service can be slow, so sit back and relax. Menu in both Spanish and English. Good stop for toilet too. My repeat favourite was the very reasonable 11 soles chocolate crepe with chocolate icecream. Enjoyed the chocolate frappe too. Friends ordered interesting chocolate concoction drinks they could mix on their own.
So fun!. We had a great time at the choco museo. They give lots of free chocolate samples and it's delicious!

Delicious place. This museum is incredible. The tour was really good.It had full explanations with extra detail.The staff knew how to answer the questions and were well informed.The gift shop was awesome and economic. I bought a chocolate lotion, it smells heavenly and people ask me where I got it . I recommend this place as a good activity for all ages.

Informative and free. We visited the museum whist acclimatising in Cusco before the inca trail. Free to look around and a good explanation from the staff. Tasted the chocolates and chocolate liqueurs.

A great couple of hours. I had some time alone in Lima before heading to Cusco and my love for chocolate found me at this place. I did the workshop and it was super fun and very informative. Learning about cocao production and the different types of drinks as well as the history. You get to make a take away tray of Chocs of your choice. Hurrah for Peruvian cocao!
Nice . Nice place to visit for 20 minutes during your city walk. History and process of making chocolate are displayed. They offer also workshops (which we didn't take).

Fun and Delicious times!!!. We went to see the Choco Museo at Cusco and we ended up taking one of their chocolate classes. The class was super fun!!! There were couples and people from all over the world and the teacher was very funny. Everyone participates, you get to try chocolate at all stages, and it was a great time. Highly recommend it! The choco museo is small but has good information. The shop sells all sorts of goodies and there's a cafe inside as well. I enjoyed my time at this location. Then again, I am a chocoholic! ;-)

LOVE the Chocolate Museum!. I have visited the chocolate museum multiple times. It is small, free, and packed with interesting information after ancient and modern chocolate culture in Peru. Also, there are delicious treats and alcohols that you can try at the end of the tour. I know that you can also take chocolate-making classes at the museum. If you are in Cusco, don't miss this gem!

Have been to many of the ChocoMuseums, very nice staff. On my Latin American travels I have been to many of these ChocoMuseums. However I liked this one very much as it was the first time that I felt somehow to be in a Museum. We had a very nice staff member attending us who taught us much about the chocolate process and let us taste different types of chocolate! I didn't know that chocolate beans are actually pretty much like wine..

Yummy. A nice spot to visit and learn about the chocolate we often crave. It's an interesting tour, and there's a cooking class if you have time. Good gift shop with a wide variety of chocolate gifts, if you not to give all your friends baby alpaca items.

So much fun!. My husband and I took the chocolate making class at ChocoMuseo on our last day in Cusco. It was a blast! We got to make our own custom creations and take them home with us. It was such a fun experience! Our instructor was friendly and knowlegeable. She laughed with us and helped us create some tasty treats. I would totally do this again. Great for couples and families.

Lovely short tour . We got a short but very interesting free tour of the museum. We also got to try some chocolate samples which were delicious! The tour guide was friendly and very informed. This is a short but interesting tour that gives a brief background to the chocolate production in Peru.

Chocolate making workshop was excellent!. We had a fantastic time at the two hour chocolate making workshop held upstairs. The host was funny and interesting. We took part in all of the steps in the chocolate making process and made several chocolate drinks and our own batch of chocolate candy to take with us. This was a fun and very tasty experience, highly recommended!

Great gem!. Found this place off the Plaza del Armas. Small little store that sells chocolates, teas, and even chocolate beer! There is another chocolate store around the corner also. This place offers tours, but you need to book them ahead of time. Nice place to stop into if you have time.

Sipping choco tea was nice,. This is mostly a place to go have some sort of chocolate-y drink or dish. There is a perfunctory description upstairs about the processing of chocolate. There is a small shop to buy chocolate related items. Fun for a short diversion.

Great visit!. Had a fantastic time at this museum/chocolate making class. This was my girls idea and a fantastic way to end the trip. The instructor was knowledgeable but more importantly passionate about chocolate emphasizing how strong a culture there exists still today in Peru. Very fun trying the different chocolate teas, and making our very own basket of chocolates to bring home. On a side note I won the competition for having the finest beans in the class and was rewarded cocoa tea extracts that I can't wait to enjoy which was a nice touch. Recommended to any chocolate lovers!Chris & Jenna

surprisingly very educational & fun!. Ok, us 4 adults travelling with 2 kids only agreed to this stop as 'mr master 5 yo' insisted on it, & - it was great! From the street corner lady from the museum who shared chocolate samples, local tourist info & was no-pressure at all, to our chocolate museum guide jose - we were blown away with how informal, educational & fun the tour was. adults & kids in our group had a great time! jose' struggled with english a little, but used humour & made it personal. we stayed to enjoy their cafe (with lovely views & staff!) & bought high quality chocies & drinks. it's 100% free for the museum entry & tour.
Making Chocolate. This was so much fun, learning, tasting, and actually making chocolate!! We all LOVED the chocolate and sang while we worked:) I would recommend to everyone!!
A must. A must experience. Take the chocolate making tour where they teach you to make chocolate from the cocoa beans. Very impressive and a delicious and aromatic experience.

Truffle making and delicious choccies . We had a great 2.5 hr truffle making class where we learned a lot about making chocolates. The Museo is great too and the chocolate is delicious. Well worth a visit.
Chocolate lovers. Lovely tastings and very good chocolate from different places especially from Peru. Ps. Also chocolate liquors!

The Hot Chocolate was Fun!. The lonely planet's description of this place was perfect - I think they said it was barely a museum. It's probably pretty cool if you sign up for one of the chocolate making workshops, but we just dropped in. They have 2 rooms with some information about how chocolate is made, and a small store selling their brand of chocolate (with samples!) We indulged in 2 fresh hot cocos at their small cafe, and that was a fun treat. They brought it out with raw melted chocolate, a pot of milk, and all the spices to make our own creation. It was fun, and we were happy. Turns out it's a chain and they are all over Peru.
So much yum. Good way to fill a bit of time. I saw they had tour options to make your own chocolate etc but I stuck to just wondering round the museum and taste testing

Sweet teeth unite!. We attended the chocolate cooking class. It was fabulous! The young lady (I think Antonietta) was delightful, spirited, and funny. We went from the beans to the finished chocolate product - what an amazing and fun-filled activity! Can definitely recoommend!

Fun workshop!. My friend and I did the chocolate workshop and had a great time. Our guide was very fun and VERY enthusiastic! We learnt a lot about chocolate and made our own delicious chocs to take home at the end.

A great place for all things chocolate-based!. A nice shop, café & museum with lots of different chocolate products to taste & buy. I took part in the Beans to Bar chocolate workshop which was very enjoyable, although could have done with a bit more hands-on experience, as other reviewers have mentioned. During the workshop, we learnt about the processes involved in making chocolate, tried three different types of hot chocolate, had a go at grinding beans by hand & got to create our own chocolates to take away (with a choice of milk or dark chocolate & plenty of different fillings, such as coconut, peanuts, almonds, oreos, cocoa nibs, puffed quinoa, M&Ms & salt). The staff were very friendly (especially Yilmar :) ) & happy to give tasters of products; I recommend the chocolate banana jam & cocoa nib tea, which were both incredible! The on-site café is also really nice, with plenty of decadent chocolate drinks (with soy options available!) & treats to choose from & lovely views over Plaza Regocijo. Overall, a nice place to spend a couple of hours & I wish I could visit again!

Chocolate making class. The ChocoMuseo offers a chocolate making class that was SO fun! I had only one other person in my class, which seemed uncommon, so we had a very personalized lesson. You select your cacao beans, heat them, peel the shells, grind them, etc to make 3 types of chocolate drinks and later melted chocolate/flavorings to make candies. Before getting started you go over a basic history of the cacao tree and chocolate history. I felt there could've been more the museum aspect of it, which is why I took off one review point. However, the instructor was awesome (and speaks in English, Spanish, or French) and your drinks/candy are delicious! Definitely recommend.

Its a Trap! But a delicious one...... We went here expecting a "museum". Its really a ploy to get you into the chocolateria, where they make all kinds of sinful chocolate delights. Choose your poison, or try them all... Your tastebuds will thank you.

A fun way to spend the afternoon. I came here twice--once to tour the museum, which is small and cute (with a bunch of free samples at the tasting bar), and again for the chocolate workshop. I would've liked a little more hands-on activities and a little less talking/history during the workshop (since I had already gotten that info on my previous visit), but I had a fun group and got to take home a bunch of chocolates, so in the end it was worth it!

Fun time learning about chocolate!. Stopped by here and did a chocolate making class, and enjoyed a cup of the make your own hot chocolate (with a view!). It was very informational on the process of making chocolate and fun to make your own blend of chocolate. Great place to shop, or take a class!
Really fun. We did the short session of make your own chocolates -- 15 candies for a decent price. We had a good time making them and better time eating them.

Learned a lot about chocolate . For a free museum this place tells you all you need to know about the production of chocolate from growth to the final product.Really great friendly team.Cafe was amazing we went for the sharing chocolate fondant and boy were we glad we did.Fantastic place...., well if you like chocolate anyways.
Waste. Brief description of how cocoa is grown and dried and made into chocolate. There is a 2 hour tour, which we opted not to take.

Quick stop for me. Expected a real museum, but only made it into the first room. Was offered some very small samples by some giggling girls and bought some chocolate to bring home to my mother. I would assume if you wanted to experience this place in its entirity, booking a tour is your best bet. I did eat some dark chocolate later in the day and it was easily the greatest dark chocolate I've ever eaten.Enjoy!

Informative and fun activity. Miguel was very knowledgable about the history of cacao, and I thoroughly enjoyed using the original tools and equipment to start the chocolate making process (thankfully we didn't actually use our own product). A little bit expensive for a 2hr experience, but glad I did it. (Although could use some more air in the kitchen, it got very stuffy)

Free museum with free choclate tasting. We were here on an advise of a friend. Its a small museum on the first floor. The staff were very friendly. Antoniette, the guide in the museum received us and took us through the museum. We got to taste different chocolates, choco drinks, and Chico jams and also liquor. No one forced us to buy anything.
Smells so gooooooood!. Go there on a rainy day, learn something about chocolate production, savor some free samples and spend time in the best smelling place of all of Peru!

Busy spot. My family loved this place although I didn't particularly enjoy it. Entrance is FREE, which is cool for a museum. And there's lots of tastings to try. It can get very very busy in here but if you're a big fan of chocolate, you've found a gem. There's also seating with a view!
Nice for a coffee . Nice to sit down for a coffee and if you want to try different picosecond flavours. It was expensive though.

A fun way to spend an hour or two. We walked in not expecting too much and using this as more or less a throw away use of an hour. But this was actually a lot of fun and surprisingly informative. Plus the chocolate food offerings are actually very good. We ended up buying some chocolate loose leaf tea.
Delicious tour!. Look for a young man named Victor to explain the chocolate process and guide you through samples! He is a great salesman!
Best Hot Chocolate. World class hot chocolate prepared at your table to your liking with fresh melted chocolate, hot milk, honey and chile powder!

Such a Fun Diversion in Cusco. The Choco Museo is not to be missed while visiting Cusco. Conveniently located just a block off the plaza, the short free guided tour gives great information about cacao beans, the history, and process of chocolate making. We had "Jill" as our guide and he was fantastic!! He was very thorough and his English was excellent. The best part - sampling! We could taste the differences in dark, milk, and white chocolate. Then we tasted the differences in chocolate made from beans from different areas. Who knew they could have those nuances? We tasted various flavored jams made with chocolate. And we tasted liqueurs made with chocolate - several samples, as long as we could keep standing perhaps. We finished with smooth creamy hot chocolate made the old fashioned way.Of course they also offer several items for sale in their second floor museum, as well as their shop on the street.We were limited on time so were unable to take either of the 2-hour classes. The class in session at the time seemed to be having a great time though. This should definitely be on anyone's 2-day tour of Cusco. I mean, how many cathedrals and churches and monuments and old buildings can you truly remember? A chocolate museum, tour, and samples? Unforgettable!

Chocolate, chocolate, chocolate. I spent some money here especially on my little chocolate monster daughter. Been several types of bar chocolate, chocolate coffee and more. You can spend some good money here and have a great time. Nice and clean store. Would definitely come back for more. Next time!
very cool. great place with classes for all ages to make chocolate, best hot chocolate in cusco. very clean and on a very nice plaza

Bean to bar!. Who doesn't love chocolate? This place gives you history of chocolate followed by the chance to make your own which is awesome! The experience takes around 2 hours to complete and includes tasting multiple types of chocolate from various regions, the cost is 75 soles per person. A small cost to pay for making your own chocolate! This is highly recommended.Not a lot of pictures due to chocolate being everywhere!
Choco news. Nice little museum where you can try a lot of choco variants: licor, chocolat, maté ... interesting place to have a little stop.
Let's make chocolate. Had a lotion fun in the chocolate workshop today. From bean to my very own handmade chocolates, plus a couple of hot chocolates. A great way to spend a few hours in Cusco.
Fun alternate activity. We had a private (4 of us) introduction to chocolate making. It was extremely informative and entertaining, and we got to take our home-made chocolates home.

Is not a must in Cuzco . The choco museum is not a must in Cuzco is just I tiny store that sells mostly products made out of chocolate. Such as lip balms, choco oil, chocolate tea and Artisanal chocolate

Miguel was awesome and funny!. This was a delicious and fun experiance. There were only the two of us, but Miguel tailored the class to scale. Seeing chocolate from bean to bar was touristy...but not cliche. We really enjoyed this experiance

Something different!. Check this place out! They do free tours of the museum and give you some great background information about where the coca beans come from and how the chocolate is made. They give you samples to try of not only the chocolate but also some liquors and coca tea! The bean to bar workshop is good fun and costs 70soles per person!

Great workshop. We attended the 2 hour chocolate-making workshop, which we thoroughly recommend. Our teacher was good fun and we made two central/south American chocolate drinks before moulding our own milk or dark chocolates, with an endless selection of additions (salt, raisins, m&ms, nuts, flavoured powders etc). You have to wait a little while after the class for your chocolates to set in the fridge, but they are delicious! The shop attached is expensive but after the class you cannot resist buying something!

Nice, quick attraction. Great for a relaxing day in Cuzco. I recommend getting the tour, otherwise you just walk around and read the signs. We got to try a bunch of different chocolates and liquors and after, they have a great selection of chocolate you can purchase. It's small, and quick. As a chocolate lover, I found it interesting. It may be a nice, calm thing to do after walking around all day.

Free attraction!!. A fantastic free attraction. You get to try all different chocolates, jams and alcohol with chocolate in too. You can learn about the history of chocolate in Peru at the same time.It was very interesting.

Good place to sample chocolate not much to see. This is a great place to taste a variety of chocolates but there is not a lot to see in the museum. It is recommended to take one of their cooking classes.

chocolate making class is a show not just a class.. everyone i have spoken to has loved this so it was time to give it a go.the guide was the single best guide ive had the pleasure of working with. we had a class of 14 people and he managed to engage with every single one of us and even spoke several different languages to help people out.the actual experience is done in stages and as some stages take a lot more than 1hr you start them off before having things changed for the finished product. which meant we got to try every stage without getting bored.the whole group had fun, we all got covered in chocolate, we all ate far too much chocolate and we all learnt a lot about chocolate..... mission accomplished.for the money and the time its well worth it and i will recommend this for years to come.

Not much of a museum. As a belgian guy and a month without decent chocolate we were trying our luck in here. The museum was nothing much (only 5 min of reading ) and the chocolate wasn't too special either, but maybe we're just too spoiled.
Best Chocolate Experience. From Bean to Bar Cooking Class to the best chocolate treats……yummy! Great way to spend some free time while in Cusco.

Disappointing. We love chocolate, so decided to spend a couple of hours here learning about it and making it. It was fun tasting it and mixing up different concoctions. Our guide showed us different ways to make hot chocolate and when he got to the Mayan style, he told us it needed blood and asked our teenage son to stick out his tongue to provide it. We thought he was kidding at first, but the guide had a sharp stick and antiseptic. My husband intercepted him and stopped the blood draw! Weird!!! The chocolate we made was not good either.

Make your own Chocolate bars!. Too much fun! Got to make our own chocolate bars from real beans. Our chef was awesome, she made it so fun and educational. And you get to keep the chocolate bars you make. Did I mention the chocolate tasting? the chocolate drinks? If like chocolate, you have to do this!

enjoyable chocolate making class. We enjoyed the chocolate making class that lasted two hours, and we started with raw cocoa beans and got to go through the whole process of peeling the beans, roasting them, crushing them ... all the way through to putting the chocolate in molds & coming back at least two hours later to pick up our home-made chocolates. Everyone got to participate - some of the steps we each did at our own place; some of the steps were done in a central pot and we took turns stirring it etc. If you are a chocolate fanatic, I'd highly recommend the class. I did think that we would learn more about the history of chocolate making during this class, and we did not learn much about that so that was a bit disappointing. The chocolate prices in this store are expensive (eg. $US 6 per 85% dark chocolate bar of 90-100 gms each) but it was yummy chocolate. I did ask at our hotel what is the best chocolate in town, and he told me the Republic of Cocoa which also has a store. Their chocolate prices are 32 soles/bar -- or about 9-10 US$/bar so much more expensive than the ChocoMuseo's prices. One thing we did learn while in Cusco, is that just because a chocolate bar says it is 85% chocolate, doesn't mean it is. We bought a bar marked as 85% chocolate with the brand of 'Machu Picchu chocolate' at the San Pedro market and it was more like a 45-50% cocoa bar. So if you want good chocolate to bring home for friends, best to get one of the better brands so you know it will be good.

Loved the variety of Hot Chocolates. If you like variety and hot chocolate then you MUST visit. Second floor and a view from the window into the square below as you sip on a myriad of tastes in your mouth, provided by the menu on offer. The Museum is always busy with tourists getting hands-on experience of making chocolates etc..but..we prefreed to just sit and sip and watch life go by!!
Great Visit!. We got the chance to make our own chocolate. The host was so funny and entertaining. Enjoyed the presentation and chocolate. Take a visit, it's really fun!
Chocolate fun . My family did the paid tour and chocolate-making. They had a great time and made delicious treats. I waited for them in the on-site cafe and enjoyed cake and a locally brewed beer.

Fun Chocolate Workshop. We had a fun workshop learning how to make chocolate from cacao beans. At times, it was a bit silly having to sing but hey we are on vacation and it was fun. Equally fun visiting the museum while we picked up our chocolate afterward. Good memory and very educational.

Decent chocolate but overpriced . We didn't do the your, just stopped in to buy chocolate. Chocolate bar, regular sized, was 20 Solas. (US$7). Couldn't say no to the kids but wished hadn't stopped in.

Quick Visit. The Choco Mueso was a small place with just a few rooms. Everyone was very nice and inviting. There was a chocolate cooking class that was going on. You can make your own chocolate. I believe the cost was 70 soles a person and there are 3 classes a day. They have everything chocolate: chocolate powder, bars, liquor, and even condoms. The employee was very nice can provided many samples.

Fun activity - do the workshop. This was a great activity! We really loved the longer workshop where we got to learn to make chocolate "from bean to bar." The museum was small and a little low budget. The reason to come is for the gift shop, the cafe, and the workshop. I'd advise calling ahead and scheduling your time for the workshop. We didn't do it and got lucky. They only have three a day (for the longer one), and it was one of my best memories of the trip. I wouldn't want you to miss it!

Perfect family event. We had a extra day to acclimatize in Cusco before trekking to Machu Picchu. With two teenagers, we figured this might be fun. It turned out to be one of the most memorable times during our trip. The Museum walks you through the whole process of learning about the beans, roasting them, grinding them and making our own chocolate. It was super fun, informative and tasty. Highly recommend.

Chocolate workshop ok, products appear poor. My partner and I did their chocolate making workshop, and found it to be OK for what they were offering, if a bit touristy (and particularly seemed more targeted at younger travellers/ backpackers judging by the jokes woven in) and quite expensive at 75 soles each.We still managed to learn something, and even though the ingredients on offer for the chocolate making appeared to be cheaper ingredients, we were pleasantly surprised with the chocolates we left with (we chose to use dark chocolate and were picky about what we put in them, and also managed to snag molds giving us lots of small chocolates).Looking at the products in the shop however they appeared to be quite poor quality - the chocolates they offered for tasting tasted cheap, as did the chocolate liqueurs and jams (the ones we tried tasted like overly sweet, cheap jams with a bit of cocoa mixed in) - so I wouldn't recommend buying anything in the shop.The overall impression we got was that the Choco Museo is just a great big money spinner for whoever owns the chain (we saw others in Ollaytantambo, and Pisac), and we were told by a local it's actually French-owned.

Beverage of the Gods. This business has it right! The branch in Cusco serves incredible hot chocolate. They bring a thick, incredibly good chocolate sauce to your table that you mix with milk to your preference. If you are hungry, there are crepes and some appetizers that were pretty good too. I dare anyone not to get a buzz from this beverage of the gods. It is incredible.

Chocolate lovers. This was 1hour time spent you don,t need a tour guide but there is a lot different type of drinks you can sample with alcohol and then purchase the one you like the best.A lot of different type of chocolates of course 50percent to 100percent dark and white my cousin was driving me crazy with trying different types. I am not much of a chocolate lover. But she had a blast.I sample the drinks all 6 types. Lol

So much fun!. I took my grandmother for the workshop, and we both had an amazing time. Not only is the workshop educational but it is thoroughly entertaining. Our teacher was amazing and extremely welcoming. she made us laugh and encouraged a bit of silliness. I would recomend this for anyone , even if you go by yourself the workshop is extremely interactive and you will feel like a part of the group.

Love this place be sure to visit the cafe!. You may get short of breath climbing the stairs to the Choco museo but it will be worth it when you get to the top! I didn't do the tour but the café is excellent, especially the Mexican hot chocolate. Don't miss it!

Fun Chocolate Museum. Free museum with lively guides who tell you lots about chocolate and give you lots of opportunity to try lots of different things. Puts you in the right frame of mind to buy things! Opportunity to do some classes to create your own chocolate - looked full so no chance to join.

Lots of fun!. Did the "Beans to Bar" workshop and had a great time. The museum and workshop area are super cute with a little cafe and things for sale. Our class was full but we all got a chance to make and taste chocolate drinks and chocolates. Our teacher was a lot of fun, spoke perfect English and was very well informed. We each left with a dozen chocolates we had made ourselves. Delicious:-)Would definitely recommend for something low key to do in Cusco while getting used to the altitude. There were couples and families - all seemed to have a good time.

The class was a delight!. We read about the "bean to bar" class and were pretty much hooked as soon as we read about it. The class was offered 3 times per day and takes 2+ hours. Included in said class was an overview of where the beans come from, the process of fermentation that makes them legit and then an actual class during which you make the chocolate we all love!During the class, you roast, peel, crush, grind and taste chocolate throughout the process of it becoming some dreamy Valentine's Day delight! We learned that roasted beans give off banana, coffee and olive notes - cool party knowledge, check!After finishing the process of prepping the beans, you try three different drinks - chocolate tea, Mayan hot chocolate and Peruvian hot chocolate (not sure if that's the real name, but that's what we called it). Following the drinks, you get to pour your own chocolates and mix them with any fixins you like! After pouring they take an hour to set so don't make the mistake we did of having to leave right after the class. They were super accommodating however and rushed our ( in a freezer we think).A really fun and unique way to spend a few hours in Cusco. Well worth the $25 per person!
If you love chocolate. Very neat place with both a museum of sorts, chocolate making classes and retail store with a lot of chocolate options.

Chocolate Class. I did the "Bean to Bar" chocolate class at the ChocoMuseum. It was great to hear about the process from the instructor (who was great), but there was a lot less hands-on experience than I was expecting. The class boasts of "making your own chocolates", but that just means pouring already-prepared chocolate into molds and adding some toppings. I think I'll go for the "Truffles" class next time. :)Tasty though! Definitely stop by to pick up some choco bean husks for making tea!!

Delicious and fun!. We took the "from bean to bar" class that goes over the chocolate making process in a very interactive way. You get to peel, crush, puree, and roast the beans, try some local chocolate drinks, hear about the history of chocolate, and of course-everyone's favorite part- make your own chocolate to bring home!!
Fun. We had a free day in Cusco and my kids wanted to do the chocolate making class; it's a fun couple of hours playing with chocolate.

Loved the Choco Museo in Cusco. Did just the basic guided tour through the museum with an elementary, but thorough explanation of the process of bean harvest to actual chocolate end-product. Much self-guided information provided as well in diagram form and captions about the history of chocolate, etc. in both Spanish and English. The added bonus of tasting various types of chocolate was great. The museum also sells a variety of chocolate-based products. The White Chocolate Chirimoya Liqour is definitely a worthy find along with many of the chocolate treats to take home. An hour and a half well-spent.

Excellent experience. Gil the instructor was excellent. The whole experience was Informative, funny and tasty. A great way to spend a leisurely morning. We did not have children with us but the other children there really seemed to enjoy themselves.

Workshop was great! . We did the 2h workshop with Antonieta. It was informative, fun, memorable and gave us a chance to be creative and appreciate all the work that goes into making chocolate. That being said, once we picked up our chocolates and tried them, they weren't that appetising, the main reason being the quality of the chocolate provided which is a shame. The museum has many different sections to read about and the shop offers samples. Prices are expensive. Cafe is great for people watching and to sample different chocolate beverages.
Expensive but fun. I had a great time. Jill, the host, was very entertaining and fun. The chocolates I made were not very tasty, but I love the raw cacao nibs I purchased from the Museum shop.

2 hr Chocolate making was outstanding!. Family of 4 with an 8 yo and 10 yo... The two hour class was expertly delivered to entertain and inform. Our teacher "Gill" was hilarious. And of course the chocolate is great too!

Good Educational Quick Tour. We had to zip into the ChocoMuseu as we were running out of time in Cusco.We were given a free concise, but very informative tour and history of chocolate and its varying flavors depending on the region it is made. Really interesting and free samples!Lots of wonderful products available for purchase.There is a class, but we were in too big a hurry to participate. It looked interesting.The building the museum is housed in is old and interesting and you can get some fantastic shots of the nice square from the upstairs windows.Enjoyed our visit!

yum, yum, yummy!. we signed up for the chocolate making class and were thrilled! the host stepped us through the entire process, and we tasted hot chocolates and left with some amazing chocolates...handmade by us :) one suggestion: the class was held in a somewhat public area and noise from other customers not in the class was distracting. limiting other customers from that area would help significantly.

Really informative!. We just decided to stop in here during a walk around Cusco and were pleasantly surprised. The free tour was informative and the free samples were certainly a bonus. We wished we had signed up for the course afterwards!

Overrated. It's nice they offer a free "tour" in the shop. We ordered the chocolate mousse cake, an iced chocolate drink and the chocolate ice cream - all were mediocre at best and not cheap either. Can't really recommend this place other than the balcony is good for people watching and killing time.

So much fun!. Jilcito made our chocolate making class extremely fun! We learnt about the process, had fun making hot chocolate and eventually our own chocolate! Highly recommended group activity or even for solo travellers!

Fun! More than you can imagine.. We did not plan to tour the chocolate museum as we were finishing up our Alexander and Roberts tour but others on the tour suggested it as it seemed to have potential. IT WAS FANTASTIC. We strongly urge anyone - not just those with children with them- to take the chocolate making class at the ChocoMuseo. It was a blast!! It lasted 2 hours and turned out to be one of the unique and enjoyable experiences in Cusco. The chocolate that you make you get to keep and that was also delicious. Pedro made the experience even better. There is not any downside. Do the class.

Chocolate making class. Our kids (14, 13, 9) loved their 45 min mini chocolate making class. They were able to choose the chocolate molds & toppings. The chocolates were ready to be picked up less than an hour later. The museum is small, but interesting. There's also a cafe and shop. Fun stop for kids in Cusco!

Awesome. Great experience, very knowledgeable guide who was great at english. Entrance and guided tour is free and recommended. It is courtesy to purchase something from the shop after the tour, but the products are great as well.

How Fun!. 75 soles for the chocolate workshop and it was pretty fun! I went with 3 other girls and we all had a blast. It was informative but all very interactive. We also got to make our own to take home! Keep in mind the workshop is 2 hours, but you have to wait for your chocolate to cool for another hour before getting to take it with you. So if you're pressed for time and can't wait that hour, you may not be able to bring home chocolate!

Gladys is amazing!. Great time here. Free tour with some samples led to us booking a class the next day with Gladys who was simply amazing. Great location, great tastes and great things to take home here!

Really sweet time. My mom came to visit me in cusco and wanted to learn about Peru's chocolate culture! We had a great time taking the chocolate workshop (bean to bar): it was a nice group of people and a charismatic workshop leader. Taking home the chocolate you make was just another perk

Amazing private chocolate making class. So much fun for our family; 2 adults and three children 6, 8 and 13 all thoroughly enjoyed this informative and fun class. We learned a lot about the process of chocolate making in a very hands-on and interactive manner. We roasted and ground our own cocoa beans to make our chocolate drinks. The class culminated in our creating our own truffles. Highly recommend this for families. They also have a small shop and cafe- alas we did not have an opportunity to taste the creations at the cafe.

Making some chocolate!. My boyfriend and I did the Beans to Bar chocolate making class. It was a wonderful experience learning about how the beans are prepared to make the chocolate (even hot chocolate and cacao tea!) and having the opportunity to make it! The instructor was very interactive with the group, with involvement in different demonstrations.Overall a great and tasty experience!

Great Visit . As someone who is not always a chocolate fan, I was not sure if I would enjoy the museum. The brief tour was conducted by Miguel, his professionalism, enthusiasm, and depth of knowledge for what he does made this tour fantastic. Not only was I fascinated about the process, Miguel also found flavor combinations in the "sampling" portion of the tour that I really loved. I'll be going back for the upcoming chocolate beer event.

Worth a brief visit - it's free!. We happened to visit the ChocoMuseo in both Cusco and in Lima. The young lady at the one in Cusco was very friendly and allowed us to try multiple chocolates, the choco tea and such. It's worth a brief visit to see how the cocoa beans are harvested and processed, but I would not travel out of your way to visit.

Delicious Tour...and Free. My fellow trekkers and I had such a great time at the Museo tasting chocolates, beans and liquors :) If I could have bought one of every item, I would have! Remember that the tasting room is around the corner on the side street, upstairs on 2nd floor, from the retail store which is on the main street overlooking the Plaza.

A great time at the museum!. We spent 2 hours at the chocolate bar workshop and loved it! We tried 3 types of hot chocolate, and worked on our own bag of chocolates (we tested them after the workshop and they were very good). The leader was spirited and funny, and the kids asked to go back the following day.

Such a fun place!. Our guide, Jill, was a great guy. Super funny. The "museum" is tiny and takes not time at all, but is super worth while. The tastings themselves are worth it. The chocolate is cheaper than you can find anywhere else. Sadly, we forgot ALL the things we bought when we had to store them in the kitchen of the Amazon lodge we stayed in...

Informative and fun! . The tour was wonderful. You learned a lot about the making of chocolate from a knowledgeable guide. You got to try many types of chocolate and goods made from chocolate (spreads, liquor, hot chocolate, etc.) Easy to find.
Yummylicious. This was a nice short visit between tours. The selection of items food and cosmetics was great. We are enjoying our purchases as I type!

Just went for chocolate, not the workshop. Nice place with great view over the Plaza Regocijo. the chocolate was delicious & rich - thought it was rather small on arrival at the table, but realised afterwards that it was just the right size to leave space for something else. The chocolate making workshop was underway & looked fun from the outside.

make your own chocolate!. I can't speak much to the museum itself, but we did the chocolate class (beans to bar) and had a fantastic time. It only costs about $25 USD for 2 hours and it is informative and absolutely hilarious.. I think 100% of the people in attendance had a blast!

Expensive . They offer you free samples of their tea, which is delicious. It's very expensive to shop here. Save your money and buy your chocolate at the market. 3soles for a chocolate bar at the market and 18 soles for a slightly larger size at the ChocoMuseo. It's an interesting place to visit though so it's worth popping by.

Delicious chocolates. The chocolate making class was so much fun. The instructor was really funny and kept us all entertained the entire time. I loved all of the drinks and treats we made. My advice would be to eat the chocolate within the few days of making it. While delicious at first, mIne did not fare so well after a week!

Great free tour and fun cooking class. We went in the morning and we got a 20 minutes free tour that was very interesting and we got to sample different types of chocolate. We took a chocolate making class in the afternoon that was fun and we got to take the chocolates we made with us. Their chocolate was amazing!
Not much of a museum, good choc . Wouldn't go for a tour or lesson in chocolate making but worth a stop in to see the process and get some terrific chocolate at a fair price.

Brilliant!. I went on the chocolate making class and found it brilliant! They explained everything from the bean to chocolate process! Very interactive and fun! Would definitely recommend to everyone!

Great coffee in a quirky location. Went to ChocoMuseo twice during our visit to Cusco. The Mocachino and French Press coffee were some of the best we found in the area. Brownies will put back on all the calories burned hiking the Inka Trail!

Informative displays and good cocolate. The museum gives you good overall information about the history of chocolate, how it is grown, processed and packaged. You can also take a class in making chocolate. The best thing is the aroma of chocolate that of course makes you want to buy some. There are milk and plain chocolates in a variety of flavors, all very god to the taste from my experience.

interesting. This was a small location and we saw that they were making chocolate in the kitchen off to the side, though we didn't try it. We did do the small self guided tour, and then sample many of the different coca items. You can purchase many of the items there.

Delightful Chocolate Making Class!. Tauck booked a chocolate making class for our multifamily tour group at the ChocoMuseo, and I'm so very glad they did. The kitchen session was led by Gladys, a wonderful instructor who spoke very good English. She explained the process of making chocolate, spreading out chocolate beans still in their hulls which we removed with our fingers, and then chewed on a bit of the bean to discover its complexity of flavor including hints of banana and vinegar. She then set up the chunky ingredients (ranging from raisins, coffee beans, and almonds to marshmallows and M&Ms) and also the shaker ingredients (cinnamon, sea salt, chili pepper, coca, ginger and more.) We selected molds to shape our candies and whether we wanted dark or milk chocolate. After some final instructions on how to fill and tamp out air bubbles, she let us at it. There were shakers going back and forth, ingredients added, slight pandemonium, and lots of laughter. It was a delightful interlude and we received our completed, cooled candies at the hotel. I can't speak to the restaurant but we found some nice reasonable trip gifts, including $5 earrings, chocolate bath salts, and (naturally) candy. Also, a not unimportant thing when traveling with families, the best public restroom we went to in Peru.

Only ok.. We happened upon a more local chocolate museum that had WAY BETTER chocolate for way better prices too. They didn't speak much English at all when we went in but that was ok. This shop was good and they spoke English but it was so busy I just wanted to get out which meant I didn't buy anything.

food is food but chocolate is nectar of the gods!. took a bit or searching as we thought it was ground floor level. history of chocolate, see the cocoa beans (taste them too!) background to making of cooking and dessert choc. choc from different regions of Peru can be bought.all natural ingredients. they also offer choc making course which is very popular but we didn't have the time. a small coffee/chocolate area looked inviting! quite expensive but our exchange rate is pretty terrible at the moment. dollar and euro owners found it very reasonable!.

When they're busy, they can lose track of you. My wife and I had such a nice experience there last year, that I had to take my daughter this year! Well, a LOT depends on your server. And how busy the place is. I ordered a hot chocolate, and my daughter a "fondue." Both came soon enough, but our waiter had made clear we were to pay him. Except he never came back to the table. Eventually we wandered out to the cash register and paid there.But we did get a balcony table, so we did get to watch dusk fall on Plaza Regocijo! Still worth the time.

Delicious and fun. Do it! It's a fun learning experience that ends with delicious chocolates you make yourself. You learn about the cocoa plant from seedling to tasty final product. The staff are friendly, knowledgeable and super entertaining.
Yummy. Chocolate liquor was delicious. Also the many combinations of chocolate with other things like banana and hazelnuts was sinfully good. History of chocolate was informative.

Fun and delicious!. I did the bean to bar workshop and it was an awesome experience. "Pedro Wonka" guided us through the chocolate making process, and it was an excellent combination of being interactive as well as informational. He was soooo funny and also so knowledgeable! You get to taste chocolate along the way as well as keep your own chocolate at the end. Would highly recommend:)

When you are done hiking, eat chocolate!. This was a great way to spend a couple of hours before heading to the airport for our flight back to Lima. We thoroughly enjoyed learning about chocolate making and loved roasting and grinding our own beans to make our own. The workshop was very relaxed and would be good for all ages. Of course there are tastings, too, but mostly just two hot drinks. We did bring home our own chocolate, though. Very enjoyable!

Great chocolate making course. Really enjoyed the two hour chocolate making course - we cooked the beans and then ground them down before making two different hot chocolate drinks. We then got to make our own chocolates with different fillings - well worth it and only 75 soles each.

Fun workshops, delicious chocolates. My husband and I took the bean to bar workshop. The location is central and was a quick wall from our hotel. The class size was small. Our instructor, Yil, made the class fun for everyone and offered to take pictures along the way. You get to take home chocolates that you make which is a wonderful souvenir. This is a good event for a variety of ages, interests and activity levels. I highly recommend adding this to your list in Cusco!
Fun to learn, taste and purchase chocolate. I came home with chocolate and chocolate tea. We loved this cute museum and the mission to protect the environment and fair pay for farmers.
We Ate It Up. This is an interesting look at the Peruvian production of chocolate. Great samples and informative staff. Free admission.

A delicious mid afternoon stop. Tucked into the second floor of an interior courtyard this place is a little hard to find from the street. The shop has a little museum area on the second floor and the attendants are very happy to walk you through (with tasters) their various chocolate offerings. The only problem is you end up wanting to buy everything. Major credit cards accepted.

The chocolates we made were divine!. We did the 2 hour tour, learning about the art of chocolate making was OK, but the real fun was in doing it ourselves. You make a sheet mold of chocolates, mine were 16 small, hubby had 8 large and they were our supper treats for the next several days...yum!

Informative tour. The free tour was very informative. There were also free tastings of various liqueurs and chocolate products.There was a large range of chocolate products for sale but they were all quite expensive.

Workshop was lots of fun. My friends and I came down the chocolate workshop which went for a little over 2 hours. It was well run, interactive and lots of fun. It was very interesring to see how chocolate was made from start to finish. There was lots of chocolate to eat at the end after you make your own whicb was very yummy. I also visted the museum prior to doing the work shop for the free samples and the cafe which were both great. However if your making the trip I would definitely recommend doing the work shop.

Fun tour and a must see in Cusco. The free tour is informative and involves a tea, chocolate liquor, and mini chocolate tasting. We also did the chocolate making class, which was a must do if you have 2 hours to spare! The instructor spoke great English and was very knowledgeable about the process and the history! You get to make a few different chocolate drinks and then get to make a bag of chocolates for yourself.
Very good chocholate. We bought here some very nice original Peruvian chocholates with salt and pecan I was very sorry later I havent bought more ,also assorted truffles .
Only had a short time to visit. I was only here for a short visit but they were very knowledgeable about chocolate making and my daughter took a tour the day before and was very pleased.

Fun way to spend a few hours. This place was really fun. They give you free chocolate tea and then the tour begins. It was very interesting to learn the process of making chocolate from start to finish. I bought a lot to take home

For any chocolate lover . Liqueurs, milk chocolate, dark chocolate, moisturiser, lip balm, biscuits, tea or makeup... It's all made from Peruvian coffee beans for you to take home with you as a momento.Not sure if you'd like it? Guess what? You can try it before you buy it! Take the time to walk around and explore the history that is explained around the walls on this double level little shop. You're welcomed with a nice chocolate tea by the staff and they offer chocolatier classes where you learn more about the coffee beans and get to make some chocolate and of course eat it. A great history about chocolate in Peru and so many momento to take home with you.Definitely worth a visit. The best part is that the chocolate blocks they make there are in the shape of inca walls. A true momento!

Free chocolate tasting and amazing cafe. We came here twice and the second time I ate WAY too much. The staff are lovely in the cafe and you can try the free chocolate out front. Make sure you have the hot chocolate with cream and try the cheesecake! I stopped at lots of these around SA but enjoyed this one the best!
30th anniversary trip to Peru . This is not a museum. It is a way overpriced chocolate shop. Go to the San Pedro market a few blocks away and get similar chocolate for less than half the price

Beans to Bar Class- LOVED IT. This was def one of my favorite activities I did while in Cusco. I eventually was done we all the ruins visit and wanted to do something different. I'm so glad i took this class. The instructor (who I wish I remember her name) was very entertaining and informative. I highly recommend the class. Plus you get to each chocolate made by yourself.

Something quick and different. I was in the plaza de armas area and walking around, received a flyer promoting the museo. It was an interesting 20 minutes, and something definitely worth taking a look at. They have different variations of chocolate worth trying and their prices are reasonable.
Neat little museum. Well laid out and a quick visit. If you plan in advance and have enough time you can pay for a two-hour session making your own chocolate!
A good stop over. We stopped in here when we were acclimating on day 1: learned a little about choco, had a few taste tests, and chilled in the cafe with a delicious hot coco.

Chocolate information overload. This small 2 storey building gives a very good informative tour of the growing and making of chocolate. It's free and worth an hour of your time if you are keen on facts and figures. Great range of chocolate flavours and unusual uses for chocolate for sale.

Worth a Stop for the Samples . This museum has a free tour, a cooking class (about $30USD,), a cafe, and stores where you can buy as much local chocolate as your heart desires. The free tour only took about 30 minutes and we got a ton of free samples. Plus the guide was fun and informative. Definitely worth a stop in!

Take a cooking class or chocolate making class, FUN!. We took a chocolate making class. Pedro was the instructor. He spoke many languages, we had a great fun group of people from everywhere, and Pedro kept us laughing. We had so much fun! The chocolate was great and the history lesson of Peruvian chocolate was interesting also.
If You Like Chocolate...... Great display of bean plant all the way to the finished product. Unusual combinations of flavors in their chocolate for sale.

Short Visit to the ChocoMuseo. This is a great place to go if you're looking for something free to do in Cusco. I visited the ChocoMuseo with a friend, and we took a short tour around the museum, tried different chocolates and chocolate syrups, and briefly looked over the instructional areas.The best part was sitting on the terrace overlooking the square below and sipping on a hot chocolate with amaretto. Not a bad way to spend an hour in the afternoon.

Afternoon visit to the Choco museum. We stopped by this little museum to buy some Chocolat and we were surprised how friendly everyone was and how interesting the chocolate classes were. The Caffe has great desserts, coffee and beer. The store downstairs is full of interesting product based on cacao. I wouldn't say it is the best chocolate you can find in the area but worth a try for the big array of flavors options with spicys .

Fun chocolate class. Took a chocolate making class here after my friend recommended it. The instructor was great, really funny and informative and made the class more enjoyable. The chocolate they have on sale is delicious and there's lots of variety on offer. Nice place to just enjoy a coffee and slice of cake too. If you're a fan of chocolate then make sure you stop by whilst in Cuzco.

Fun and interesting place to visit. Not much to say but that I found this a fun place to visit. Friendly, knowledgeable staff in the shop. Tasting different chocolates and syrup mixtures was interesting.

Willy Wonka's experience . Just love it!, i love chocolate but this was totally different experience. I ordered a willy wonka's style, with milk and marshellows, SO DELICIOUS. my other friends order a "Mayan" with milk honey and pepper. Singular hot chocolate but recommend too. Worth the stop and if you sit on the balcony with good company and hot chocolate, it would be the best in the world. Just contemplated the amazing view of the square with a hot chocolate.

Free sample!. This is a museum + store. You can see the brief process of making chocolate from cacao. But I think the one in Lima is better. You can have sample chocolate as well as a cup of tea. There is chili chocolate too. Interesting!

Tourist trap worth a visit. Definitely a tourist trap but worth a stop. The Museo itself was ok at best. The cafe had pretty good coffees. The mochachino my daughter has was great. My coffee came in a French Press which I thought was odd. The best coffee drinks were at the nearby Museo de Cafe.

Delicious. The best brownie I ever tasted, also great the hot chocolate. You can learn to prepare chocolate there as they have continuous workshops with Master Chocolatiers. Very nice to learn how many products they create from cacao. You can taste and learn about this product.

Chocolate making class. Fun way to relax after lots of hiking, climbing and sightseeing. Gained a better understanding of growing, harvesting and preparing chocolate and chocolate drinks. Our instructor knew how to organize a group. Her engaging style made the session a memorable experience for all the participants.
Good free tour. They do a mini a tour were you learn about how chocolates made, chocolate tasting and more. Fun thing to do if you have 30 mins spare.

Loving & fun afternoon in Cusco! Delicious!. We decided to visit the ChocoMuseo after returning from a 5 day trek to Machupicchu. The staff warmly welcomed us in and provided a general overview of the process of chocolate making from cacao. If you want more in-depth knowledge or to practice making chocolate, they offer classes. We were served cacao tea and treated very well. The food is also delicious! We spent an hour in the cafe sitting in the sun and soaking in the energy and life of Cusco in the afternoon! I highly recommend a visit!

Cooking Class. Choco Museo cooking class was outstanding! Gladys was the best teacher ever! We had so much fun going to the market, learning about all of the local products and dishes, making pisco sours, and prepping and cooking wonderful dishes! We learned so much from Gladys and thoroughly enjoyed her company!!!

Chocolate class. We came here with most of our group to participate in the two hour chocolate making class. Our instructor was very friendly and knowledgeable as she took as through all the steps that goes into making chocolate (even with a brief city-wide power outage!). The chocolate drinks that we got to sample during class were delicious. I enjoyed making my own chocolates-but here's a tip, go light on any sea salt added. There were some chocolates in our group that turned out inedible because of too much salt! You will have to come back in an hour to pick up your chocolates so plan accordingly. We brought back some chocolate flavor samplers as gifts for our family too. This was a fun activity to do if you have a few days to spend in Cusco and are tired of the usual museum/church scene.

Chocochocolocoloco! :). Had soooo much fun in the evening chocolate making class with Pedro last year! I ended up there as I wanted a cooking class but due to a mix up on my part I double booked myself (the office staff were the nicest about it by the way, especially considering my own idiocy!). What sticks out in my mind was the Mayan hot chocolate... spicy, wonderful and I wish I had some right now. Ended up 'winning' some chocolate tea for pounding the cacao beans the fastest too. Pedro definitely made it fun, and I'm so glad I signed up for this chocolate class in Cusco :)

As educational as it was delicious!. What a fun stop in Cusco! Our guide was very knowledgeable and had a great sense of humor. The presentation was short and included plenty of opportunities to taste at the end.

Chocolate....mmmmm!. Very interesting place which tells the history of the cocoa & chocolate. There's usually a guide who will walk you through and explain things or you can walk through on your own & read what's on the walls. There are other activities that you can pay to participate in besides the free tour. They do give you small samples of chocolate tea & a couple other things. Of course, there are lots of flavors of chocolate to buy as well as non-edible items, too.
If you want to know about Chocolate, come here.. A quick small museum with tasty samples. It's close to the historical area of Cusco and worth a stop.

Fun and tasty treat. I took the 2 hour chocolate making class. The teacher was fun entertaining. We got details on the origins, history of coco bean and got to make our own chocolates that we got to take at the end of the class. Recommend if you want to relax from all the site seeing in Cusco.

Fun, Interesting. 14 of us on an Overseas Adventure Travel Trip to Peru and Ecuador went here with our tour guide. Yilmar, a very funny guy, entertained us as we learned about Peruvian chocolate and tried samples of chocolate jellies, candy, and syrups. We had a good time but I would have much preferred to spend our limited time in Cusco doing more meaningful explorations.

I love chocolate. I love that the chocolate is organic and locally made. Staff wasn't too helpful. Also, unfortunately there's not enough room to sit and enjoy. I understand that the location is the location and I'm not trying to be too picky but it is what it is. It's good for an in and out purchase which is what I did.
Chocolate Museum. Kind of commercial. Seems that they just want to sell some chocolate. OK since it was free. Chocolate was good.

Worth a stop. Cool museum and tasting, fun introduction to the process of making chocolate, although the guide was oddly arrogant and came of as a pompous primary school teacher, quizzing the group on the process of growing and making chocolate as if we should have studied before hand. I found it amusing but the looks on the faces of others in the group indicated they were irritated by it.

Fun and relaxing way to spend an afternoon. Took the afternoon chocolate cooking tour and really enjoyed it. First, we learned about the origin of chocolate and cocoa fruit and the process of making chocolate from scratch. Then we took to the kitchen to crush, peel, roast and grind the cocoa beans up to what would normally be a useful paste. Given time constraints, we then switched to pre made chocolate to then assemble our own chocolate using different seeds, spices, nuts and sprinkles (M&M and Oreos were a true crowd pleaser).Once our moulds were full we were then encouraged to lick the bowl and the chocolate was delicious! The chocolate was then set and we could pick it up an hour later. Applicable to all ages and good value for money in my opinion, a great way to spend the afternoon!

Yum!. Great place to pick up chocolate to bring home. There is a great variety of milk and dark chocolate, all organic with distinct flavors.Make sure you try the chocolate tea made with the shells of the cocoa bean. Delicious!
Interesting . The choco museum is a small but interesting museum in cusco and it is free. We got a lot of information about chocolate is made and got to taste a lot of chocolate based stuff.
Choco Making Class was Fun!. Highly recommend the 2 hour choco making class. Guy taking us was fun and the chocolate tasted great at the end. Highly recommended!

A Fun Visit. This is a quick, easy and fun stop. If you love chocolate, stop here. Learn how chocolate is made. Tip: Time this a a dessert stop at their cafe. Note: They also offer chocolate making classes.

Best chocolate liquor. The ChocoMuseo was a fun place to stop in after a long day walking around Cusco. The staff were friendly and extremely generous with giving out free samples. We were able to try out a wide range of their products, from their chocolate moisturizing lotion (which smells absolutely divine), to tasting their chocolate spreads (our favorite was the brazil nut), chocolate bars (including one infused with coca leaves) and the best part, their chocolate liquors. Suffice it to say, a large part of our suitcase ended up dedicated to their chocolate products.
chocolate, chocolate, chocolate. Hard to find, ask a local. If you stay longer take a class. Very interesting free samples. Recommended MeuterMedia
ChocoFantastico!. We enjoyed a great little intro to the world of making chocolate. The hosts were friendly, informative, and well prepared.

Chocolate workshop - so much fun!. We went to ChocoMuseo on our first full day in Cusco, as we wanted a fun activity which wouldn't leave us too exhausted at the city's high altitude. Arriving just before the 11am session, we enquired as to whether there were still spaces. Fortunately for us, there were - although having gone back in the afternoon to collect our chocolates, I'm not sure we'd have been able to get into the afternoon session, so overall I would recommend booking in advance.Our tutor, Gladys, was fun and informative. She also switched effortlessly between Spanish and English to ensure that everyone in the group was catered for. With an introduction to the cocoa bean and how it is harvested, stored and fermented, we were well set up for our hands-on experience. I won't spoil too many surprises here, but it's fair to say that almost all stages of "bean to bar" are covered, and that you do get to be very hands on. Also, Gladys nearly got the better of us with a little joke; a quick Google search when we got home confirmed what we thought - that she'd been pulling our leg :-)The only stage that's excluded, for timing purposes, is the tempering of the chocolate; even then, we were given a good explanation, but given the complexity and the time required it makes sense that we didn't get to have a try ourselves.Finally, we were able to create our own chocolate flavour combinations - I'm enjoying mine as I type!Afterwards, I enjoyed a brownie and a cup of chocolate tea in the cafe - a nice, relaxing and reasonably-priced way to pass the time before heading back to the workshop to collect my handiwork!

Great activity for a slow day. We did this class with our 8 year old the day after Machu Picchu as a slow and mellow day. It was so fun. The woman who taught the class was funny and bright. We learned about how chocolate is made and made our own chocolates to take home. Delish!

Best Hot Chocolate of All Time!!. Regarding the historical/educational content of the museum I can't comment.I was told the hot chocolate was a can't miss, and it absolutely did not disappoint. It was the most delicious hot chocolate of all time. See the attached photo, it's picture perfect. Highly recommended for quick stop between tours or at the end of a long day.

Very nice place . The Choco museo was really nice and it smelled delicious. We did the free tour first which was great and free(however small) and then the chocolate workshop which was really fun. Our guide/teacher was very nice and sweet however at times hard to understand her English

Small museum and shop dedicated to chocolate.. The museum is on the second floor, and you have to hunt for it - round a corner and upstairs in a courtyard. The people were very welcoming, but really, there wasn't much about the history of cacao at all. There were classes available, but it was not clear how you signed up, or when. There were chocolate samples - great! In the end, it seemed to be mostly a chocolate shop.

A Cusco "must do". My husband, a friend and I attended the 45 minute class as we were short on time and we were all so happy we did! It was packed with interesting chocolate infromation and we got to make our own unique chocolates to take home with us and lick the delicious melted chocolate we did not use from the bowl! What a treat for anyone who loves chocolate. The class was totally worth it. They fit us in as our schedule was tight, and I am sure if you have more time that the longer class would be great! Also we had children in our class (about 9 and 12) and they enjoyed it!

Chocolate lovers will love this. A small museum which takes only an hour to visit but can be longer if you wish to do a class. Thorough information on the history of chocolate and how its made plus you can try the different types of chocolate and the many chocolate liquors, the highlight of the visit. Plus there is a shop where you can buy them very reasonably priced.

Unique and Fun. Although they have a first floor store, the actual museum, cafe, and class is on the second floor and can only be accessed by walking around the corner and entering through an open door and up stairs (it can be tricky).There are several reasons why we are giving the ChocoMuseo a 5-star review. We signed up for the chocolate making class and it was SO MUCH FUN (well, the first 20 minutes that is)! My son was ill about 20 minutes into the class and one of the employees immediately approached him with coca tea, rubbed tea leaves on his forehead, and gave him some liquid that she fetched out of a first aid kit. She was very kind and caring. We weren't able to complete the class unfortunately and luckily my son only suffered briefly from dehydration (it was a hot day).We were able to return to the second floor cafe and store after our Inca Trail hike/Machu Picchu trip and was sitting in the cafe drinking and eating when both the lady that helped my son and the man that was teaching the class remembered us. We spent about 2 hours in the cafe enjoying the surroundings. While at the register waiting to purchase all the fun chocolately goodies, we were offered a 10% discount!Not only is the ChocoMuseo extremely educational, but it is comfortable, kind of like your family's kitchen. If you have kids, I would definitely not miss it.

Moved. Well this museum was not where my guide book said it was. But with a little chance we stumbled upon it. The tour was free and was very informative from our hilarious Swiss guide. And at the end you get to taste liqueur, chocolate and tea. Fun...

Really great fun and educational. We had great fun learning about and making chocolate as a group. The course lasted about 2 1/2 hours and Pedro kept us amused and informed all the time. We would recommend this.

Free and friendly . Right, the staff spoke excellent English and was super friendly they gave me free samples of chocolate and tea afterwards. It was all delicious! It is quite small but it's free so it's more than worth it

choco market. of course this museum is primarily a store selling their chocolate, but it's fairly interesting to see the process if you are unfamiliar. great trip for kids although it can be a little crowded.
If you have time in your hands. Came just for curiosity, not a roomy place to receive a lot of tourists at a time. Nice explanations and employees.

Hands on vehind the scenes of chocolate production. We had a fun afternoon learning heaps about cacao & the making of chocolate. Really interesting, heaps of fun and really delicious. Our host was super entertaining and knowledgeable. As I cannot have cow's milk I gave them a headsup and they swapped it for soy milk (nobody noticed the difference).

What a mess, below zero holiday feeling. We went today to the chocomuseo to try their chocolate milk and some of their snacks. One can ask: what can go wrong knowing that their product quality is decent according to Peruvian standards. Well, many things are not OK- staff: clearly each employee does not know its responsibility as they are litterally jumping around. We had 4 different waiters, asking the same questions - also after order was placed. Our 'main' waiter was completely unstructured, laughing around withcolleagues without attention for the guests. Very unprofessional. Openess is great if it remains professional. How can you Enjoy your drink if they litterally are taking away each fork, plate or glass once its finished? Its means to be superb service but it gives you the complete opposite feeling. Like they are constantly looking at you. Also no question if you enjoyed it or not.- product: as said decent. The chocolate fondue however was with rather cold chocolate making it impossible to eat with the fruit- visitors: great that its a museum as well, but if you are drinking a chocolate milk with 30 people shouting around you, there is only a crowded mess after all and it takes away the Joy of drinking your hot chocolate completely. Nice view if you can catch a spot on the terrace.- payment: you need to go to the cashier to pay, where another employee needs to type in your full order again.Sadly i'm not just An old pensioner picky on everything, but a 26yo not liking to write bad reviews.

Delicious chocolate tea!. Mmm had a wonderful experience visiting the museum. We were treated at the front door and given a quick tour discussing the history of cacao in Peru, then shown to the cacao tea and hot chocolate samples before being let loose in the store and restaurant area.
