We went with the special of the day: crepes with ice cream, which were large portions and tasty. The museum had lots of different items that could be bought, ranging from tea, chocolate bars (of course), creams and lip glosses, liqueurs and more - great for souvenirs for back home!

Well worth the stop while in Plaza de Armas!!!. I had read about this museum but was not all that excited to visit but was so glad we did. The museum is just right of the presidential palace and better yet it was free. The young lady inside greeted us and asked if we needed help and if it was better to speak in English. She spoke quite well and was very knowledgeable about chocolate in Peru. She offered us choco tea and it was so good we bought 5 bags of it. Also a unique gift to give. My 9 yr old son learned lots at the museum and I as well. It's not big but well worth a visit.

Perfect for chocolate lovers. We discovered this place by chance when walking around Cusco and I'm glad we did. The have a small shop in the first floor but also a "coffee" place upstair where you can taste several chocolate licors at the chocolate tasting bar and create your own chocolate beverage (mine was a combination of cumin, cinnamon and aji pepper, delicious!)And it is not only about chocolate drink, you get to buy chocolate tea, chocolate nibs and chocolate made cosmetic products such as soaps, creams and scrubs. The place has great environment and balconies for you to sit facing the plaza. Great to go at night!If you don't get to go to Cusco, they also have stores in Lima and Ollantaytambo.
Chocolates. If you are a chocolate lover, you need to stop by the Choco Museum. Free chocolate to try. Varieties of chocolate and awesome gift to bring back to USA. Best chocolate I have tasted.

So much fun!. This was one of my favorite experiences in South America...the chocolate making class was so much fun and my professor (Guillame?) was hilarious! It is a bit pricey but there are women standing around the museum entrance (not the gift shop entrance) with a 10% off voucher so make sure to pick one of those before paying the full price at the gift shop.

Great for families. Our children (10 and 12) loved the 2 hour workshop. But they loved their chocolates even more! Our teacher was really helpful and funny . We really leant lots of facts about the production of chocolate

Chocolate Museum, Free and Fabulous!!!. This museum is educational, fun and most of all very tasty! Lots of free, generous samples!!! The chocolate chef/tour guide was very informative and entertaining! We wished we had the time to take a chocolate cooking class, but had to suffice with purchasing one of their many delicious chocolate liqueurs. D & E Collis
nice little museum/shop. Very helpful and friendly staff - it is a must see just to try the complimentary cocao tea and chocolate treats.
great workshop . the chocolate bean to bar workshop was creative and informative for kids and adults alike. It was great fun. Highly recommend.

Interesting Chocolate Museum!. When exploring Cusco it's hard to find a lack of things to do, however a stop into the Choco Museum for some free choco-tea is very much worth the effort! Delicious chocolate teas, liqueurs, and (shockingly) chocolate line the walls along with an interesting exhibit on how the chocolate beans are harvested and processed. Nice staff, and worth a visit!

Chocolate Lessons are amazing!!. This place is well worth a visit even if you just have time to wander the shop and help yourself to a free hot chocolate sample. I took one of the chocolate making lessons which lasted about 2 hours and was really great fun. I would highly recommend and for 75 soles (approx GBP15) it was great value with the chocolates you made ready to take home an hour later. The chocolate also tastes amazing!!
Nothing exciting. Highly overpriced and closes early 7PM. I felt like we were being rushed to walk through this place and there was nothing there to learn or experience. not impressed
my girl loves chocolate. it was like a dream to visit a place like this...one can consider peruvian chocolates laike being even as good as their swiss counterparts.
Choco Museo. The chocolate making class was really fun! It is a great way to spend a few hours and learn the history of chocolate making in Peru.
Best thing to do at Cusco.. Best chocolate class ever!I like the logistics and information. The chef very professional and well prepared.Worth every penny ;)

Fun to visit and try the chocolate. This isn't a huge place and I bet learning to make chocolate would be fun. There was a class going on while we visited and they looked like they were enjoying themselves. They have nice bright displays explaining how they make chocolate and of course, some products to try. Good place to buy a souvinier to bring home!

Yummy. Friendly staff. Greeted you with cocao tea at the door (one of my faves so I was very happy) amazing selection of chocolates and chocolate products. I brought a jar filled with my choice of chocolates inside. Really good souvenirs

Friendly staff, cafe is a great hang out spot. Came here to learn about chocolate one day and the staff was so friendly and informative. Then came a few days later to just hang out in the cafe. The wifi is great and it's actually one of the cheaper places in town to grab a craft beer and hang out. All beers are 12 soles (and not cusqueña!). Plus they have great coffee and chocolate options. If you need a nice relaxing place to read a book or plan your next adventure, this is it!
Fun at the ChocoMuseo!. Learn how chocolate is made and enjoy chocolate deserts and hot chocolate, from mild to hot. Friendly staff and fun souvenirs.
Chocolat!. You get a nice history lesson about chocolat and on top of this you get to try out some chocolat. It was great fun

Friendly Staff, fun activity!. My husband and I took a bean to bar class with Choco Museo and had lots of fun + chocolat was delicious! I must say I was disappointed we need a machine to really make the bean to bar but I guess I was too hopeful! The museum is free and it's worth it but the classes cost money.

Take the class!!!. The "museum" itself isn't a very big draw. Sign up for the class though...it's so fun! I left my husband behind, but it's great for groups or couples. You'll learn all about cocoa production and make your own delicious chocolates. Instructors are engaging and fun and you'll also meet plenty of fun people. WORTH IT!

Fun and educational.. Me and my travel companions enrolled in the two hour chocolate making class. The museum was quite cool even without the added knowledge and fun of the class. The teacher was fun and full of jokes. All of the members of our group had a great time interacting, chitchatting and making chocolate. Not only did we get to learn about the whole process of chocolate making from tree so bar, but we learned about and tried several tasty chocolate beverages along the way. A few days later we came back and hung out in the cafe. All of the food and beverages were quite tasty, and they even served a selection of tasty craft beers. Definitely a cool place to check out and the class was very well priced for the experience.
I Love Chocolate!!. We did the 2 hour class which was great fun as we were taken through the process from beans to making our own chocolates. Highly recommend.

Good place to learn about chocolate.. The ChocoMuseo was a great place to learn more about chocolate and pick up some goodies. Ive attended a Chocolate tour on a farm in Costa Rica, so in comparison, This location only gives you the most they can offer. But for what it is, its neat to stop by and check out

Beware: this is a chain/scam!. Chocomuseo is not just a cool thing you can experience in Cusco--they also have identical locations all over Latin America. They draw you in because you're a temporary tourist, and you think, "cool, I can learn about the local chocolate-making process!" However, chocolate isn't made locally in/near Cusco at all! They are just taking advantage of your "gringo ignorance" of South America so they can charge you extremely high prices for chocolate novelty items. Not worth it.

Take a chocolate making class!. We were in Cusco for just a couple of days and I'm thrilled we choose to take one of their chocolate making classes- they offer 2 hours ones and 45 minutes ones at incredibly reasonable prices. We did a 45 minute class and were told about the process of making chocolate, the difference between milk, white and dark chocolate, got to taste cocoa beans, and specialize our own. It was a nice break from tours and old buildings, informational and a lot of fun. Plus...it was outright DELICIOUS. They let us finish the chocolate we didn't use in our molds.

Great excursion. We have 3 teenage daughters that love chocolate - was a great two hours of entertainment learning and making chocolate - our host Gilmar was highly entertaining making it all the better - one of the better excursions we have had in Peru and that says a lot - the event fills up daily do boom in advance
chocomadness. the place gets a fullpot just for the amazing smell you're surrounded by during your visit.nice staff, nice samples and great little cafe with a splendid hot chocolate!

Learn how to make Chocolate!. I took a class in chocolate making. It was fun, easy and entertaining. For a low price you get the class and get to keep the chocolate you make. They request you make a reservation 2 days ahead of time, but some people were able to join our class without a reservation. Their website is a little screwy when trying to make the reservation - just pay in advance and they'll message you right back. (Sending in the requested date didn't seem to work.)

Tasty visit. Such a tasty treat! The museum on the second floor has a bar full of chocolate deserts, all looked amazing! We tried the banana strawberry crepe and it was filled with such a rich and natural chocolate flavor! The view of the city was also a nice treat!
Make your own choco!!. Was soooo much fun. Really enthusiastic chef guides you through the choco process. And you have lots of ingredients at the end to make your own. GO EASY ON THE CHILLI!!

Fun spot!. On the lower level is a gift shop, the 2nd floor is a small museum and cafe. We took the Bean to Bar class. Gladys, our instructor, was fun an informative. Taking home the chocolates we made were a fun souvenir.
Fun visit for treats and souvenirs.. Fun way to spend a few hours learning about and sampling chocolate. Great place to buy local chocolates for desserts then and there and to bring home as gifts.
nice to see but not a must. Nice information, it is not a must, but good information and entertainment on a rainy day. It is located in the historic centre.

A fun morning making chocolate! . Went for the 2-hour workshop here which introduced to you the process of making chocolate from bean to mould. Had a fun time roasting cocoa beans, peeling them, grinding them, and eventually customising your own to take home! Excellent place to visit if you're a chocolate lover wanting to learn more about how your chocolate's made. Also great for any families with children - recommended for all ages!

Chocolate making class. What a wonderful way to spend a couple of hours on a wet day in CuscoThe class was very informative with all the background of how and where the cocoa beans come from ..Then preparing them through allthe stages to end up with a delicious tray of custom made chocolates ..It was fun and very interactive I really enjoyed it and learnt a lot ..definitely have s greater appreciation for chocolate now!
Average experience. Small museum that has some chocolate sauces for tasting. They do offer chocolate making classes. Some products to buy. I personally didn't find it worth a visit.
delicious. Went to this cozy place about two times during our stay in Cusco. Both times we has delicous hot chocolte with honey and pepper. Absolutely perfect.

Great Bean to Bar Workshop. I did the two hour Bean to Bar workshop last week and loved it. The teacher was great and everyone in the class seemed to have a lot of fun. Highly recommended for chocolate lovers.
Chocolate and lots of laughs. Love the bean to bar class! Got to eat plenty of chocolate and the instructor is hilarious. A great experience. Will be going back to do the truffle class for sure!

Heaven for chocolate lovers. I made two trips to the Choco Museo. Not having much time in Cusco, I decided not to try a workshop, but a friend and I spent a very happy hour on the balcony drinking hot chocolate and watching life go by. We came back later in the week to do some souvenir shopping. One of the nicest things about this little museum was the lack of hard sell. We didn't feel under any pressure at all to buy anything.

A Yummy Experience!! Highly Recommended. We booked a chocolate making class, it was fantastic!!! It was very hands on and the instructor was so funny and down-to-earth! She also spoke fluent english!It was such an interactive class, we got to try a lot of different chocolate drinks and made our own chocolate which we took home with us. The class room was clean and well maintained. There was also a young girl in our class with her parents (maybe 8 years old?) who was having so much fun, I would recommend this activity for families! The class was a few hours, the time flew by as we were having so much fun! After we had finished we spent some time in the adjoining shop and sampled the Pisco drinks mixed with different flavours - the lady behind the counter was very accommodating! I would recommend this to anyone who has a spare few hours, it was a highlight of our trip!

Great chocolate class. This museum is small but very informational. My friend and I also took a chocolate making class here which was very interactive and fun. You can walk in and sign up. At the end of the class you get to take the chocolate you made home.

Worth the Visit. The Chocolate Museum was a very nice addition to our visit because of the treats you could buy, but I was very disappointed in the lack of organization. I felt that we were overlooked as a group came in and were given full attention.

Nice free visit!. We tried the ChocoMuseo free visit. The staff was speaking english, we had the opportunity to taste very nice choco-liquor, chocolate bar and hot chocolate. We ended the visit buy buying a chocolate cheesecake at the restaurant (SOOOO GOOD) and a chocolate ''bean-to-bar'' chocolate bar. Very nice experience!

Really well presented. Choco Museo presents the history of chocolate-making in Peru in a simple, visual but understandable fashion. Then you get to sample. Yum! Prices seem reasonable. Staff speaks English and seem interested in you. Very pleasant experience.

Take a Class!. My two friends and I did the "Bean to Bar" class and we really enjoyed it. Our instructor was very entertaining and had us laughing a lot. He explained the chocolate making process and then we did some of the steps. We made spicy hot chocolate, sweet cinnamon hot chocolate and then we each made a large tray of chocolates with whatever add-ins we wanted. It was worth the price, especially considering how much chocolate we got to take home.

Well run. Despite being advertised as a museum I agree with others that the exhibits and free tour provided serve as a courtship process towards angling the customer to purchase chocolate or dine at their small cafe - which is fair enough. On entering the museum a English guide introduced herself and took us around - taking around 20 minutes in a tour focusing on the creation of chocolate as well as it's introduction and ongoing production in Peru since the colonial influx. She also introduced us to her products and included a free tasting. I was quite impressed by her English and depth of information and to be honest was waiting for a dollar squeeze. But apart from the expected sales pitch while sampling the chocolate I didn't find her pushy or tip hungry at all which was quite refreshing for this city that loves to charge tourists.I think the real highlight of visiting the chocomuseo are the 2 hour classes in which you created your own chocolate. These cost 75 sol and take place at set times of the day, with a reservation being necessary.This makes an excellent rainy day activity while in Cusco, although I wouldn't classify it as a 'must do'. Give yourself 1 hours for the museum and cafe alone or 2 hours for the cooking class. The cafe served decent but not exceptional chocolate products - although I still suggest on purchasing a item there as a way of payment for the free tours they provide.

chocolate making class. the museum itself is small, but the chocolate making class was super fun and a great activity to kill time and learn something new. you get to make 3 beverages and then chocolates. might drag a little bit for kids, but still fun.

Super Fun-Take a Class. for $25 we spend a delightful 2+ hours learning how to make chocolate. We did everything from the bean to pouring our own hand-dipped bon bons to take with. So much fun and learning!

Two-Hour Bean-to-Bar Class. I had a one-on-one chocolate making tutorial (bean to bar) with Gladys. (Apparently, the Monday 11am class period isn’t that popular, and so I was the only one that showed up.) The class was 75 soles and lasted a little under two hours (but allot another hour on the back-end for your chocolate to chill and for you to come back to pick up!)As you can imagine, you don’t actually go from start to finish with the bean. You go through the motions of roasting the bean, peeling and grinding it, but you fill the actual molds with chocolate that they have already made. The ground bean paste that you actually do make is used to make several cocoa-based drinks instead. Prepare yourself for cheesy activities (such as singing while you are mixing the drink, or saying a toast in Quechua). The quality of the chocolate wasn’t that high, but I thought it was still worth it. Note: I think the Peru Cooking Class chocolate-making class gives you more chocolate for the same price (200g instead of 120g), but I couldn’t make the Peru Cooking Class lesson, as it was only at night (7pm), and I had a plane to catch).

For all Chocolate Lovers!. If you're a chocolate fanatic like me, the workshop is worth your time! While yes, you'll learn some chocolate trivia, the real fun is making and eating the chocolate! The instructor for our chocolate making workshop was fun and energetic. This is such a fun and delicious way to pass away a rainy day!
Small, but nice. Feels more like a shop than a museum. The kids (11 & 8 yrs) enjoyed the tasting and theshopping of chocolates the most.

Fun activity. We visited the Chico Museum in Lima. It was both an interesting and fun experience. We did the from bean to bar session and spent about 2 hours learning about, making and tasting chocolate. It was a really great activity.
Fun-tasty museum. Great to learn about how chocolate is made and to taste cgocolat, chocolate jam & liquor. Puruvian chocolate is delicious!

Brilliant - do the workshop!. Did the chocolate workshop on Christmas Eve with the family as a treat and to stock up ahead of the big day - really nice and interesting experience - lots of fun too. The chocs you make are as good as the flavours you choose - my chilli, coffee bean and salt combo may take a while to catch on.

Interesting and delicious, lots of personal attention. We didn't know what to expect from the Chocomuseo but were encouraged to enter by the woman giving out free chocolate samples outside.We were told to wait in a room to the side and just a moment later we were greeted by our own personal guide, Yilmar. His English was amazing and he was such a jokester. It was a really fun visit, and he made us laugh a lot as he explained the process of making chocolate. You get to taste the cacao beans from the earliest stages, sip on cacao tea, and try chocolate-infused liquors, all for free! I didn't feel pressured in the slightest to make a purchase.The products were so good that we bought as much as we thought we could take on the plane home, and enjoyed a snack in the cafe inside. Their chocolate is good but the cafe had some of the best guacamole we've ever had! I'd highly recommend a visit. It's a great free activity and the employees are genuinely friendly and seem happy to be there.Gracias, Yilmar!!!
Make your own chocolate !. Learned a lot about chocolate production, and took a class in making our own chocolate. Lots of fun !

Learn something new!. We went to this museum, which is located in a little lane-way,as part of our tour. Very educational but we had a little difficulty hearing the lady talk as her voice was not very loud and another group came in and talked over her.

Excellent tour . We had Gilma as our guide he was fantastic, really great English, entertaining and funny.He spent around half a hour with us and and one other couple explaining the whole process.We got to try tea, coco beans, chocolate, hot chocolate and liqueur s. He was very generous on serving sizes. Once the tour was over he thanked us all and shook our hands.There was no tip expected! I was really surprised! He was excellent. We experienced better service from Gilma than on tours you have to pay for! Amazing free tour worth it just make sure you ask for Gilma.

all the lovers of chocolate, unite. I found this place by chance one rainy night when we were downtown....it was completely smelling of fresh chocolate in thousands of recipes...its impossible to reject one sample and you can stay to try more, highly recommendable

Cooking class. We were looking for something different to do in Cusco besides ruins, then we found this place offering a cooking class. We truly enjoyed the class, it begins going to the market to buy the ingredients, then every person has a task with the ingredients and at the end you truly make your meal. We cooked corn soup, lomo saltado, rice and potatoes. Also learned to make pisco and tried different fruits with chocolate as a desert. We pretty much knew all the fruits because in our country we have all of them, but it was good to have in the group tourists from Europe and Australia that didn´t know them.We had a great time and I definitely recommend this activity which begun at the market at 5:45 and ended at almost 9:30 pm. It is not expensive at all because includes all the ingredients, the class and the meal. We spend 120 soles per person.
More of a shop than museum. Although you do get given information here don't be fooled that this is a museum. It is a shop and cafe.

Quick Fun. We stopped in here for about 30 mins. The guide walks you through how chocolate is made and it is very informative. I had no idea how it was done and learned alot. We got lots of samples and they have a small store.

No need to visit more than once... The museum was very little. It probably took 5 minutes to see it all. We got a free (mini)cup of chocolate-tea at our arrival, which pretty much tasted like water with a hint of chocolate. At the cafe we ordered a 'make your own' hot chocolate (liquid chocolate that you mix with hot milk). We heard only nice things about it and had high expectations. Unfortunately, I was pretty disappointed. It's just a regular cup of hot chocolate, nothing more, nothing less. The crepes with chocolate was cold and did not feel freshly made. The shop was great, with a lot of nice products. You can also make your own chocolate at the museum, which is pretty cool.

Interesting and fun . Quite interesting and fun to visit this free museum, located in the Plaza next to the main plaza. Very close. You get to taste different types of chocolate, chocolate tea and learn about the processes. Also has a workshop, cafe and a little store. A store at which you are going to want to buy something.

Delicious and fun!. Free tour! I was the only Spanish speaker in a group of 4, so he had to speak English, but did perfectly well. It was interesting, engaging, and brief but informative. Free chocolate tea sample, and various chocolate liquers to sample at the end! So glad these places exist.

Fun way to pass half an hour . This is a free chocolate 'museum'. It gives an overview of the history of coca, to modern day chocolate and its importance, through a Peruvian lens. The guy overviewing our visit was enjoyable and spoke good English. You can taste some chocolate and have a sup of tea as well, gratis. There is a cafe serving, surprisingly, chocolate based drinks! (And coffee, etc). also a selection of chocolate bars you can buy.

Informative Little Chocolate Shop. We had a hard time finding an employee that could give us a tour in English, but all of the pictures and information on the walls explained the chocolate making process in a concise manner.The most impressive part of the store was their selection of different chocolate products, liqueurs, soaps, etc.They also offer a chocolate making tour where you get to actually go through the process with an employee, but because we visited on a half-day tour, the stop was very brief.Good service, and full of delicious gifts to bring back for family and friends.

Fun and tasty!. My mom, 16 year old brother and I did the bean to bar chocolate workshop. It was fun, the guy (can't remember his name) who led the workshop was very entertaining and fun. We did toast, shell and mash the chocolate, but you don't actually make the chocolate from stratch - that takes 24 hours. They give you melted chocolate to fill in molds with the topping of your choosing (lots to choose from). The chocolate is very tasty!! Also, a little background info about cocoa is provided, which is pretty interesting.
Chocolate good - tour not so much. We bought some chocolate at the store and it was good....but the museum was not very interesting or worthwhile

So much fun making chocolate with Pedro!!. My husband and I did the 2hr Beans to Bar workshop with Pedro and it was so much fun!First of all, Pedro was awesome. His English is excellent and he really cares about chocolate so his knowledge was amazing. We learned so much about the beans, the history, and all the work that goes into the production of chocolate. Pedro was also really funny so we had a great time.During the class, Pedro showcased three iconic drinks using various parts of the cocoa bean. Without spoiling too many details, the Mayan version was my favorite! At the end of the class each person will get to make chocolates using various toppings. The only downside is you have to wait 45min for the chocolate to cool down/solidify before you can take them with you.

Great Tour and Different than the others!. Had a great tasting and tour with Gustavo! Highly recommend this ChocoMuseo. We had visited the one in Cusco, Peru previously but really enjoyed the differences in this one.
Interesting displays of how chocolate is made with cafe. On second floor. Has displays explaining history and how to of chocolate making. Nice café. Good coffee.
Peruvian cooking class. Gladys and Cartia were exceptional. We enjoyed every moment of this class and loved visiting the market beforehand to buy the fresh produce. Great night highly recommended.

Fantastic & Delicious Surprise. Really fantastic small museum in central Cusco. It's a wonderful way to spend 15 minutes to several hours of your stay, depending on what you have available. We explored ChocoMuseo the day after a trek, just before leaving town. We wish we would have known about it earlier -- the Museo offers several classes that looked like a lot of fun. Lots of samples. Helpful staff. Great for rainy days, too. Don't miss it when you visit Cusco.

a chocolate lover's delight. We visited ChocoMuseo three times in our too brief visit to Cusco we liked it so much. We did not get to do the chocolate making workshop but we did pretty much everything else including most of the drinks in the cafe. Try the Mayan hot chocolate and take in the views from the little balconies!

A small and fun place to visit if you have a spare hour in cusco. We enjoyed visiting this place. Although you have to pay quite a bit for the chocolate making classes, it is possible to just visit the small exhibition without participating. After we got a chili hot chocolate from the cafe which I would recommend.

Worth the climb to the 2nd floor!. We enjoyed learning about the full life cycle of cacao! Our guide was friendly, spoke English well, and answered all of our questions. We, of course, came away with a new appreciation for chocolate and a few epicurean delights to bring home. Most interesting is the cacao shell tea. I wish I would've bought more. And, don't forget to tip your guide!

Who doesn't like chocolate?. As walking in Cuzco we discovered this store with great chocolate preparation and even very educative and we could participate in selecting how to prepare a piece ourselves. We enjoyed the kindness of the people serving there, don't miss this place with lovely tastes.
The best for choco lovers. Try the cacao tea, it's magical! Also the Mayan style hot choco. The guides all speak English and the are great presents in the shop.

A fun and informative tour!. I didn't expect too much from the Choco Museo, and I was wrong! It was excellent. Very interesting tour of how chocolate is made. All the staff speak really good English, and of course the chocolate products were excellent! I would strongly recommend going- it's 30 minutes of frivolous tasty fun!

Fun place. Visited both Lima and Cusco location in my travels and both were not disappointing! Make sure to walk around a store in your travels as it is very interesting and a fun place. I ended up buying most of my souvenirs here! My suitcase was full of Chocolate by the time I got home!!Would recommend to anyone! Wish we got a chance to do a class but... next time!

Highly recommend!. The museum is a really interesting cute place, the staff was extremely nice and gave us explanations about the chocolates we tasted. They also make Liqueurs from chocolate and sell them in pretty low prices.The museum is free, but we also took a chocolate class in 75 soles and it was worth every sol.

Very nice place with free samples!. It's very interesting to people that don't know how chocolate is made.Also, you get free samples. The chocolate is delicious. Chocolate tea is pretty nice too.The products are more expensive than usual, but if you really like chocolate it's worth it. I bought a chocolate bar with nuts and it was delicious!!Great chocolate.
The class was so much fun. Our experience was highlighted by the instructor of our class. He was hilarious. My whole family was eating the chocolate on the plane ride home. We had a blast!

Brief visit, but left wanting more!. We stumbled upon the museum by chance, and thought we'd take a look. Some great gift ideas at this time of year, and plenty of products to choose from. You could easily justify buying a lot of chocolate!

Had a blast!. This was a great way to spend 2 hours in Cusco. Not only did I learn about chocolate making, I also had a complete blast. We got to learn how to make two different kinds of chocolate drinks and molded some chocolates with hand selected toppings. Our instructor, Gilmar (correct name?), was hilarious, sweet and very knowledgable. I would recommend this class to any chocolate lovers visiting Cusco with some spare time for a relaxing and fun activity.

Great schtick in chocolate workshop. We enjoyed the antics of our chocolate instructor, who had us speaking Quechua, "guinea pig" and singing to our chocolate as we made some yummy samples to take home. The "museum" part of this operation is quite small, but a cohesive explanation of cocoa and its significance in Peru and around the world. Worth a stop.

Fun for children, lacking information. We participated in the "Bean to Bar" workshop at the museum. Although we had fun, we would not recommend this workshop for adults. The information we received prior to the workshop was misleading, since we hardly did anything ourselves during the workshop nor did we go through the whole process of making chocolate. We hardly received any information about chocolate making, leaving us dissappointed in the end. The only thing we did ourselves was pealing the beans and making paste with them. Afterwards we could taste some drinks, but it wasn't very clear what they were nor why we were tasting them (they mostly tasted like honey). The "chocolate bar" making is nothing more than filling a mold with already melted chocolate. In conclusion, I think this is fun for kids, but don't pay 75 soles for it if you actually want to learn and do something. It's way overpriced for what we did.
Good explanation of cacao production and tasting.. The cacao tea and chili dark or light chocolate are delicious. Worth the stop if you have 15-30 minutes.

Surprisingly good visit. The Chocolate Museum was a surprise great experience. Pedro met us when we walked in and gave us a fun lesson about chocolate and all the free samples we could handle. We sampled everything from the beans to liquors. We didn’t make it to the chocolate making class, and the majority of the “museum” is just a chocolate shop. Everyone from our group ended up buying something here, its a great place to get souvenirs and gifts to bring home.
Meh.. Small place and the staff weren't really that interested in my presence... I did manage to buy some chocolate, but i had to ask twice...

Fun chocolate making class. Busy little place that includes a cute cafe and shop. Total of 12 in the class with a gregarious teacher switching between Spanish and English. Very enjoyable and informative, not to mention fun. We we surprised that making chocolate includes dancing and singing! Apparently it improves the flavour :)Only downside, it was hard to hear the teacher as the class was open to the other rooms. Also people kept wandering through, sometimes interrupting! A couple of doors to close would fix all that any make it a much more enjoyable experience.

We took a really fun cooking class here.. My friend and I visited in August 2012. We took a cooking class, small group of 4. We started out at the local market to get ingredients. Our instructor let us sample some local fruit we hadn't tried before. We made Lomo Saltado, a creamed corn soup, and had chocolate fondue with fruit for dessert. It was all amazing! Great class, a lot of fun. The chocolate here was delicious!

Free Entry. Definitly worth a visit to see how the cacao grows and how they make chocolate you can taste lots of chocolate and liqors and if you wanna spend a bit of money definitly try the chocolate Fondue

Neat place for people who love chocolate . I love chocolate so I probably spent a bit too much time here. Lol. The museum is small but offers great information on the history of chocolate and the coco bean as well as the steps to harvest and produce the treat as we know it today. There is a tasting bar for liqueur and jams. They also offer free tastings of different chocolates and of their chocolate tea. Different classes are offered throughout the day. I took the "from bean to bar" class. Two hours, but it went by quickly. The class was highly entertaining and informative and in addition to trying different types of chocolate beverages (tea, Mayan, conquistador) and learning how they are made, you get to make your own chocolate pieces that you can pick up later after they set in the mold. You get a discount in the store after you finish the class and there are all kinds of different chocolate novelties. There is also a cafe that has offers delicious treats.

So much fun!. Making your own chocolate, and eating it, what more could one want? In addition to making the chocolates, visitors also get to learn about the history and process of chocolate making, and how it has influenced Peruvian history. If you have a few hours to divert from historical sites in Cuzco, I highly recommend it!

Informative choco break. The museum, workshop and bar are nicely intertwined creating a nice atmosphere. The mini tour is fun and tasty. Afterwards with a bit of luck you can grab a barstool overlooking the nice plaza enjoying your chocolate delight.Prices are not the lowest but its filled with people on a Sunday afternoon in the low season so they are not likely to go down soon. Recommended!
Free and fun. Totally free, with free tasting, you will learn everything about cacao. They also provide (paying) workshop to brew your own chocolate. lovely place
Interesting but expensive. Interesting information if you want to know more about cacao. They sell all kinds of cacao products (love the chocolate with salt !), but it is rather expensive.
If chocolate is your thing, you can't miss this.. The name of the place speaks for itself. Chocolate of all kinds are there for the inner chocoholic in all of us.

Learn about and make Chocolate. Great learning experience, we joined in with a chocolate making class. From beans to eating great fun, lots of laughs and ended up with some great chocolate. And some strange flavours.

Nice attraction for a rainy day. This place is more like a shop and a coffee (and chocolate) place to make you purchase something or to take some chocolate cooking lessons, so the ´free museum´ name is not quite correct.However, it is free and they do show a little about the chocolate making process.They also offer some free samples so you can taste.I do recommend to have a short visit if you´ve got some free time.

Bean to the Bar was great!. My wife and I were travelling on our honeymoon, I booked the workshop are the chocomuseo because we read good reviews and were interested to find a bit out about the chocolate process and where better to do it than in Peru.The guy that took our class was entertaining and turned it into a bit of a show. We had a good laugh and found out some really interesting things about chocolate. For one, I now know how bean gets to the bar. We made various types of hot chocolate, chocolate tea and finally our own chocolate which we could take away.Would recommend to friends, it was a great way to spend 2-3 hours

Fun times making chocolate!. This is a great experience. I took the two-hour Beans to Bar class. You get to drink hot chocolate made from the chocolate you make from the beans, Two different kinds, and the presenter will tell you about them. It takes 24 hours to make the chocolate and sugar combine properly, so the chocolate you take home from the class is not the actual beans your worked with. But that's ok. It's still very informative and fun and I'm glad I did it. Please note: I took this class in Cusco but I think I did a review for the Ollantaytambo store and I don't know how to recall it.

Chocolate heaven. We went to the ChocoMuseo based on a recommendation from our tour company. All we did was look around and observe the exhibits but we saw other groups making chocolate bars from scratch. A cool little joint if you have 30 minutes - 1 hour to burn during your time in Cusco. Plus they give you free tea!

Interesting History and chocolate sampling. It's definitely not a museum. There's two small upper level exhibits and a front entrance way area with chocolate information, but it primarily is a shop. Luckily, they do give out free samples of their chocolate so you can taste the difference and they give out samples of their liquor and spreads too. The chocolate is rather pricey here.

From Bean to Bar! Make your own chocolate!. This is an AWESOME 2 hour activity! (plan for 3 hours as you need to pick your chocolate up 1 hour after the class)I was so pleasantly surprised at how much fun I had here. I would certainly recommend the chocolate making classes!

Nice history lesson in self guided tour. Enjoyed the free self guided tour here and the samples as well. Some nice displays explaining this history of chocolate, as well as the processing of it to a fabulous food source (chocolate really should be a food group in my opinion).They had some chocolate samples as well as samples of the liquors, all of which were mmmmm good. The chocolate making sessions looked interesting but we did not partake due to time constraints. The banana chocolate liqueur was especially good and I will enjoy that on some vanilla ice cream at a later date.

Visited the museum today. We just took a tour of the museum with Gylmar, who was an excellent guide. We learned a lot and after tasting samples of several chocolate jams, could not resist buying some to take home.

Take the Chocolate Making class, it's AWESOME. . A friend and I travelling had an afternoon to kill in Cusco, so we checked out the 130pm chocolate making class this past Tuesday. We didnt book ahead, but showed up in the morning to see Availability. We were able to get in no problem. Our presenter, Yarmin (I lost the card with his name spelled correctly) was phenomenal, very fun, smart and entertaining. This class is educational, while being relaxed so there isn't a "lecture feel" to it. We got to learn about cocoa nibs, the chocolate making process, and got to make 2 chocolate drinks with beans we rosted and crushed ourselves. It really embodied experiential learning! We loved the class, and it made our day. To top it off, we got to take chocolate home and got a discount at the store.Take this class, even if you get the initial impression that it's hokey. You won't regret it.

Surprisingly Good Fun. Hit the Choco Museo after a tip off from a fellow traveller and actually it's really good. We did a whistle stop 40 minute workshop where you learn a bit about the history of chocolate (more interesting than you might think) and then make some chocolates. There's also an option of a 2 hour class.You can fill your chocolates with any number of fillings including 'Inca Viagra' which my girlfriend inexplicably and horribly announced she was going to give to her Mum. After I swallowed the sick in my mouth I found time to try the vast array of chocolate based liquors they have available, some good, some bad, but it's a fun and boozy lottery.Great way to spend an hour or two.

Spend some time in good company and eat pure choc. I got here looking for hot chocolate in a rainy evening, ended up staying a few hours while oscar was talking me and a group of Brazilian ladies through the history of chocolate, delighting is with chocolate tasting and choco-pisco chupitos

SO MUCH CHOCOLATE. Perú offers a small percentage of global chocolate production. But, what they make, they make with style. Try all of the different chocolate preserves and chocolate liqueurs. Great value as the tours are free! Which is great, because their chocolate is very not free.
Had a great tour!. Delicious chocolates and some nice gifts to bring back home! I recommend a stop here to learn about chocolate in Peru.

Only do the class if you have time. We went to the Choco Museo in both Ollantaytambo and Cusco. In Olltantayambo, we just ordered chocolate, but in Cusco we also did the chocolate making class. It was a fun novelty, but it no way a must do. We had individuals speaking three languages, Spanish, English and French, and our teacher spoke in all three languages. Very Impressive!! But it also made the class extremely drawn out. By the time we got to making the chocolates, everyone was losing interest and was bored. The highlight was the French family with three young children- watching the girls be so excited about the chocolate made the class.

Go to Gato's Market instead if it's closer :). Yes, they have chocolate. However, I felt that it was over-rated in so far as I expected more. The chocolate is delicous, for sure, but I'd just as much rather have picked up chocolate from Gato's Market on Calle Ruinas.

ISH. We usually buy 70% dark and this is not quality! It's been a month and we still have half a bar around. Read the info on the walls with photos. Buy if you must. We found it gross and were told by others that there are much better chocolate places.

Great "bean to bar" chocolate workshop. The place is really nice to visit if you are a choco-holic. One could feel that it's slightly expensive but quality has a price and the Choco Museo definitely works with the best cacao and chocolate in Peru. The "bean to bar" chocolate workshop – a two hours class – is one you shouldn't miss if you are interested in learning the basics of chocolate making. It's a delightful and captivating experience that I will remember for years. Our teacher, Pedro, was such a colourful character.
Samples!. Not the most detailed museum but definitely worth trying out some samples and purchasing the cocoa tea! Worth going but a bit pricey for the chocolate itself.

Make sure you do the class!!. The museum is pretty cool, but the class made it all worth it! We were lucky enough to get our own private class. The class went way more in depth than I thought it was going to. We actually got to roast and mash up the cocoa beans and they showed us every step of the process! We got to try three different drinks made with the cocoa that we had ground up - which were all delicious! We then got to make our own chocolates which ended up being about 6-8 good sized chocolates. It was definitely worth the money and one of my favorite experiences while I was there!

So much fun!. We had so much fun at the Choco Museo! The Workshop is a definite must. We did the workshop in which you start all the way from the coco bean. We had a blast, it was a perfect sized group, and the timing was perfect. Gladys was our teacher and she was amazing! She went around and took everyone's picture with their own cameras throughout the whole process. There was even a contest :) Our trip to Cusco would not have been complete without this visit!

Ok museum, wish we'd done a class!. We had a nice tour of the museum and learnt about the chocolate making process. Our guide (Oscar I think??) was friendly and served us teas and samples of their products. The cafe was yum, very rich food though, think I overdid the chocolate! Unfortunately we didn't do a class as were near the end of our holiday and were too tired. Next time I'd love to do one, they looked fun.

Excellent Treat!. We enjoyed hot chocolates and brownies from the cafe section while people/dog watching from the cafe balcony. After our trek we booked a chocolate making and cooking class. Each were loads of fun and the instructors were very nice.

Great way to spend a view hours!. We completed the chocolate making session one evening and thoroughly enjoyed the experience! The host was full of energy and explained the chocolate making process in an interesting and fun way. Tastings chocolate throughout and even get to make your own chocolates with different additions to take home. Very highly recommended!!
yum!. We bought a ton of chocolate from this place, and thoroughly enjoyed the hot chocolate (we got three different kinds and they were all great).

Free to Visit but come for a workshop. The museum itself is small, kind of neat but takes about 5 minutes. The real draw is chocolate making workshops and tastings. If there's a chocolate lover in your life, sign up for a workshop.

OKay.... ...but nothing to write home about. The 'tour' was fast and scripted. It's basically offered so you will purchase the products. I was annoyed that they didn't honor my coupon. They said they things I bought were already on sale. Yet they honored my sister's coupon. Hmmmm

The best hot chocolate!. We stumbled across this place by accident and did the abbreviated tour, so I can't comment on the chocolate classes. The highlight was the little cafe and the amazing hot chocolate drinks they make. So good in fact that we went back 3 times!

Some interesting facts, displays and souvenirs. This place is worth having a look at! I did a free walking tour througg Loki hostels and the guide took us here. I learnt a lot! The souvenirs are a little pricey as to be expected but good to taste.

Enjoyable and informative free museum. If you have an hour to spare, this place just off the main square in Cusco is well worth a visit. You learn about chocolate production around the world and get to taste all sorts of chocolate and chocolate based products - and it's free !

Great Fun. Our party of 2 couples booked the 'bean to bar' chocolate workshop. It was 2 hours of fun! The lady who taught us was great (even though she wasn't feeling too well the day we went). We were told about how the cacao beans grow, then the fun began. We tasted the raw dried beans, then roasted and shelled them. Next we ground the beans to form a stiff paste. The lady used this to make 2 types of chocolate drink for us all to try. This involved some singing which I would normally avoid, but we were having so much fun I didn't mind joining in. As the next process, the blending, takes 24 hours we were provided with some ready made chocolate to put in moulds with our own choice of additions. The chocolates were then put into the fridge and we could collect them 1 hour later. We also had a cake and hot chocolate drink in the small cafe area. It was the best hot chocolate ever. All in all a great couple of hours. You do need to book though - we called in the day before.

Amazing chocolate products. The museum itself is nothing of special although I did learn some interesting facts. You may try different samples of chocolate. The cafe serves a delicious hot chocolate, and they have soya milk! There is a lovely balcony with a great view! I also bought vegan cookies and bars that were delicious.

Great Stop on Cusco Walking Tour. We toured Cusco for the day and ChocMuseo was one of our stops in the city. It was a great little break for us. We received free tastings of various liqueurs, tea, and chocolate. This was a great place to purchase souvenirs. Loved the chocolate replica of Machu Picchu!

Fun and entertaining!. I did a chocolate cooking class at the chocomueso in Cusco, Peru. I had an amazing time, it was so much fun!! The host was funny and interactive, we got to try lots of different forms of chocolate and learnt lots about it along the way. We also got to take home the chocolates we made, which tasted amazing. Would definitely recommend!

Fun and delicious!. Friendly staff and delicious chocolate sampling!Good for learnings - history of chocolate and cacao and how it's made. Free admission! Tastings include : cacao tea, fondue, iced chocolate.we bought some chocolate strawberry/banana spead and also a chocolate mango liquour. sooo good!

Take a chocolate making class!. Sign up for a chocolate making class. You do everything from roasting and taking the shell of the beans to grinding them up and then trying a few yummy chocolate drinks. Then you get to make your own chocolate pieces and put different flavors in it. So much fun.

A MUST IN CUSCO. I went there alone before my wife arrived. A very nice young woman gave an informative (free) tour of the museum. Then it was coffee - fantastic, never had better anywhere and the waitresses, 2 delightful young women from Argentina, were great. Not only is the coffee superb but the brownies are to die for as are the omelettes. Delighted my wife agreed. An oasis in the centre of Cusco.

Fun and interesting . It's definitely a place to buy chocolate, and good chocolate at that, but they also provide a lot of interesting information about the history and production of chocolate. They also let you sample chocolate tea, chocolates from different Peruvian regions and chocolate spreads. It's a bit more expensive but also higher quality. Good for an hour or two. And they also sell drinks and some food. Worth a trip.

Very informative and fun. It was a really informative and fun museum which shows both: history and production of chocolate. Afterwards you can also taste some of the products that they sell like chocolate tea which is really good

Great thing to do in Cusco for FREE!. Lovely welcoming staff. Not only the entrance is free, but also a mini guided tour with chocolate tasting! Really good information boards to find out about the process of making chocolate and the history of chocolate. Plus it has a cafe if you want more! There is a shop on the street, but the actual museum is round the corner on the first floor.

Free to visit & taste, great workshops . The staff are very friendly & helpful, and you can taste different chocolates and beverages... Take the chocolate making class to make your own chocolate for 75 sol. Really worth it.
A great experience. The workshop was interesting, tasty and Pedro was great - funny and helpful. I would recommend it if you have time in Cuzco.

Free and VERY cool!. AWESOME! free to walk through and taste the chocolate and tea with guides explaining everything. The gifts inside are very unique and well priced. Very cool - quick and fun way to spend part of your day! Close to plaza de Armas too!

Great way to spend the morning. Lots of information about chocolate and its evolution from the Mayan times to today. My wife and I took the class and it was incredible! We got to experience every stage of the chocolate making process, and left with our own self made chocolates, seasoned with our choices of coffee, chili, nuts, salt, and other items. The people were amazingly friendly, and the cocao tea they gave us was great! Also, if you take a class you save 10% on anything you buy in the store. Lots of yummy treats! And if you don't want the class, their café has amazing options for a quick snack. If you are in Peru, it is worth going to this place, or its other sites in Lima or Olantaytambo.

Fun, Friendly Staff and Great Cuzco activity. This was a great activity to do while adjusting to altitude in Cuzco. A group of 4 women in my family went and learned how to make chocolate from cocoa beans. Gladis was an excellent teacher with a great sense of humor. This class attracted an international crowd which made it fun as well. You wouldn't believe all the things they make out of chocolate there! We also got to taste 3 different kinds of drinks made from the cocoa paste we made. One warning: you are standing on your feet for about 2.5 hours so wear comfortable shoes. I highly recommend this fun and knowledgeable staff as a way to learn about a local industry.

A Great Place to Visit. Of course you want to do more than just visit this fabulous location. You need to experience the knowledge imparted by the staff and sample some of their fine chocolate. We didn't leave without some chocolates to take with us for later in the day for a snack.

Chocolate making workshop. As a true addict--I mean connoisseur--of chocolate I was sure to swing by the chocolate museum and book a workshop for my group, they easily fit us in the same day and had several workshop windows available. The workshop starts with a brief explanation of chocolate agriculture and a tour of the (one room) museum (it's a much better confectionary and gift shop) and then you get to sample all the steps in the chocolate making process and your group selects, roasts, peels, friends, and mixes beans into three types of delicious hot chocolate. Then you chose molds and ingredients and set to work making your own chocolate bars. The staff was fun and engaging, if perhaps a little too tacky for some of our tastes; but at the end of the day you pick up your own chocolate bars, which were delicious! Overall the workshop was amusing but not amazing, and I'd recommend it if you have time around Cusco and love chocolate and audience participation.
Choco museum. Nice if you need to fill up some time. We tryed cocoa beans, chocolate jelly and liquors plus different kind of chocolate. Though the chocolate seemed expensive.
More "Gift Shop" than "Museum", but hey, CHOCOLATE!. Fun! It's not much more than a glorified gift shop but that's ok! Excellent chocolate and lots of tastings.
Beautiful Experience - Chocolate Class. The two different chocolate making classes are what make the Chocomuseo great. If you just go for the museum, it's ok. Take the classes and it's amazing!

Great Staff, Fantastic Experience!. To be honest, there is not much I love more in this world than chocolate... So without going into too much detail I will simply say that the workshop is fantastic. The staff are hilarious, and I was captivated and included for the full 2hrs. You get to do a little of every step from bean to chocolate which is super, and at the end you can have a bundle of chocolates of different flavours which you pour yourself :) There are up to 12 people per workshop, ours had a family who also seemed to enjoy it :)
Average. If you have time, it's interesting to know the process of chocolate making, but the quality of their chocolate is not the best.

Only visit if you have time to kill. I happened to have 15-20 minutes before meeting my tour group and I only popped in here to see what all the raving was about. Plus the overview is free, but the chocolate making session was expensive at 75 soles.The "tour" was tiny with a 5 minute explanation of where chocolate comes from and then a mini tasting session, with huge lines and barely enough space to stand.The chocolate tastes great, but not worth the cost, especially when you just buy equally good chocolate at the Lima airport duty free or even at the Metro supermarkets in Lima. If you have done chocolate tours in Canada or Europe, this is really a miniscule place, so don't expect much.
Awesome chocolate class!. Had a chocolate class with 2 friends there, and it was awesome! We learnt a lot, the chef was very nice and it was a great experience! Would do it again.
Need a chocolate fix. Interesting and delicious! Lots of samples available... even the chocolate liqueurs! Great for the chocolate lovers fix ... or for just a nice cup of hot chocolate.

History of Cacao in 30 minutes. It's a nice, small museum with the history and fabrication methods of cacao. There is also a store to buy some chocolates and local products. It's interesting, but could be better. There's also chocolate making classes, for the ones with cooking spirits!

Unique Hot Chocolate Varieties. My husband and I enjoyed this place so much, we drank hot chocolate there multiple times while in Lima, Cuzco, and Ollantaytambo. However, we liked the Cuzco location best. It's located just off the Plaza de Armas and offers seating on a second floor balcony that allows you to overlook the square. Their menu is broad, and you can order multiple kinds of hot chocolate. My husband ordered a "Mayan Hot Coco," and he was brought melted chocolate, steamed milk, honey, and Cayenne pepper. To an empty mug, he added these various ingredients to taste...very unique! They offered several such options.If you need something to do, spend some time here and have a delicious drink while you watch the world go by!
Interesting Museum. I did the 2 hour chocolate making workshop to kill time. It was more interesting than I expected. The cafe is also delicious.
Oscars birthday. Had a lovely time celebrating oscars birthday with many samples of chocolate piscos. Yilmar didnt get stuck in the bathroom this time. Happy birthday linguinne. Good receptionist!!!

A tasty musuem. A very fun experience, we did the 2 hour chocolate process just to kill time, but were pleasantly surprised. The host was fun and funny, we got to try chocolate in all kinds of forms, and enjoyed the whole experience.

One of highlights in cusco for kids. After 4 days of hiking, sight seeing and museums, our kids were excited to go to see how chocolate is made - hearing rave reviews from our tour guide, we were not disappointed. It was a great time, an experience our kids will remember. The staff does an amazing job of bringing together the guests on each tour into one team - we felt like we were on Master Chef Jr! A lot of fun.
Who doesn't love chocolate?. Who doesn't love chocolate? The workshops are professional and well organized. Lots of added value and you can take the products you make home afterwards.

Cute Shop, Very Touristy. The chocolate class was fun, but it's not really a "chocolate making" class. It's more of melting and pouring into molds. But you learn a lot about how chocolate is made, and get to eat some too.

Everything Chocolate. We had lots of fun making our own chocolate in heaps of different flaours. It was very informative and we learnt the full process from plant to bar. It has a little shop with different chocolate products.

A must for chocolate lovers!. After checking out the main attractions around Cusco, we decided to check out the chocolate museum after reading the positive reviews. They have a small museum with the history of chocolate and the option to take 2 glasses - "bean to bar" and "truffle making". We did the bean to bar class and we very happy with our decision. The class took two hours and we went through each step of chocolate making beginning with the bean. I had already toured a chocolate farm before, but I learned many new things. We got to taste the chocolate along the way with each step. We then got to make our own chocolate treats to take home with us. Pedro was a great instructor. We also enjoyed getting to know other travelers from around the world. If you have a couple extra hours in Cusco I would definitely recommend this!

Fun afternoon. A great find, we went in for a wander and ended up having lunch overlooking the square below and staying for the chocolate workshop.Great fun and only 5 in our group but some are much larger.Gladys was really patient and helpful and we thoroughly enjoyed our time here

A little bit touristy and slightly pricey.. We didn't realize until later that the ChocoMuseo is a chain. You can find more locations in Lima as well. The prices are relatively high but the chocolate varieties vary greatly. I wish that we had had more time to take once of the chocolate making classes.

Good to have a snack and take a load off, but not sure this qualifies as an attraction. If you have time to kill and want to relax for a bit, then the brief 10 minute explanation on where chocolate comes from and chocolate making class is a nice diversion. But, Cusco has so much more to offer than this. You can find shops like this in just about any city.That said, my tween ager loved it, so good for the kids.

Family enjoyed the samples & cocoa information. Our family really enjoyed this museum/store. It would have been fun to participate in a chocolate making workshop if we had more time. Loved the chocolate we purchased in the store.

Fun and interesting . We explored the (free!) informational museum, enjoyed some chocolate tea over looking the square. Everyone we encountered was friendly and helpful. We didn't have a chance to do a class, however the classes were full and people seemed to be enjoying themselves. It's worth a stop in!

a unexpected place to enjoy .. i heard bad recomendations about this place. but when i went it was how to be in an amazing fairy tail. the smell is realy romantic and the hosts are realy friendly. i take the class. from the bean to the bar with some friends and it was fantastic we learned how to roast the beans and the history of cacao. thanks iban for the class. he is the teacher and his class is entertaining and interesting. a beautifull and racomendable shop . remenber its not a tradicional museum.

Great concept, do the workshop!. Choco museo is basically a shop turned museum. I accidentally walked by and on entrance was welcomed with an interesting tour, tasting of different chocolates and the fantastic cacao shell tea. The tour is about the cacao plant and the Peruvian chocolate production. Not all guides are as knowledgable and well spoken but the explanations upstairs can give you additional information. There's a beautiful hand drawn infographic of the chocolate making process and on the other side upstairs a comprehensive display of the history. The chocolate making workshop from Pedro was one of the best things I did in Cusco city. We got to make chocolate from scratch, roasting and grinding the beans and then choosing from a wide variety of extras to put in our chocolates. After two hours there ready to pick up and they were super tasty! Pedro knows a lot about the history of cacao and of Peru in general and is a great speaker with cheeky humor. The only thing they might need to improve is the graphic design of the chocolate bars to match their delicious and high quality taste. :X but that might just be a personal preference.

One of the best things you can do in Cusco. Loads of info about the history of chocolate, the growing and production process, with a taste of their delicious chocolate after. Friendly and really helpful staff. Free tour but you end up buying chocolate or something there because it's such a good place. Definitely go.
Chocolate Making Class. A couple that we met on the train to Macchu Picchu had recommended this experience to us. We were so happy that we followed their lead!

Expensive but delicious chocolate!. We found it far to expensive to do the tours or classes but we wandered around and took advantage of the free chocolate pisco tasting. There is someone who walks around and offers samples. Nice place

Sweets and more sweets. It was an interesting experience, a lot of sweets and nice souvenirs. However, my kids (10-14) wanted to take a workshop "from bean to chocolate" and we felt they didn't want to include them (too many questions and excuses) . At the end, we desisted
Everything is about chocolates . Great informative place about chocolates. There you will find many kind of chocolates which you can buy and also they teach you how to make your own chocolate.

So yummy and fun!. SO MUCH FUN! If you are interested in it, buy it here! I am so very disappointed that I didn't purchase the cacao tea. I thought I would be able to get it in the USA, but I haven't been able to find it! Take a chocolate making class as well! It was a lot of fun!

Interesting and tasty!. Interesting place, especially the historic overview where one gets to know the changing roles of chocolate from the Maya, via the Aztez and Inca to Europe - the value this commodity once had, compared to today´s mass consumption. Also plenty of opportunities to buy a great variety of chocolate and attend workshops. And museum is free!
Great Experience. One of our favorite places in Cusco. Bought most of my souvineers from there! Schedule a chocolate making class a day in advance. Its well worth it.Blake

Make your own chocolate . I did the chocolate workshop and absolutely loved it! Even though I had already visited chocolate museums and cocoa plantations I still have learned new things and especially the funny instructor Pedro made the workshop a special event for me! I also love the chocolate I've made for myself :)

Informative. Spent one hour in the museum. Information is on several language, and there is personell to tell you about the chocolate prosess. Nice that they have tasting saples of different chocholate and drinks with chocholate. Worth to visit.

Not a museum. This is a store and chocolate classes school with a few displays on the history and processing of cocoa. They have a cafe and store that only sells their own chocolate products. Unless you want to take a class, a waste of time.
Chocolate classes. Outstanding more than 2 hour session on the history of cocoa and its evolution in Peru. Great for Kids and adults and especially for families. Pedro was great.
A delicious cup of hot cocoa!!!. We went to the store, not the museum. Free sample bits of chocolate, tasters of chocolate liqueurs, and the best cup of hot cocoa around!!! It's well worth a visit!

Coffe and Cocoa 2Day Tour..!!. We booked with no little challenges the Forastero Tour, a 2day tour of a coffee and cocoa plantation, involving the whole process from plant to final product, a number of educational and fun experiences and the chance of living at a small coffee farm for a day and a night... Needless to say that the experience was memorable. Interesting, fun, educational and having the coffee you saw making from the fresh bean or the chocolate you pick up as a bean from the tree is just priceless. Ask for Abel or Oscar at the Cusco shop for info as the only problem we had was that other staff seem to know very little about these amazing excursions...

Enjoyable, Short Stop. We were on our way to the Regional History Museum in Cusco when we stumbled upon the Choco Museo. It was a great coincidence that was worth our time.The Choco Museo has a gift shop on the first floor and around the corner on the second floor is the actual museum. The museum isn’t very big but it is interesting and is worth a glance. There is also another gift shop in the museum itself.When you first get there someone greets you and gives you a mini tour of the museum as they teach you a thing or two about chocolate. At the end of the tour you are free to taste as many things as you want that they have available (chocolate bars, chocolate jams, and chocolate liquers). I enjoyed most of the things that I tried. My favorites were probably the Brazilnut jam and the banana jam. Those ended up making their way home with me. Don’t be afraid to ask for samples, they will let you taste anything and the staff were incredibly friendly when we were there.The Choco Museo is not large but it is worth a stop, at least to grab some gifts for people back at home. You should not need more than an hour there.

SO much fun!. We visited the museum, its not very big but the given explanations were very interesting. We then ate and drank some of the hot chocolate prepared which was amazing. Super tasty! We decided to come back the same evening to make our own chocolate (they have workshops)! It was a very fun experience where we learned a lot about mayans, chocolate ingredients and all. The staff was easy going and fun! Very cool place!

Bean to Bar Class. We did the Bean to Bar class and had a good time. We lucked out with a good instructor and fun group of other participants. We learned a bit about the history of chocolate. We also got to roast some cocoa beans, try three different types of drinks (cacao tea, mayan hot chocolate, and european hot chocolate), and make our own chocolates. It was a nice way to spend a couple of hours. We had to wait about an hour for our chocolates to harden in the fridge before taking them "home" with us so we hung out in their cafe and had a snack (sandwich, brownie, and coffee).

Great place to buy Peruvian Chocolate!. I visited the museum store, not the museum itself. But it's a great destination in and of itself! Great selection of Peruvian chocolate sourced from different parts of the country. Each area has it's own unique flavor and you can sample some of them. They also make a delicious cup of hot chocolate here. It's worth the calorie splurge!

Wonderful!!. Our host was hilarious and animated, a little too much sometimes but thats the fun. I was so interested in the old Mayan, Inca and local cocoa drinks we made with paprika and honey. Grinding and making our own chocolates to take home was a winner!

fun & educational. its fun & free. Of course they push their cafe & chocolate, but you dont have to buy anything...and the 'making chocolate' experience looked like fun too. Informative 20 min for something you know you've eaten a lot of.
Not as good as the Ollantaytambo museum which is free. Not as much choice in chocolates, and they are expensive. No chocolate croissants. Charge for admission.

Fun and educational workshop. We did chocolate making workshop with my kids and had fantastic experience. We learned a ton about chocolate making process and our guide Pedro was a lot of fun. Highly recommend.
Cute, interesting little place. Cute little museum that does an excellent introduction to the process of making chocolate, a few tastings and then they leave you to shop!

Informative with free samples!. Clean, informative store with pricey chocolate but reasonably priced chocolate making class and clean western style bathrooms. Go for the samples, stay for the bathroom :)

A place to check out if you have extra time. We got a lousy guide, after the first introduction he sent us upstairs to read about history of the chocolate, promised to bring the samples, and totally neglected us. The have a café inside, and my husband ordered Mayan hot chocolate. All the ingredients were served separately (hot chocolate, hot milk, hot chili pepper, and honey), so you can mix it yourself to your liking. We set at the small balcony with the lovely view enjoying the scenery and rich taste (5* for both hot chocolate and the view). We never finished the tasting part of the tour, but I saw others enjoying it.

Love Chocolate. If you love chocolate, you will love the Choco Museo. We spent most of our time in the shop tasting the different chocolate lacquers. I left with a chocolate banana alcohol but the choices seemed endless. The museum part was nice but the shop is the can't miss part.
Little but worth the visit. We just left there, and yummmmmy. They have all different chocolates, made fresh in the cafe/store. Free samples, nice employees, great place for gift purchase.

Interesting store - Great Cocoa Tea. We didn't go to the museum portion, as I thought there was a fee. if there wasn't a fee, I wish we would have gone for a quick look. They have come chocolate and cocoa tea to sample in the store. Lots of cocoa type items to buy. This place is somewhat out of the way, and difficult to find. Worth a quick visit, if you are in the area.

Wonderful Staff and Chocolate - what more can one ask for?. We were very warmly received by the staff at the choco museo on our recent visit. Mirasol, our guide was very pleasant and enthusiastic. She gave us a very warm welcome with a cup of Choco tea followed by excellent explanation of how chocolate is made and who consumes the most...not surprisingly, the UK is right up there, the second biggest consumer on a per capita basis! Don't miss the chance to go to the choco museo if you are in Miraflores. It's a great place to visit and you will leave with some very tasty Peruvian chocolates!

Delicious Museum. About 6 of us visited this Museum together. We had booked a chocolate making workshop that lasted about 45 minutes. During that time, we each made our own batch of chocolates, mixing in any of a tremendous variety of delicious ingredients. They turned out very well and we all left with our souvenirs to sample later. It was enjoyable and informative.

Loved the museum and samples. The Choco Museo is in Cusco, Lima, and Ollantaytambo (may be more but I'm not sure), and they are all great! The one in Cusco is just one block away from the Plaza de Armas, making it a great stop on a day that you're visiting the area. It's a little hard to find - you can see the Museo shop from the plaza in front of it, but the museum itself is on the second floor. To find it, you need to go to the left if you're looking at the museum and then take the stairs - you should see it then. The museum is free. It's quite small, divided into 2 rooms, but is thorough - it talks about the history and manufacturing process of chocolate in Spanish, English, and French (good translations). In the center, you can taste different kinds of chocolate, chocolate jams, and chocolate tea. There is a little restaurant if you want to buy treats. They also have chocolate-making classes, but they are rather expensive (~75 soles), but you can still have a great experience just walking around the museum and shop!

Lots of free tasting opportunities. The staff were exceptionally friendly and we could taste as many chocolate treats as we liked. We would have made a purchase but we were trekking and in the middle of our trip so unfortunately we did not bring anything back to the states. The historical display explained the entire process of making chocolate. They even had samples of coco before it was processed. Everyone was given coco tea and I had seconds. Well worth the visit before we had our dinner. All for free.

Excellent & Fun Chocolate Education. Went with friends for the chocolate making experience. Learned quite a bit about the process while having a very enjoyable time. Definitely recommended! Cost per person for class was 75 Soles. They also have a gift shop and cafe. NOTE: I arrived before my friends and found the address OK, but it opens into a courtyard with a small, abandoned shop on the far side with the ChocoMuseo sign on it. That's not it .... you need to go upstairs. Would be a good thing for the business to remove the old downstairs shop sign and direct client to the second floor.

Fun quick stop in Cusco. We stopped in to check out the Choco Museo and enjoyed our brief tour and history of chocolate in Peru. The museum is free and full of samples and information. It's not large and it is easy to see the whole thing in under 20 minutes. We also stopped by the cafe and enjoyed some coffee and chocolate treats. If you have time to spare in Cusco this is definitely worth a stop.
Go once for the taste. Friendly staff gave us a nice 20 minute tour with Family. Fun watching the Cocoa Kitchen in action. Bought some Cocoa Nib Tea....fantastic!

Attention All Chocoholics..... What a great way to spend an afternoon in Cusco, Peru with Friends!! Take a Chocolate Course together. Learn about the Cocao Bean- Process your own Chocolate - mix delicious Chocolate drinks - AND - finally create your own delicious Chocolate Molded Treats!!!!!Our teacher Rony was Fun, Knowledgeable and made the experience Memorable for all of us.I would highly recommend this course to anyone visiting Cusco.

Lots of fun! Great evening activity before dinner.. This experience was lots of fun. You get to sample so many yummy things throughout the class, like tea and Peruvian hot chocolate. You also learn a lot about the cacao bean and chocolate making relative to Peruvian history. At the end of the class you all get to make your own chocolate with fancy fillings and decorations to take home with you. We ate all our chocolate during our Inca Trail hike. So good, so worth it!

A great intro to chocolate, chocolate processing and candy making. A basic (I'm a chef w/ candy/chocolate experience), informative and fun experience in understanding chocolate. I did this with a bunch of friends who had no chocolate making experience. It was fun for all and the chocolates we made (low cal of course!!) were delicious.

FASCINATING;-)!. After Machu Picchu, visiting Cusco and a cathedral or two, and more Inca ruins, we were ready for something different. We had a FANTASTIC lunch at Cafe Santa Cata and then went to the ChocoMuseo. It's a FUN friendly place where you can learn about chocolate from the beginning to the end. We were told that Peru is one of the few countries that grows organic chocolate. That was my most interesting fact. There was plenty of taste testing and we bought chocolate bars to savor the experience. If you're short on time in Cusco, there is a ChocoMuseo in Lima in El Centro. Another tip is, if you have time you can go and see a cacao tree plantation near Machu Picchu. That is organized through the ChocoMuseo.

Chocoholic. Visited twice - took the tour the first time and very much enjoyed all the free samples! The museum was more on the process of making chocolate and actual historical information was a little light. However, the cafe was great and I tried the two different types of hot chocolate and was grateful to receive advice on the correct way to create the Mayan variety! Great view across the Plaza Regocijo too.
