Had so much fun making truffles!. We popped in the Chocolate Museum because we had a bit of a craving for some chocolate - both to eat and to learn. The place is located just off Plaza Regocijo. The entrance is completely free and if you are lucky you could get a brief, but detailed and wonderful, explanation for an employee of the different parts of the museum. In the 10 minutes we spent we learned about the size of the cocoa bean, how it's processed, tasted their chocolate tea brew and were the different rooms. We liked it so much that we booked a truffle making class (~$25 USD) for the next day.The truffle making class lasted 2 hours and we left with about a dozen hand-made truffles each as well as the intel on how to make our own when we return to the states. We had a lot of fun and the instructor was great. It was the perfect break from the traditional sights around Cusco.

A Highlight of my trip. I am waiting for my pickup to the airport munching on the chocolates I made during the ChocoMuseum workshop. It was a really fun and informative two hours well spent. Pedro was knowledgeable and a great guide through the history and making of the chocolate. A truly unique experience.

Fun for all. This is a must if you have a few hours and want some information and some fun. It is set for the whole family or simply kids at heart. The guides/instructors will help you make chocolate and have some fun in the process.There are two work shops, we did the chocolate making. The other is Truffle making. Make sure you book the one you want. The classes are small, about 16 and last 2 hours. Allow another hour to pick up your chocolate creations.

I could smell the chocolate!. The smell of chocolate alone made me like this place so much! Added to the fact that you could browse the different products they offer - from, well, chocolates to tea and to coffee syrups and beauty products - and be amazed at the different things that can be done with chocolates. The staff in the Museo were also very welcoming to visitors and very eager to give them a tour on how the chocolates were organically made. I appreciated the fact that they were not pushy to sell you stuff - they just let you wander around and smell or taste their product samples and are ready to answer any queries you have. Not on my list to do in Cuzco before but definitely recommend to others that this is a MUST DO - especially if you love chocolates! I recommend the Cocoa Tea! Delish! I loved this place so much that when I saw their shop in Lima, I had to stop by! lol

Yummy. A welcome diversion from the thousand street hawkers all selling the same brightly coloured rubbish. The museum is interesting, but the best bit is the cafe, make your own hot chocolate, and then into the shop to buy more....recommended

Awesome afternoon at the ChocoMuseo. We spent the afternoon here doing a chocolate making course. Well worth the money. The course was completely entertaining as well as being informative- and you get to take your creations with you. Well worth the visit. Highly recommend.

A fun and yummy diversion. We stopped here on a whim and spent about 45 minutes viewing the museum and chocolate "factory" (more like a kitchen where they make chocolate). We were so glad we stopped here. Make sure you go around the corner from the main street store front, inside the little plaza and up the stairs to the museum. They have tastings of chocolate, chocolate tea and chocolate jam (surprisingly good). There is a small tour with information on chocolate making. You can also watch chocolates being made and the smell is amazing. You can buy the handmade chocolates in the gift shop. We also visited the cafe for the crepes and hot chocolate. The crepes were the best! You can eat them on a tiny balcony overlooking the square below. There is also free wifi and a nice bathroom.

A MUST DO IN CUSCO. I took a chocolate making class here after taking the tour at the museum and it was one of the highlights of my trip to Peru! Pedro was our instructor and he made the class even more awesome! And to top it off the chocolate we made was AMAZING! I highly recommend to any chocolate lover out there! Thank you again "Pedro Wanka!"

Chocolate Lover's Paradise. I was pleasantly surprised at this free attraction. It was informative with descriptions on local growth, uses, production and types of chocolates. There were opportunities to taste chocolate jams, liqueurs and different flavoured chocolates. Make time for the chocolate making classes offered. Location is tricky to find; around the corner from their store on the ground level, but the museo is upstairs above the courtyard. Pleasant staff and not pushy about buying product. Worth visiting even if it is simply for the aromas...

Choco Museo. I had the chance of going to this Choco Museo in Cuzco with friends and we loved both the museum and our guide. At the end of the free tour, everything smelled so good that we had to sit down and savor a hot chocolate and enjoyed it so much that we signed up for the chocolate-making workshop. The workshop was instructive and pleasant, lead by Pedro who was nice enough to give us recommendations for the rest of it stay in Cuzco. Best part was, we got to keep the chocolate we made! Overall, wonderful experience that I would highly recommend to others!

Hopeless "booking system". A friend and I booked ourselves in for a chocolate making class a week in advance.They were happy to take our money.Upon arriving excited and in good spirits, we were accused of having booked ourselves in for the truffle making class instead - and almost forced to leave.Luckily, a couple offered to do the afternoon session instead, allowing my friend and I to remain in the morning session with the rest of our friends.A female staff member told us we should have received an email confirming that we were in the truffle class - but they never asked for either of our email addresses at the time of booking - so they were obviously at fault for overbooking! She was quite rude, and we received no apology for the mix up and drama created.To be honest it ruined my mood and tainted the entire experience, plus my perceptions of the company. It is a great concept but they need to get their customer service together. To think we made the effort of being organised by booking early!

Forget Wine Tasting...Chocolate Tasting is an experience to remember!. I was not sure what to expect when I entered ChocoMuseo. We were greeted immediately by a tour guide who provided the background to appreciating the flavors we were to experience. He had a tray of chocolate samples to try as he told us the story behind each flavor. We tasted a tea made from chocolate, which I purchased for gifts...big hit! We tasted chocolate liqueurs and preserves. Last, we ate in the cafe. A must if you are visiting Cuzco!

Free and such a great place!. Found this place by accident and it was amazing!Free tour with one to the workers who explains the chocolate process to you. Well worth a visit and the chocolate is so good I bought 2 bars!Lots of free samples.... What more could you want from a place?

Free tour!. This place is so much fun. The tour that is provided is free! Lots of fun information about coca and chocolate making. We were recommended to come here from someone we met in Cusco and definitely was worth the short visit. The best part of the tour is tasting the different jams, alcohol and tea.

Easy going and well worth you're time. This will not compete with the historical sites around Cusco but is a nice stop after lunch. We just went there and a guide teaches you the basics of chocolate making for free and afterwards you conveniently end up in the shop and cafe. The prices are a bit high but not unreasonable (e.g. 9 S for a cup of hot chocolate or 15S for a 200g chocolate bar). And the quality is great and overall a really nice experience. We spent 1,5hrs there and enjoyed every minute!

cute but not what I was expecting. This "museo" is more like a chocolate shop with some educational aspects. There are some displays showing how chocolate is produced as well as the plants it comes with. Employees are friendly and informative, but the real draw here is the array of chocolate products for sale.

Diverting, tasty - basically an advert for products. We spent a little under an hour here. There were some good fast facts about the history of the chocolate industry, and some awareness raising on its impact in the wider world. Great.But basically it's a loss leader for their very lovely shop and fun choco products, which we definitely made use of too. Hardly a cultural highlight, but still a nice spot.You can get more Cusco travel tips here, at our blog:https://ednaventures.wordpress.com/2014/12/09/cuzco-a-beautiful-countdown/

Nice free little tour and tasting. We popped into this location after having lunch across the plaza. It was a great free tour and we got to taste a plain cocoa nib and cocoa husk tea along with some of their fully processed chocolate. They have a nice little exhibit upstairs showing all the steps in the process. Their bean to bar workshop looked fun and smelled fantastic.

Fun workshops and delicious café food!. A friend and I stopped here for chocolate fondue (delicious!!!) and learned that they have chocolate making workshops. We signed up for the "Bean to Bar" class and loved every second of it! It was really cool to learn about all stages of the chocolate making, and of course the drinks and chocolate you have during the workshop are to die for!I loved the first workshop so much that I did the truffle making class as well which was not as interactive as the first one, but still really great. I'm still dreaming of those amazing passionfruit truffles we made!Pedro was our chef for both classes and he was a really great instructor. He's very knowledgeable about chocolate and you can tell he really loves interacting with people - not just in the workshop but in the museum tours as well. Thanks Chef Pedro and Choco Museo!

Super nice!. We came here for a quick visit in the afternoon and had a really nuce time! The entrance o the museum part is free which was really great and they even gave us a guided introduction, Antonieta who was our guide was supeeer friendly and nice and knew her business well! They gave us free samples of chocolate and cacao tea which was sooo yummy! We bought chocotejas or peruvian truffles for 3.50 soles and tried them when we got back to our hotel and it was soo worth it! Amazing dark chocolate ffilled with caramel and nuts, a must try!!!

Fun Chocolate making class. We had such fun participating in the chocolate making class, making chocolates right from the cocoa bean stage. My two girls (age 11 and 13) loved it too. It was very hands-on and educational. The staff member was entertaining while giving a lot of information and keeping the class moving. A great way to spend a few hours. Highly recommended.
free chocolate!!!. Not only you will learn about chocolate, they will fill you with free chocolate, liquor, tea, etc!!!!!!!! Really good to buy gifts!
Delicous Handmade Chocolates. The chocolates we bought from here were delicious. We also purchased some coffee that we haven't yet tried. Friendly staff.
SEARCH THIS OUT. Fantastic place to find, learn about how chocolate is made locally and even sample various chocolate beans, drinks and liquers. Cafe is amazing.

Great fun for the family. A good laugh, interesting, friendly staff. Our 3 young children really enjoyed it roasting the cocoa beans, drinking the various hot drinks the host prepared and of course making their own chocolate flavours.
Fun past time. The exhibits were interesting and the chocolate is delicious. We bought a bunch to bring home and everyone enjoyed.

Fun & Tasty Stop in Cusco. The places smelled amazing! Friends and I did a quick tour of the place. You might get confused getting there. There are two places, one up stairs, which is the main Mueso, and one on the bottom which is part of the main Mueso but is really just a gift shop. They give you a short tour and then you can buy all the cacao goodies you'd like. They have chocolate samples and well as cacao tea. I loved the tea, it was amazing! Brought a bag home with me. We were there for about 20-30 minutes. The store does take credit card, which was awesome. They also have a cafe inside, didn't get to try it since we got there a bit before closing.

You don't need to have kids to go, you just need to love chocolate.. Way, way better than I expected. Bigger and nicer than the one in Lima, they have a nice little museum, knowledgeable people, lots of chocolate types to try and a nice café.Yes, of course they have to make money and it's a selling point, but they've actually invested into the museum and they let you try any type of chocolate or tea or whatever before buying. And they have good prices.You don't need to have kids to go, you just need to love chocolate.

Lots of Chocolate and Coffee. We spent quite a bit of time here as one of the servers gave us the tour, tasting and testing all the chocolates and coffee's. We loved the experience and information. We brought home some great organic coffee and chocolate!

A great afternoon excursion with kids. After a day of sight seeing and going from one place to another, this is such a fun little excursion for the family to do something unique together. During the 3 hour "class" the instructor teaches about chocolate making in Peru and South America and each step is made fun with hands on activities- peeling the cocoa beans, grinding them, making cocoa tea, etc. The grand finale- making your own chocolate- was definitely a fun mess of ingredients! I just wish we did that a little earlier so that the chocolates could set and we could bring them home after the class instead of coming back the next day. But fu for the kids!!!

We loved the cooking class.. Very informative, clean, organised, delicious and great for kids as well as adults. There are two little colonial patios looking out onto the plaza below to enjoy a hot chocolate.

If you love chocolate you must go. I love chocolate, but I had heard some mixed reviews about this place so I wasn't sure if I should go or not. I went anyway one day while I was wandering around. It was so much fun! You learn how chocolate is made, get to sample some chocolate, try some chocolate tea (yum!), and you can even buy some to take home with you. I overheard a woman bargain with the cashier in the shop to give her a better price for buying multiple chocolate bars!

Calling all chocoholics. The chocolate is great, yes, but go to the cafe and order a hot chocolate (I got one with my chocolate crepe). The hot chocolate comes in a small jug of liquid chocolate and hot milk. Add to your desire! YUM!
Great little tour for what it was.. Mostly a venue to sell their merchandise, but cool and informative nevertheless. If you have a free hour it's worth doing.

Try the samples!. My friend and I stopped here on a whim. It was rainy and we wanted to be inside. The staff was very friendly, offered us several samples (from spreads, to teas, to liqueurs!) which were all very good.

Loved it! Do the chocolate making course!. Amazing chocolate making course and such tasty treats to take home with you!For more reviews and information on places we've been and things that we've done check out our blog!www.looktheworldintheeye.comfacebook.com/looktheworldintheeyeinstagram.com/looktheworldintheeye

A tasty experience. If you have limited time in Cusco you might not want to spend it doing the chocolate workshop they offer, but we had a more flexible schedule and don't regret it for a minute. Oscar was our workshop leader and he guided us through a very pleasant and fun experience. You learn a lot, taste some goodies and, the best part: bring some delicious personalized chocolate home. You also get 10% discount on the shop if you attend the workshop. Don't have time to do it? Visiting the museo and grabbing a drink at their bar wastes 0 time and is also worth it.

what a lovely place. being there twice. second time did the course. the guide was exellent and I had so much fun making and eating and drinking chocolate. only sugguest would be chair provided for everything. a+++ a good activies for all age

The class is a fun experience!. The "bean to bar" class was a super fun way to spend part of a day, even when we only had 2 days to enjoy Cusco. The price was definitely reasonable, especially getting to take home some chocolate at the end (though you do have to come back a few hours later so it can solidify). It was interesting to hear more history and information about chocolate (e.g., depending on what other plants grow nearby to help cross-pollenate, the cocoa can pick up some of those aromas in its taste)FYI, even though they say you have to reserve online, we never heard back any confirmation, but we ended up walking buy the place in person, and we were able to sign up for the following day. Though it's not set up quite like a museum, there was definitely alot of interesting history and info around the area (that is the size of a clothing store). They definitely have some interesting chocolate-related products (e.g., chocolate tea, lotions, etc. so interesting gifts for a chocolate-lover, plus various edible chocolate bars and spreads too).

Fun Tour and Delicious Hot Chocolate. The aroma of the chocolate is divine. The tour is fun and free. The best part are all of the free samples. Their chocolate is locally sourced and the added ingredients are creative. The adjoining cafe is nice with the balcony seating and delicious hot chocolate.

Not much of a museum. the 'museum' is a cafe and chocolate store on the second floor of the building. some demonstrations and taste testing but other than that, dont expect much in the way of an educational experience. the chocolate is very good

Group chocolate making class!. We were in Cusco with a group of worldschoolers so we signed up for a chocolate making class. It was incredibly educational taking us through the steps from pod to table. We chose the more in depth 2-hour class. The kids ranged from 5-15 and the class was enjoyed by all. At the end you all take home what you've made. Highly reccommend!

Had a blast at the workshop. The museum is a gift shop where you can buy chocolates. But we went to the workshop where Pedro was leading the session. It was a fairly big group but it was a very informative session where we learnt everything about the cocoa pod from the tree to the chocolate. The session was so much fun! Pedro makes the session really interactive and fun for everyone of all ages! Thoroughly recommend despite being on the pricey side paying 75 soles.

a cute museum -- WITH SAMPLES!!!. we stopped by this museum and had a lovely hour -- learning all about chocolate -- from cacao harvest, to roasting and then blending - all the while enjoying little samples. The chocolate here is expensive -- it's also very good and since you get to sample it first -- you know you'll love what you buy. My favorite was the tea that you make out of the husks of the cacao beans. I ended up buying a bag to take home along with several chocolate bars.

Museum, factory and shop all in one!. This was a lot of fun. Like chocolate? Want to learn how its made step-by-step from the cacao bean? Want to make your own chocolate? Want to taste chocolate liqueur infusions? Want a giant brownie and/or mug of hot chocolate? Or a sample of cacao bean bark tea? Then this is the place to go!

Free tour with samples! Delicious chocolate! Fun gifts!. Went for the free tour of the choco museo and our guide was hilarious. We got to sample choco tea, chocolates and ordered desserts. All in all, delish! I bought some gifts for myself and family/friends back home.

5-stars for the chocolate making, 2 stars for the "Museum". This isn't really a Chocolate museum in any real sense. They have a couple room with information on how chocolate is made & grown, but it's basically a gift shop. If you want to buy good, organic, Peruvian chocolate, by all means go. But don't go expecting much more than a gift shop.If you take the class, however, you'll get a totally different experience. It's not cheap - 75 soles/person, but you get a busy 2 hours learning how chocolate is made - from the tree through to chocolate bars (and you get to make your own chocolates at the end). You get to taste stuff along the way too - an unfrosted, but fermented bean, a roasted bean, hot chocolate and some different kinds of chocolate.The class leader we had was great - entertaining, animated and informative. And the guy who was there when we were picking up our finished chocolates was equally so.If you have any interest in understanding the chocolate-making process, the class is a lot of fun and quite educational. Plus you walk out with a bag of chocolates that you made.

chocolate dreams. a fun afternoon full of information, laughs, and best of all, chocolate! the teacher was fun and informative, and we learned a lot about production of chocolate, and history. We also had a diverse group with people from several countries. it was so fun! well worth the money.

cool stop. great place to spend some time while acclimating in Cusco. It's free and the staff offer a good deal of history and details of chocolate-making. The samples and gift shop items alone are worth the trip

Touristy but fun. I took my kids here for a learning experience. We had a lovely time learning about the process of making chocolate and creating our own tasty combinations. I was surprised to see one in each town we visited. Definitely more store than museum. But, the chocolate was delicious and the two-hour course worth the price.

Free entry, good chocolate. You can't really miss this as wherever you walk you get given the flyers for this attraction. It's quite small, it has a bit of a story about how cocoa is grown and turned into chocolate (don't expect it to be anything like Cadbury World but then this is free!). You can buy chocolates of various types, we bought some dark chocolate and some sugar free chocolate, both were very good. We didn't try the chocolate making classes but these looked to be interesting too.

Not a museum at all . After going to Brussels last summer I had seen a great chocolate museum with many historic things and artifacts. I thought this would be similar. But actually this is just a shop to sell chocolate. Not really a museum. But I give it 3 stars because there cafe had some very good make your own hot chocolate which I made with some chili powder. Excellent. And there were free samples. If your looking for something for free to take some time during the rainstorms this is a good idea. Did I see anything new or learn anything here. Not really. But I guess that's why they have a workshop here.

So much fun!. Had one of the best time with strangers learning about and making chocolate. So worth the time and money. All the staff was wonderful and especially Pedro who was our master of ceremonies.

Charming tour and friendly .A must visit. Museum twinned with manufacturing fascinating tour and can watch chocolate being tempered and then moulded.Very friendly people and knowledgable.Oh and you can taste it...Delightful

The chocolate helps the altitude sickness!. I'd read about ChocoMuseo online and thought it would be a cute place to check out whilst in Cusco as an alternative to the history side of town (which is excellent).I was pleasantly surprised to discover the chocolate significantly helped the altitude sickness!The museum is a small space that provides tours by knowledgable guides fluent in many languages, and shows you the process in making chocolate, and also provides a couple of samples. Even better, the whole thing is free!There is a cafe if you'd like to purchase a drink or some snacks, and there is also a shop where you can buy products to take home.I'd highly recommend a visit

Had so much fun at the Chocomuseo!. We had an absolute blast at the Chocomuseo. It was one of the many highlights of our trip. Our instructor was fun and top notch, and we left with a great deal of knowledge and chocolate!

CHOCOLATE!!!! GO HERE!!. A small, but educational museum that illustrates every step of the chocolate making process. The best part is enjoying the view from the balcony while sipping on the delicious "Maya" and "Conquistador" hot chocolate. A must!! Both are equally tasty, so splurge and try both!!

Really Enjoyed. For about $25 per person, you get a 2 hour chocolate lesson and get to make some to take home (takes 45 minutes to cool). We had Achilles as our instructor, and thought his jokes were silly, but really enjoyed him. He prepared us 3 drinks and taught us a lot we didn't know. We really enjoyed the experience.
Delightful lesson. Enjoyable education on chocolate. Tastings are great, light atmosphere. Good place to rest after touring the City.

Excellent Workshop . We did the workshop here to learn about the chocolate process and have a go ourselves. It was simply brilliant fun and really educational. We had pedro doing the workshop and he was excellent. We spent a few hours here and it was well worth it.You also get to take your own made chocolate home!Enjoy
Lovely!. We took a tour of the chocolate museum and had a wonderful time. Entry is free, and you get to sample chocolate bars, jams, and liqueurs. The people are friendly and speak wonderful English.

Make your own chocolate. We went in Lima, Baraconna district and had a super time. Roasted and ground our own beans for cocoa tea, hot chocolate and chocolate. We had the process explained from beginning to end. The only thing missing was the actual cocoa pod to see. A fun afternoon and we brought our chocolate home!

Nice workshop and museum!. They'll teach you a lot about chocolate, and you can taste their chocolate too. There's a workshop for those who want to make their own chocolate, and a very delicious cafeteria. Its really worth visiting!

Interesting workshop - make your chocolate. The workshop explaining the process of chocolate manufacturing is interesting, beside the visit of the museum. You can book your participation before, we did it on the day of our visit since they did not reply our emails. However, an enjoible experience and a good chocolate bar as a reward.

Heaven for your sweet tooth. Someone who speaks excellent English (in our case, Pedro) actually shows you around explaining the ins and outs of chocolate production. Exhibits show the history of this confection and the processes involved in producing the variations. Pedro then allowed us to sample multiple varieties, some delicious chocolate tea, chocolate and fruit jams, and ultimately, various chocolate liqueurs. All for free!! They even have classes in making various chocolate products for a reasonable price (about $25) including enough chocolate eating during the class to satisfy the most serious chocoholic. We were impressed.

Small but fun. This is a small place but its still cool. They show you how chocolate is made and give you some samples. Then you can step into their restaurant to try even more. They sell lots of delicious chocolaty souvenirs. I recommend stopping by if your in the area, the tours are free!

Brilliant. I just took part in the chocolate making class. It was so much fun with the right balance of facts, information, practical, sampling and you get to take home a nice little bag of chocolates you make in the session. A nice way to pass a few hours :)

Delicious and fun!. We explored the facility and a guide ran us over the history and facts about chocolate! We then decided that we would stay for a chocolate making class (extra $$), which was also great. We learnt more about the process of chocolate, roasted and crushed cocoa beans and then enjoyed a few different chocolate drinks. We then got to create different flavoured chocolate using the different ingredients provided then covered with your choice of chocolate. Over all it was good fun!

Loved the chocolate making workshop with Josie. This has been a highlight of my time in Cuzco. I enrolled in the 4pm workshop and was early so was able to have a hot chocolate with chilli and honey, I sat outside on the balcony which has a lovely view. All the staff were very helpful and friendly. Josie was my teacher for the class and she sure is passionate about chocolate. It was so interesting to learn where chocolate comes from, the process involved and it's context in terms if countries which produce and consume. The class is hands on so I now how to make chocolate from scratch. I went to the class by myself and my fellow classmates were friendly. Great to do solo, on a date on with a group. thanks Josie and the chocomuseo team for a fun afternoon!

Good for 1/2 hour. You get to see how they make chocolate and have a few free samples. Not that exciting but my wife did go to a chocolate making class the following day which she thought was good fun. The chocolate is high in coco content so doesn't really suit my tastes

Nice tour of the museum. Our tour was very informative. The nice guy from Barcelona who provided the tour was very nice, patient, and enthusiastic! He also spoke good English which is always a bonus in Peru. We then tried the brownie which was excellent and the hot chocolate which was ok.

You're here for the chocolate.... Try to cocoa tea and buy it. And if you're a 'real chocolate' lover you'll love the different types of chocolate. If you like Cadbury, Hershey's or Mars you probably won't like the choc here. Get the cocoa tea instead.

uncomfortable atmosphere. Shop assistant was so rude and unkind. I thought if I had wanted to take part in their class she would be kind. Even when I left I said 'Chao!' but she turned her head and just saw me without reply.

Beware. Had a hot chocolate here - delicious.HOWEVER - the chocolate itself is not nice! My friend and I bought samples of different flavours.... We threw the majority of them in the bin (and we're chocoholics). They weren't cheap either. Think twice if you're buying as a gift... Especially if it's the dark chocolate.

Wonderful 2 hours!. A good alternative from all the ruins and great mountains in Peru... This is where you will indulge in 2 hour of warmth, laughter, and of course, chocolate. In my 2 weeks of trip in Peru, I put Choco Museo in the middle- it helped me recollect myself in many levels :)

Vote for Pedro. Really interesting to learn the history of the cacao bean on the South American continent, delicious chocolate samples and funny tour guide. We sampled chocolate from beans that came from all over Peru. Our tour guide was Pedro. We love you Pedro.

Take the Chocolate Making Class!. Took the chocolate making course with a group of friends, awesome!! You get to shell the beans, roast them, grind them, taste a few types of chocolate drinks from different parts of the world, and then make your own chocolate bars with a variety of toppings and things to add in! Absolutely great@

Worth experience. It was a very interesting experience. I did the workshop and since was alone had a personalized class, it was great! All the beverages and the chocolate itself is really good. Plus you make something good since they use cacao as a way for helping poor communities.

Nice class, OK experience. The class was nice experience overall but not the most interesting thing to do in Cusco. You learn about the process of chocolate making, but not really making your own chocolate from scratch (the process takes many hours). In the end you mix some prepared chocolate with other ingredients and create your own candy, which you can pick up later or the day after (or in our case 3 days after!) The staff at Choco museo are all very nice, especially the teacher (although she didn't speak the best english, and with all the professional terms it is a little hard to follow if english is not your mother language). Overall is a nice experience, but very touristic.
great fun. I had a really enjoyable experience learning all about making Chocolate, and its history. Well worth the money.
Great hot chocolate!!. The museum upstairs is a great way to get a hands on experience with South American Chocolate production. Delicious testers and an awesome hot chocolate afterwards. Must see!!

Great way to spend a few spare hours!. We checked out the museo and did the chocolate making class for 2 hours as it was raining in cusco and we had a few spare hours before the inca trail.The staff were great and very knowledgeable on the history of chocolate and the cocoa bean tree.We learnt a lot and got to make our own chocolates which were delicious!They also have yummy chocolate liqueurs that you can try. The coffee one was the best!Reasonable price and really worth it. Definitely do it if you like chocolate!
Cool place. Nice educational materials, lots of chocolate related stuff to choose from for souvenirs. Staff welcomes you with some free choco tea and a free introductory tour.

who knew..... We did a chocolate making activity for the kids - but it turned out to be a lot of fun. The teacher was very engaging and fun. There were probably 14 people in our class - and all had a good time. At the end we got to make our own chocolates (milk or dark) and they were ready for pick up an hour later.

great place. make sure you book at least one day in advance, as the places are limited.it is a great experience - with a lot of jokes you learn about the cacao - and see the process of making chocolate.at the end you even can take the chocolates you did.

Huh? This won a Traveler's Choice Award?. Unless you truly have nothing better to do with your time in Cusco, then take a pass on the ChocoMuseo. I have absolutely no clue why people are clamoring over visiting this site. It certainly is not a Museum, and is essentially 1 of 2 options: a glorified gift shop/cafe to sell you their chocolate, or a small kitchen area designed to sell you their chocolate.The owners of this store must be laughing their way to the bank every time a foolish tourist antes up the 100 soles to spend 2 hours doing essentially nothing except take home 5 soles worth of chocolate.The entire place is located on 2 floors, and is tiny. Before you book anything, go and see for yourself just how the entire place is a sales pitch, and that you learn very little about either cocoa or chocolate.
A chocolate lovers dream.... Found some of the best artisanal chocolate ever in Cusco. Try the chilli chocolate, the cacao beans and the chocolate with coca.
Death by chocolate. What more can I say? Delicious!! Definitely worth stopping by the cafe and trying their hot chocolates and the fondue!
Fun and quirky. I enjoyed making my own hot chocolate using local organic produce. The staff are lovely and the place just smells like chocolate. You must stop here and try for yourself!
ChocoMuseo - Nice diversion when acclimating. We liked the shop and tastings - a nice diversion. They offer chocolate making classes too - if you have time in Cusco. Sounded fun.

Get involved! It is such fun!. We had a wonderful time between 4-6 pm on one of our days in Cuzsco . The activity is educational,entertaining, delicious and you get a lovely collection of hand- made chocolates to take away.

Great place to check out. This is a must place to visit if you like or love chocolate. You may also take a class here, It is also a great place for a drink and snack Nd it has a great view of Cusco. We enjoyed the milk chocolate Sal de Maras bars and bought some to take home with us.
What a smell!. If you need a chocolate kick, this is the place! A nice tour, some samples and some shopping. All while smelling chocolate! What could be better?

Chocolate school - great fun. we took the class the last day in town while we were waiting for out night flight to Lima and then home. It was the perfect way to end our trip. Every time we eat the chocolate we made we miss Cusco.

Great chocolate making class, "museum" okay. If I were only rating the chocolate making class then I'd give it five stars. This was a unique experience where you not only learned but got to do all the steps required to convert a cacao bean into chocolate. I did a "class" like this in a similar place in another city which turned out to be nothing but pouring melted chocolate into a mold - the class from ChocoMuseo was the real deal.The museum itself, however, is really just a chocolate store. There is a room above the store that has a nice display of ~6-8 boards to explain the chocolate making process - the boards are simple but effective - but that's it. There's nothing real to see.Note: I'm a chocoholic and particularly enjoy dark chocolate, but the chocolate I got from the class was too bitter for me (it's not actually what we made in class as one of the steps requires 24 hours). So I suggest either getting milk chocolate or adding sugar to the mix when given the option to mix in various additives into the molds. My wife got milk chocolate and it's much better.

Something different.... The museum is tiny, but well out together, and SO interesting! The guides are enthusiastic and friendly, and you get plenty of free samples. Stay for a hot chocolate at the cafe afterwards too...they're to die for! All in all a deliciously different way to spend an afternoon in Cusco.

Chocolate making class was so much fun!. I took the chocolate making class which was so much fun and experiential. We roasted, peeled and ground our own cocoa beans after a quick tour of the museum. We learned so much about cocoa and even got to mold our own chocolates. Highly recommend for something different.
Most delicious hot chocolate. I went to the ChocoMuseo in Cusco more than I'd like the admit. The people were so friendly, and hot chocolate was incredible.
chocolate lovers. nothing better than spicy hot chocolate and a brownie when it is pouring rain outside. freebie chocolate tea if you're having a quick look is good too.
Worth a visit. Nice way to spend an hour or so. Lovely chocolates. Nice little cafe there with delicious hot chocolate. Well worth a visit.

Chocolate from one continent to another. Travelling to Cusco we didn't expect to find something deicious,but only warm and nice cloth. That's why we were surprised when we have found Musem of Chocolate.Chocolate is really great!Everyone in my family liked it,even that one who doesn't like black chocolate liked that one that i brought with me.Excursion was very little,but informative. Guys around us are not annoying,very kind and answer fully at any question you ask.This place have to be added to the your list!You woun't be dissapointed!

Chocolate Dreams. Heaven exists- in every spoonful of melted chocolate that you mix with Cinnamon, Cloves, and Hot Milk in the cafe at the Choco Museo. The greeting at the front door of the shop by Fabian who offered us three varieties of chocolate drops entranced us. And watching the process of evolution from cocoa bean to finished chocolate slab was informative. We bought some wonderful varieties of chocolate to be broken off cchunk by chunk to create sublime hot chocolate. What more could a person want while wandering through the streets of Cuzco on a Sunday afternoon?

Love chocolate - visit here. We smelled the chocolate from a few feet away from the entrance. It is a free visit with samples. You can sign up for the candy making session but we did not have the time. It is a small museum so you are not spending a lot of time reading. They have two videos to watch but they advertise for themselves before the video starts. The cafe has a make your own hot chocolate option that you need to do! The brownie was scrumptious! I enjoyed the chocolate tea. It is worth a visit if you have time to spare.

Great place!!!. If you like chocolate, this is the place for you! If you don't, it is still a great place to learn about the importance of cocoa for the region and in the world. You can learn, taste, buy and even take classes here.

hygiene issues. we came here several times during our weeks in cusco, to reload on what tasted like delicious chocolate. then we took a chocolate truffle making class here, which was, honestly, gross. the teacher viewed hygiene as an afterthought: after I said something, he gave us gloves, but not before the food was contaminated by people. the way they handle dishes and plates, how the counter top is touched by everyone's dirty hands, then used for cooling and smoothing out liquid chocolate, the dirt in the cracks of the counter. would be acceptable if mom and pop, but this place makes real money and does huge business. kids in the truffle making group were eating out of the bowls and licking their fingers (that would then be mixed in with the chocolate that everyone would eat). 3/4 four of us got sick on our cusco trip. don't know if it was this place, but i wouldn't be surprised. that was the end of us shopping here, it's just not worth it.

Amazingly interesting tour. I don't know how much chocolate I've eaten, but it wasn't until I went to the Choco Museo in Cusco that I actually understood the process of chocolate manufacture. This amazingly interesting tour given by knowledgeable and thoughtful guides (all free) taught me so much about the different types of chocolate, and how it's all made. We tasted "chocolate" from every stage of the process through to the finished product. A last minute decision to go here but worth it! Highly recommended.

Get the Hot Chocolate at the Cafe. I would come back to Choco Museo just for the cup of hot chocolate and strawberry banana crepe I ate in the café. The museum itself is a small but informative place and the chocolate is very good. But what I would go back for is the cup of hot chocolate. Wish they sold the chocolate sauce they use in for the coca, but they don't. fun place to sit and relax. Oscar was incredibly helpful to us. Nice staff and unique products to take home to friends and family.

Very interesting. Being a chocolate lover, I found it very interesting to find out how its made. The museum was interesting and well laid out, the guide was very informative and the samples at the end were delicious. If I'd had a bit more time, I would have liked to have done the chocolate-making course.

Went back three times :). This is a really cute place and a great way to spend some time while you're out walking around Cusco. The museum portion itself is small but interesting...but the best part is obviously the chocolate. They have a great selection of different chocolate bars, flavored pisco, beer, etc. I ended up getting a lot of my gifts there which my family loved.

Fun. My fiancé and I did the chocolate making workshop at the Cusco location. The staff were great at helping us in the store and rearranging the time/date of the workshop we were to attend. The workshop was a lot of fun and our host was great at explaining things clearly. We had a lot of fun and it was a really highlight in our trip. That being said, I had read online here about sanitary concerns/cleanliness. I can't deny that the cleanliness level was questionable. Things like: the employee is wear latex gloves for cleanliness but just then she ran her gloved hand though her hair so that's not sanitary anymore. Some of the staff did not have their hair pulled back or netted (as well as some of us customers working along side where some legit chocolate preparation was going on) and I actually did have to pull a long dark strange hair out of one of my beverages. On a smaller point, the grouting in the tile counter was kind of old and looking like it needed to be scrubbed/redone and resealed.Also, it was kind of funny because we were taught about how long they have to mill the chocolate to allow the sugar to fully dissolve so the chocolate isn't gritty and then the chocolate they gave us to make our take-home chocolates with was totally gritty. Still tasted good. Wasn't a big thing. Still really glad we did it but somethings for other people to consider.

Best time to spend a lazy afternoon!!. I did the chocolate workshop on a lazy afternoon after returning from the INCA trail. The instructor was really funny and made the two hours feel like two minutes. You will get a high on chocolate fragrance just by being there for a minute. And the chocolates are DELICIOUS!!!
Take the chocolate making class. My husband and I took the chocolate making class. It was fun and we learned a lot. It's a good place to buy some treats home for my co-workers.

we love chocolate!!. Great little stop for chocolate gifts and tasty snacks. Their hot chocolate was a hot milk and a bowl of chocolate you shovelled in. Perfect. Only 4 stars as it was a bit crowded.

Delicious. We met the chef in the Plaza de Armas and he gave us some samples of his chocolate. We had to go to the Museo to see what he had there. We ended stocking up on many flavors of chocolate. This may not be on everyone's list of what to do in Cusco, but it should be for any chocolate lovers out there.

The best chocolate in Cuzco! The best cooking class in Cuzco!. My husband and I walked through the doors of the ChocoMuseo to the delight of our senses. Upon entering you are awash with the incredible aroma of chocolate and confections. We toured the museum and tasted all the delicious samples...ranging from milk and creamy (for him) and dark and rich (for me). We chose to take a cooking class with the Soledad one evening held upstairs in an intimate kitchen. We were escorted by our chef to the San Pedro market to shop for our ingredients and learn more about the fruit, vegetables, grains, and cheese of Peru. Soledad is a gem and her English superb (she says she's learning but I was impressed!)Together our intimate group of 6 prepared an authentic Peruvian meal. Even with a few dietary restrictions, the food was outstanding and making Pisco Sours a treat. I highly recommend the museum for a visit and the cooking school for an experience. We did not have time to take the chocolate making class but saw it in action and it looked equally as delectable and fun!

We have been 3 times in a week and plan on going again tomorrow . This place is amazing. The smell alone is enough to make you visit. Last time we went we ordered the make your own hot chocolate and a chocolate brownie it was so delicious that we are going to return tomorrow.

Don't miss it!. It's free, fun and delicious. My guide was really lovely, informative and not the least bit pushy. The tour is really good, doesn't take long, you get to try lots of treats along the way, then if you like you can order something from cafeteria and enjoy it on the balcony overlooking what I reckon is the nicest plaza in Cusco, and finally you can purchase some goodies if you like. I had a cold mocha and it was honestly the best I've ever had. Muchas gracias!

Really educational... and great chocolate. Got to learn loads of interesting stuff about the history of chocolate, and how its made from the picking of the bean, to the moulding of the finished product. And boy, is the final product tasty!!

So much fun. My friends and I decided to take this fantastical class. We learned a lot and had a great time. Remember you get 10% off your purchases after class but you HAVE to tell them or they might miss it when you check out. Even though we were silly and forgot to tell them they credited our 10% towards a cooking class that evening. Stay tuned for that review!

Mmmm so much chocolate!. We were walking by and the sweet aroma caught our attention. I hadn't realized that the shop was a museum of sorts as well! The guide was very friendly and funny and offered us countless chocolate, jam and liquor samples as well as a little history thrown in as well. The museum is free, so it's completely worth it :)

Choco-knowledge and taste overload. Great way to spend time in Cusco when you're not shopping - making and tasting chocolate, whilst learning about the history of cacao. Definitely a highlight and 10% off in the shop after the chocolate making meant some extra weight into the rucksack - Christmas presents(honest)

Do the Chocolate making workshop!. We had one day in Cusco to acclimatise before Machu Picchu and stumbled across the chocolate museum. We ended up doing the workshop which is only 70 soles per person and so worth it! It´s around 2 hours long and we got to make different chocolate drinks and our own chocolate selection to take home. Our instructor Pedro was amazing and gave us lots of info on Cusco and the Incas as well as chocolate. It was really different to most things we´ve done on our trip and we both loved it.
cute. Fun little stop during our travels, we stumbled upon this place and learned a lot about chocolate, and got lots of free samples!

Sweet place. When you visit Cusco, put this place on your list! unlike other museums, there is not an entrance fee. There are 3 phases to the the tour; one guided and the other 2 on your own. For the first phase, a staff member will greet you and tell you all about the process of making chocolate. The next phase is self guided where you will go upstairs and continue learning about making chocolate; reading/seeing/smelling. the last phase is a short documentary that you watch about the history and uses of the cocoa bean and process. Lastly, you do a taste test and then you purchase. Prices are reasonable, 3.50 - 27soles ($1.19 - $9.19) So basically, chocolate for everyone on your list! They also offer 3 chocolate making classes per day 70 soles ($23.83)Even though there is no entrance fee, don't forget to tip at checkout after you purchase chocolate.

Chocolastic. If you like chocolate then this is your place. You can just walk in from the street and you'll have great fun. For free you'll get a tour around in the museum, explaining more how it is produced, where it is going, etc.... But after that the fun begins. You can try different kinds of chocolate, and drinks made with cacao. If you want you can also make you own chocolate. Of course after that you've the possibility to buy anything that you've tasted that you liked, or you can enjoy something in their cafeteria.

Fun to do with friends. We did the tour of the ChocoMuseo and participated in the making of chocolate. We realized very quickly that it is much more difficult to make the chocolate than to eat it. Our guide made it a fun experience and at the end we were able to make out own chocolates from various different molds and take them home with us to share with our friends. The choco tea was something we had never had, but was really good. While in Peru, you must try it. Very low in calories, but has a great chocolate taste. Enjoy & have fun!

Great Chocolate experience!. The museum/chocolateria/shop and event space in Miraflores, Lima is very nicely and appropriately decorated, and the staff is helpful and nice. Above all, for a chocolate lover like me, it is Willy Wonka's factory! Chocolate exists in every possible different types, texture, mix, presentation. ...a must see visit if you are a chocofan!

Private Chocolate Tour was the Best. We arranged to have a private demonstration and had a great deal of fun. Our guide showed us how the whole process from bean to chocolate. In the end, we made our own chocolates from the paste we had made. (They weren't very good, but the demonstration was great.)We got our hands dirty with cocoa powder, cocoa paste and chocolate.We had a great time and would highly recommend it for an early evening activity.

JUST LOVED IT!. I am a chocoholic and this was certainly the spot for me! The Choco Museum is located on the 2nd floor, in a building off a side street from the main square in Cuzco. Although difficult to find, the ChocoMuseum is worth the trip.Once inside, you pay $2 to enter the "museum" portion of the store. There are live trees, with pods, which show the life a cacao bean. Since I was the only visitor at the time, I was givena private tour. The guide explained how chocolate is processed from bitter bean, and blended with other types of chocolate, to make the "perfect" taste.There is also a section with different chocolate "molds" so you can see how chocolate is crafted into different shapes.You can buy just about anything you can think of here. They obviously sell chocolates of all types (milk, white, dark) and even show you what the ingredients are which go into the chocolate. You can buy cookies, brownies, fudge, and cakes. But you can also purcahse beverages (or powder to make your own drinks, once at home), shampoos, soaps, body creams, etc. This is really a chocolate lover's delight!This is not the only location of this museum. There are several, including a much smaller one outside the ruins of Ollanytambo. Either way, make sure to go to one of these locations while in PERU. You will not be sorry you did.

Take a workshop!. The museum itself is quite small. However, the Bean to Bark class was so much fun. The instructor kept everyone engaged the entire time. The best part is that you walk away with quite a bit of chocolate that you make yourself. Definitely worth the visit.

I Love Chocolate. My guide in Cusco took me to this place initially for a couple of chocolate bars. OK, I wound up taking their chocolate making class (FUN!) and testing, and buying a load of stuff for gifts - which I must add were really enjoyed by all. This was just a fun way to spend a few hours. PS. Try to chocolate shampoo and conditioner - Yum. Missed the hot chocolate but heard it was great.

Fantastic fun. We went to the chocolate making class , wonderful information given in an interesting way . Manuel was excellent , funny and entertaining . The whole experience was fantastic , I would recommend it for any chocolate lover .
Great Experience. Fun time and making your own chocolate treats to take home with you !!!!The course is hands on to make your own chocolate from the beans themselves
Great location. Lovely area in city and fine views.chocolate delicious and shop offers interesting things to buy.loved the chocolate skewers and chocolate drinks

Interesting site to visit. We visited this to see how the chocolate was made. There is a very small "museum" with text explanations of Coca and the beans. You can watch them make chocolates but there is not a lot to see. It's really more of a store to buy chocolates.

Good chocolate. We visited this museum to see how the chocolate was made. There is a very small display that shows you some history of the coca beans. You can then watch them make some of the chocolates. We used this as an excuse to buy some great chocolate to take home. The museum is not all that informative but the shop is great.
Breathing chocolate. It is definitely a MUST! I also took their workshop learning about chocolate and made my own delicious, scrumptious little chocs :)
hummmm chocolate!. Not much of a museum to me. You can make some chocolate «bonbons». A shop. Lots of variety. But no bargain there.

Great chocolate. chocolate is awesome but for the chocolate making lessons ask for a good guide,and groups should be no more than 12 to enjoy properly the experience .Besides that definitely you should go there

A nice free attraction. A chocolate museum situated 5 minutes from the main square (Plaza de Armas) is a 2 story shop / museum that talks all about chocolate. The museum itself is free and you are invited to have sample drinks and sample chocolates.The museum itself won't take you very long to explore and learn all about chocolate (I'd say maybe 20 minutes), but the facts that they provide is very interesting and if you like, there is a shop and a cafe where you can get some chocolate inspired drinks.A nice stop if you have a free time, but not a must see.

Good story and facts about transforming cocoa into delicious products. First time to see a cocoa plant. nice to follow the story of cocoa, chocolate, hot chocolate and other yummy derivatives through time and space

Well worth a look. A chance to see chocolate being made. You can even pay to go on a chocolate making course. Good range of chocolate products and coffee (beans or ground) to buy in the nearby shop. Chocolate tastes great and is considerably less expensive than that on sale at Chocolate Republic shop nearby.

Loved it!. I have been wanting to know the process for making chocolate for a very, very long time and was thrilled to have the opportunity in Cusco. I signed up for the basic course. Our instructor was very knowledgable, and her English was very good. I learned all that I wanted to know and we all got to participate in the activities. The end result (your own chocolate) was ready for pick up an hour after the course ended. I recommend it to anyone interested in food. Making chocolate in Cusco! How cool is that!
Worth a visit. Very informative guide told us how chocolate is made form start to finish. Plenty of samples to try including chocolate liquor and chocolate tea.

Chocolate workshop great fun. most things to do with chocolate are likely to be good but this was exceptionally good. Very informative and hands on, we got to go through the whole chocolate making process and then created our own. Generous with the time allowed and the bag of chocolates we took home. Highly recommended

chocolate education. Great museum for free…a guided tour, videos and a chocolate sampling. Near the Historical Museum. Make sure you go to the Museum part…they also have a store front. Museum is on the second floor. Very educational and hey, it's chocolate!
For Chocolate's fan only. I like their products and the history about chocolate, and the people there let you know about it very well.

Fun workshop with sweet results. We did the trufas workshop with a group of 10 people and it was both fun, entertaining and we learned a lot about cacao and chocolate. The kids in our group loved to get their hands dirty with sweets and fruits and chocolate.

Fantastic Chocolate Workshop. Not really a museum - just a small display on the growing of the beans and the process used to make them into chocolate. However, the chocolate making workshop is a must - great, hands on fun - everything from grinding the beans to making your own chocolates (which you get to take home with you after they've set). The instructor was very entertaining and I never thought I'd end up singing with a group of strangers whilst mixing chocolate based drinks!

Great staff and chocolate speaks for itself. Loved the tour (both guided and self-guided). When you walk in, you're greeted with cacao tea. We learned everything we ever wanted to know about chocolate-making. You can sample chocolate liquors and jams or you can purchase chocolate items in the cafe to eat there or at the gift shop to take with you. We enjoyed the chocolate so much that we went again in Lima!

Small but must see. Took the 2 hour chocolate making class. The teacher was awesome so knowledgable and the chocolate was soooooo good best I've had. Defiantly worth checking out. And the fruit chocolate fondu is a must!

A good history of the cocoa process.. Not only does this museum explain the growth and harvesting of cocoa pods, it details the path the cocoa pods take in becoming cocoa products. Naturally there are samples available, food and drink for purchase, and many chocolate products for sale. One can purchase cocoa butter, oil, lip balm, powder, jewellery made of cocoa beans, etc.

Chocolate was Great; Tour was Non-Existent. We arrived to the storefront on the square in the evening and asked if they were still open for tours. We were told they were and a very nice guy escorted us around the corner and up the stairs to the cafe. He then pointed us to a room that had a description of chocolate making and told us to look around. We did and then waited in the tasting area for the lone employee to pay attention to us. He was talking to another couple and despite our party waiting for over 10 minutes, neither the employee nor the other couple (also Americans) would break their conversation to allow the employee to help us. We went back to the cafe, had a few samples that were out and then made some purchases. Disappointing and not worth the visit apart from purchasing some great (and I mean really great) chocolate.

Fascinating Introduction to Chocolate. We spent a very happy 45 minutes in the chocolate museum in Cusco during our visit there. Entrance and the tour are free and the lady that showed us around and gave us different types of chocolate to try was extremely helpful. Recommended if you have any interest in chocolate.
Good experience, great chocolate. If you are on the area dedicate one hour. There is good explanations, good atmosphere and very good chocolate to taste

Sweet way to spend a day in Cusco. While my family started their trek on the Inka Trail that knee problems forced me to forgo, I spent a wonderful few hours at the bean to bar workshop. Due to a mixup, our workshop ended up being bilingual Spanish and English, which the instructor, Gladys, handled very graciously. It actually added an international flavour to the experience.I had intended to take the chocolates we created home as a souvenir, but I don't think they will make it that far.I also took full advantage of the 10% discount on merchandise for gifts to bring back. If you do not have time for a workshop, at the very least pop in to either the museum or the store to sample the cocoa tea.

I Heart Chocolate. Found this places thanks to a guy who was handing out flyers that came with a 5% off your purchase. The entrance was free and so was the tour. I decided to opt out on the tour portion and just walk around the museum sampling yummies. I ended up purchasing a chocolate liquor that was delicious! Def worth the visit if you are in the area.

Small and surprisingly modern. Very colorful and modern, this is much less a chocolate museum and much more an informative gift shop (with 3 other locations/chains throughout Peru that you will likely encounter in other main tourist areas.) The cafe, however, offers a delicious array of treats, and as no admission is charged it is worth the visit. Try the chocolate tea (complimentary) and have a seat overlooking the Plaza if possible- a lovely view and a nice place to taste some local chocolate concoctions!

For chocolate lovers!. Chocolate truffles were awesome! the dark chocolate covered fruits like aguaymanto were very yummy too. Also tried the white chocolate with crushed coffee beans. All of them were delish!
Very informative, lots of tasting. This was a tasty museum! The staff is very pleasant and talks about the process of making chocolate, types of chocolate, etc. There is also a shop but no pressure.

Chocolate heaven. Found this quaint little chocolate factory on Limas barranco district...you can smell the aroma on the sidewalk! In an old 1920s building...took a short tour of the chocolate making process..Rose was my charming guide, lots of products for sale, from flavored chocolates to chocolate liqueurs made with pisco...chocolate tea, lip balm etc...delightful..great for gifts

Must take a chocolate making class!. Great experience. Fun for the whole family. My sister and I took the chocolate class, learned loads about cacao and chocolate making. One of the most fun activities we did in Cusco.

Didn't actually make any chocolate!. Reading the website I was quite excited to join the Chocolate making workshop, who doesn't like chocolate! However, it wasn't quite what I was expecting so I wouldn't recommend this as a must do, rather if you have time on your hands and looking for something other than sight seeing. Also the workshop isn't cheap nor the chocolate products in the shop! I was looking forward to actually making the chocolate but after all the theory and demonstrations we were handed a bowl of ready made chocolate and all we had to do was pour into the mold of our choice. In hindsight my time would have been better served exploring more of Cusco. I guess since we were the last workshop of the day it was a small group, just 5 people so that was good. The 'guide' was very friendly but struggled a little sometimes with English so would often chat with the others who spoke Spanish which wasn't ideal.

Promising but no delivery. Interesting enough to visit for a quick run-through (and choco-sampling), but disorganized in arranging Peruvian cooking classes. At the beginning of the week, they said we could sign up any time. When I went back 3 days later, they said they were booked more than a week out. They also were not willing to do a class for just 1 or 2 people. At least their hot chocolate in their café is good. There is no fee to see the museum, but the cooking classes is 120 soles.

Bean to Bench Workshop. Had one of the best afternoons of my life. So much crammed into a 2 hour session and totally the best value for money.Made 2 different types of hot chocolate, got history lessons, played games, made our own chocolate bars. Just awesome. And the host guy was hillarious. Seriously, you´ll be missing out if you don´t do this when in Cusco.

Visit to Choco Museum, Peru. On a walk round Cusco during June we were given a flyer for the Choco Museum. Museum, we thought, museums are cultural - nothing like a bit of culture on holiday! As we were chocoholics we visited and were impressed - not only plenty of free samples, but an interesting historic run through of the making of chocolate in the area. Thoroughly recommend to other visitors to cusco.
Educational & tasty. On our first day in a Cuzco, we stopped in at the Choco Museo. What a great museum, and what's not to love:Free of chargeChocolate and its historySamplesVery friendly staff

Book a workshop. We did a two hour workshop - fantastic. You get the opportunity to hear the whole cocoa story, grind beans and make chocolates to take away. Also do not miss the hot chocolate - liquid chocolate that you then pour into hot milk, yummy......

A heaven for a chocoholic!!!. My name is Katrín and I´m a chocoholic!!! What a heaven this place is for a person like me :) I did the "Beans-to-Bar" workshop and it was so much fun and informative. We laughed as we learned the process from bean to a bar, we drank amazing chocolate drinks and made our own bars. What a great way to start the day, Chocolate makes people happy and I surely went out there a happy woman. It´s amazing to sit on one of the small balcony overlooking Regocijo square, have a wonderful brownie or fruit chocolate fondue. I also highly recommend the cacao tea that you can taste for free or win by grinding in the workshop, it´s delicious :)
Love the coco tea. This is a great chocolate museum. There's even samples of coco tea for guests and it's actually really good. We brought back a lot of chocolate and everyone loved it!
tasty!. we went here almost every afternoon between brunch and dinner. to rest, enjoy the view, the wifi and relax. good yummy chocolate place!

A great place to spend some quality family time. I am a chocoholic so it is no surprise that I made it my duty to take the family to the Chocomuseo. We were given a brief history of the coco trees and beans and started our chocolate making experience from the real beans. We were given the beans to roast, made coco tea with the shell and had some amazing hot chocolate to drink. We were able to add our own combination of ingredients and set our chocolate to mold. My kids had an amazing time and this is one of their favorite memory of the trip to Peru.

Definitely worth a look. We spent a bit of time exploring the choco museo they have great service, beautiful samples, yummy brownies but the high light for us was the chocolate beer a must try while you are there. Shore not to disappoint.

Nom Nom Nom :). There is no entrance fee and so you are more than welcome to just have a look in, try some chocolate specialities (tea, liquor, marmalade) and have a chat with the very friendly staff..For real chocolate lovers there are three 2h chocolate workshops every day (S70). There you learn and do all the steps of chocolate production, drink some drinks made of pure cocoa and yeah in the end make your own chocolate creations (salt, chilli, nuts, oreos, coca, sparcles, and many more)It was fun and yeah, as I've said, a must do in Cusco for everyone who loves chocolate :)

If you like chocolate.... This is the place to go. We visited the Choco Museo and received an overview of the history of cocoa, saw a live demonstration of the chocolate making process, and ended by tasting a sample of some of the various products produced from cocoa beans. Our time was short so we weren't able to take the class, which looked like a lot of fun. We did manage to make a few purchases to take home to friends and family. Delicious!

Small but worth it. This place is highly advertised but I thought it was worth the trip. There was a lot of interesting things that we learned there. The people who work there were fun and outgoing and they enjoyed giving our group a hard time when we tried the cocoa beans before they have the bitterness taken out of them. I definitely recommend getting some of their Chocolate Tea because I didn't and I've regretted it, it's fairly cheap and very unique. There are tons of chocolates and jewelry there for one to buy as well as a cafe of sorts. I didn't buy or eat anything there other than the free samples but it was a fun trip.

Old and young, take a peak. You should try it. Although its not only a museum, but rather a shop-museum, its worth the visit. You can find out about the chocolate history or take part in a workshop. We also bought some chocolate and a chocolate lip-balm.

Tasty chocolates!. We stopped by Cuzco's ChocoMuseo to learn about the history of Chocolate in Peru. We were greeted with Chocolate Tea which was delicious! We ended up buying a few packages of tea.We later toured ourselves around the Museum learning about the history of chocolate and the making of chocolate. It was quite educational as it tied in with the Spanish conquest of the Inca Empire.We sampled a few chocolates and jams, which was nice. I wish we signed up for some Chocolate making classes. Although we did not participate in these classes, we did view them and it looked amazing.This is a great place to shop for Peruvian souvenirs.

Enjoyed the workshop. This is not very much a museum, it's more a chocolate shop (various selections of chocolates, chocolate-flavoured cosmetics, coffee, cocoa, chocolate butter etc.) together with caffee. Nevertheless, you can take a chocolate-making class, which we really enjoyed. Classes run 3 or 4 times per day and it's recommended to make a reservation in advance (we made a reservation directly at the place). The cost is around 30-35 euro I think. Very nice lady, leading the class, explained to us the whole process of chocolate making, and some steps we were able to try on our own (cocoa beans roasting, mashing, peeling....). We were even preparing the chocolate "tea" (hot water and cocoa beans' shells) and typical peruvian cocoa. At the end of the class each of us was able to make its own chocolate truffles with different flavours according to our wish (various nuts, cinammon, coconut, vanilla, salt, chilli, coca, coffee etc...), which we could take home. Amazing experience!

Hot chocolate on the balcony!. I consider myself a chocolate lover and Choco Museo was an ideal location to enjoy a cup of hot chocolate. After a museum tour and chocolate-filled discussion with a young man named Achilles, we decided to move to the balcony and enjoy a cup of hot chocolate. The chocolate paste was served with hot milk, so it was easy to mix based on your preference. I recommend taking the chocolate making class, trying a few liqueurs and other cocoa products. The staff was very friendly and knowledgable at this museum. Thumbs up to Achilles and the lady from Vilcabamba region. I have visited several cocoa farms and factories, but my experience at Choco Museo was absolutely amazing.

Take the chocolate making class!. My friend and I signed up to take a chocolate making class and loved it. The class started with learning about cocoa beans and how they grow, then we roasted, peeled, and ground the beans right there, while enjoying three different cocoa-based drinks our teacher made for us. We each made our own set of chocolates, choosing from milk, dark, or white chocolate and having our pick from a large variety of fillings. The teacher was great: she answered any questions we had, was happy to take photos for us, and overall made the time informative and fun. The ChocoMuseo includes a shop with all kinds of chocolate treats (affordable too!), a chocolate cafe with a view of a lovely town square, and of course the museum and class section. Definitely worth a visit, and well worth paying to take the class!

Chocolate rules supreme. This tiny little museum has a beautiful ambience and an amazing staff of very happy people who shared in my own enjoyment. Lots of smiles, lots of conversation, and just enjoyed lingering and conversing with these delightful people. It's a half hour you'll be thrilled you took.

Try to get a seat on the balcony. Try a hot chocolate! it was the best hot chocolate i ever had! it is not on the menu. Ask for it. They have it. They will bring chocolate paste and hot milk and you mix it the ratio you want. Just try it is just sooooo good!

Don't miss this if you love Chocolate!. I happened to pick up a brochure for the ChocoMuseo at the B&B where we were staying and another guest recommended the chocolate-making workshop. We had some extra time, so we reserved our spot. We were not disappointed. First of all the place smells like chocolate heaven. When you arrive, you can immediately sample chocolate "tea", and other yummy chocolate concoctions. The workshop was fun and entertaining. Our Chef, Ivan, lead us through a botanical and historical lesson about chocolate as we roasted, peeled and ground our beans. Then we made, and tasted, some historically-based chocolate drinks before pouring some already prepared chocolate into molds with whatever additional flavorings we chose. We picked up our chocolate creations later in the day and they were yummy. Ivan did a great job leading the class. He was informative and also very funny.The other people working in the shop were equally pleasant and helpful. And, you can buy just about anything in the shop that pertains to chocolate!

Even better Than I imagined!!. Spent three weeks in Cusco trying to find this place. Finally found it in an out of the way area on my second last day. Found out what times the chocolate making classes were the following day and was there early waiting to sign up. It was a Sunday morning and unusually slow. There were only two others in our chocolate making workshop. (Usually there's a crowd). What a great experience!! We got to make chocolate starting with beans and ending with our creations. We were able to take pictures, ask lots of questions, get lots of answers and learn lots of history about chocolate and the chocolate industry in Peru and world wide.I'm so happy I finally found the museum. It is well worth looking for if you're in Cusco.My treats are yummy too!!!

Free, quick and tasty!. Some friends and I were wandering around Cusco looking for something to do which wouldn't break our limited budget or take up the whole day. We stumbled upon the museum and, since it was free entry, we decided to have a look. To be honest, I thought it was just going to be a glorified shop but I was pleasantly surprised. We were greeted by a charismatic tour guide who gave us some info (that was actually interesting) and loads of free samples ranging from chocolate tea to chocolate jams. Everything was delicious and after about 40 minutes we left with some reasonably priced chocolate and chocolate tea (which I strongly recommend). We even returned later to the cafe for some drinks and brownies. Overall, if you're in Cusco and need to kill an hour or two, definitely visit 'Choco Museo'.

Enjoyable Experience!. Had a great experience with the class From the Grain to the Bar that was very funny and very instructiveI made a reservation online and they answered promptly and very efficientThe place is full of people, they have a coffee shop, many things to buy and of course, chocolates everywhere.The people working there are very friendly. The house is one of the few remaining in Cusco, love it

Good treats.. Not much of a museum but there were interesting posters on the wall re chocolate. The treats were the highlight for us: hot cocoa to die for; many varieties to choose from. Sit in one of the little balconies over looking the square to take a nice break from being a tourist!

Great workshop - really enjoyed it. This is a great activity to do in Cusco if you're acclimatising, or have a day spare. As others have said, there's not a lot there to look at if you're not doing the workshop, although the cafe is very nice and does a great chocolate milkshake. The workshop was fantastic. Quite easy to book onto, although we missed one because it was full, so it is worth booking in advance. The lady who led it was really fun and spoke perfect English. We followed the production process right through from bean to finished product, and it was very hands on. We sampled a few Quechuan and Mayan chocolate drinks, some of them nicer than others! Then we made flavoured chocolates with loads of ingredients available to flavour our own chocolates. We then picked them up later on once they'd set. They were amazing! I thought it was very good value and definitely worth it. We enjoyed it so much we booked on their cookery classes for the next day.

ChocoMuseo - chocolate making class. We were a bit dubious about this as we thought it would just be another thing set up for tourists but actually we loved it. It was so much fun and the chocolates we made were really nice (we had option of making dark chocolate or milk chocolate). We got to try cacao beans, different hot chocs and cacao tea and learnt some interesting things about cacao.Thank youDannielle and Pete

A way to spend a few hours in Cusco. My husband and I recently took the truffles class with Achilles. He was a fun and informative teacher. The class was well organized and we had a blast. Loved the chocolates we made too. Highly recommend taking a class. :-)

Fun distraction as you acclimate. This museum is more like a gift shop with a few displays to boot but that doesn't take away from the fact that the staff were wonderful, helpful and eager to please. A decent distraction for a few hours. We made reservations for the chocolate workshop (S.70 each) for the next day and spent approximately 2 1/2 hours learning about the cultivation and history of cocoa. Although advertised as a "make your own chocolate" workshop, this is really only the last 30 minutes and entails molding and decorating your personalized chocolate bar. The majority of time is making hot cocoa, cocoa tea, etc. Fun but a bit expensive.
Not worth the visit. This is not overly interesting, it is one room and a store. We missed the chocolate making session and without that there is really nothing else to do.

Great for a break!. We popped into the chocomuseo twice during our time in Cusco, both times for a snack. Both hot and cold chocolate drinks were delicious, the brownies, very filling and the crepes, generous. We bought a few souvenirs (lip balm, choco tea) too. Lovely place but a little on the expensive side.
