Great, informative and entertaining work shop!. Participated in the ‘beans to bar’ workshop with my husband in July while visiting Cuzco. We were afraid beforehand that it might feel too long and swallow up too much of our time, but luckily we were wrong.The workshop was extremely entertaining, informative and hands-on and our teacher was fantastic. We got to make chocolates with fillings of our choice and had a blast.Would definitely recommend for those looking for a hands-on activity while visiting Cuzco.

Forastero Tour organized by ChocoMuseo. A great experience was our visit in Huayopata, where we were hosted by Julia and Jose. They live with their children on a big farm surrounded with banana, coffee, orange plantation. After a delicious lunch we visited the "garden", tasted many exotic fruits and learned everything about the coffee process. The next day we visited Raul's farm, and we made chocolate from cacao beans. They are very nice people - don't miss the opportunity to meet them and see how is the real life of the peruvian people.

A way to know the local chocolate. This place is a good way to know how they make their local chocolate.They have a factory that you can look from the window or make a tour and make your own chocolate.At the store they have a good variety of local chocolate and a cafe.

Fantastic, Sign up to Make Your Own Chocolate. We had a great time here, it was very interesting to learn about how chocolate is made and the history behind it. I would recommend signing up for the class to make your own chocolate!

great museum but products are ok. fun/cute little museum... very good for kids!chocolate products are ok... not the best chocolate! But I must add that I'm very picky and been to switzerland... peruvian chocolat just isn't up to par!
Lots of fun. It was near Chicha where we had lunch so just called in out of curiosity. Yes, gimmicky and touristy but it also made you realise how important chocolate is here.

I expected more. It is not really a museum. You can watch a little movie about how they make chocolate and the have a tree with some more information. That's it! The hot chocolate and sweety things you can get are good though.

Great Service, Great Coffee and Great Chocolate. The choco museo is a touristy spot but the customer service was spot on. Really friendly waitresses that helped us with recommendations and some of the best coffee that we have had in south america!!

Afternoon of fun. My daughter, 10yo loved this, learnt all about the process, tried some of the process and made her own chocolate which does not taste bad. My husband and I took part as well we had fun.Great entertainment and educational, with the added benefit of your own chocolates to take with you.We booked this up in advance, I think there were disappointed visitors that were unable to take part, only 14 people at once, which is a good number.

Touristy, but with some good information. We had a little time to spare, so we dropped by the small site. It was really commercial and I don't think there was much of a connection between the Incas and Cacao plant. Still, I learned something and ate some free samples.

Superb little place, great experience.. We had a few hours to kill & read about this place in a guide book so gave it a go. We were pleasantly surprised, we had a few hours of informative & enjoyable chocolate making. We decided to do the chocolate workshop which is worth the money & you get to keep the chocolates you make at the end too. We had a really nice woman called Janet looking after us. She spoke both English & Spanish & was great at getting people involved. If you have a few hours spare in Lima, this place is worth a visit.

Fun chocolate workshop. My BF and I did the chocolate workshop in the Choco Moseo, it was very pleasant experience. Manuel the person who delivered the workshop in English was very nice and adduceded and even spoke some Hebrew. The price is pretty high - s/. 70 but worth it when you get the chocolate you mad.

chocolate lovers. This is a wonderful place for all chocolate lovers. You can taste and even make your own chocolate bar. There is a history of chocolate posted on the walls; chocolate tea samples and a light menu. Has a small balcony where you can sip hot chocolate and watch the activity in a plaza.

Enjoyed this treat!. We enjoyed this chocolate museum and had the make your own hot chocolate. Interesting. I recommend you do the class on how to make chocolate-- it looked fun but all the times we were available were booked so book through hotel or call early to get a time you would like.Delicious chocolate I am savoring the pieces still at home.

CHOCOLATE CENTRAL. This was my home away from home. Our group did the chocolate making class and we were given a deep look into the history of Chocolate, and it's influence and history in Peru. We learned how it is grown, and turned in to the chocolate bar you and I enjoy today through a fun and interactive presentation. The chocolate masters also speak english. We made 2 chocolate drinks that apparently the Incas drank, and we made our own chocolates using the variety of molds, toppings and varieties of chocolate they had. the whole experience was probably 2 hours. The museum was cool too, and had cool exhibits and interactive spreads. The shop was really cool, too and had quality products. Highly recommend for the whole family.
Fun activity!. We visited as part of a tour! Got to make chocolate to take home! Staff made the activity fun, but also informative! Lots of unique items made from chocolate in the gift shop!

chocoholic. We spent a great hour or so at the ChocoMusco learning about chocolate. It was very informative and nicely presented displays.We took the time to have Mayan chocolate and a chocolate crepe while watching the celebrations in the plaza.We also bought some chocolate tea to take back to Vancouver.

Very nice workshop. I did a chocolate praline workshop and liked it a lot. The women who conducted it spoke good english, was entertaining and explained nicely what we were doing. It was not quite as interactive as I had thought, but it was still enough to do. The chocolates you make are amazing, for that they provide good quality ingredients. All in all two hours well spent at an acceptable price.

don't bother if you're not doing the chocolate making workshop. We got a little spiel about cocoa beans from an employee on arrival but this is not a museum, just a chocolate shop/café that offers chocolate making workshops.

Excellent chocolate learning.. Amazing class. Take it!!!! Gladys is THE best!!!!! The class is informative and funny. Gladys is VERY knowledgable with good jokes and an amazing knowledge of chocolate!

Good chocolate, not much of a museum. We had a mocachino drink that was very good. There's a small amount of information, but I wouldn't call it a museum. There is a chocolate making class offered multiple times a day for 70 soles/person. We didn't do the class, but it might be neat.

Great if you like chocolate. We couldn't afford the chocolate making classes although they had been recommended to us by a couple of friends so visited the free museum which was interesting and had a coffee and some chocolate in the cafe.  If you like chocolate it's definitely worth visiting.

A fun and nourishing stop. This is really not a museum. It is a store that offer classes. Posters with essential information hang in all the rooms. The staff of amiable young women are enthusiastic and extremely generous with their time. We had two different types of hot chocolate and both were exquisite. A fun and delectable experience.

A must-do for the chocolate lover. We booked the two hour "from bean to bar"-workshop for 60 or 70 soles, and it was worth every penny. In the workshop you will learn about different types of cocoa beans, make the chocolate drink the way the mayans and the spaniards used to make it (from scratch), and in the end you design your own chocolates which you then bring home. Having done the workshop you also get a 10 % discount off all the items in the shop and the restaurant. Any person who likes chocolate will like this.

more of a chocolate shop than museum. there is a small area with a display telling of the cocoa plant, but it really is a chocolate shop, eatery, and cooking lessons where you make truffles from scratch

A nice Surprise. We ducked in here to get out of the rain and found it a nice surprise. We were able to watch a chocolate making workshop as we sipped a chocolate drink and shopped for chocolate to take with us. While it is not a "go out of your way to find it" place, if you are in the area it is a nice place to take a break. Sit and have a chocolate drink and leave with something for later.

CHOCOLATE HEAVEN: EAT, DRINK, LEARN, SHOP!. Whether you take a chocolate making class, walk through the museum exhibits or enjoy the Sunday Chocolate Brunch, you MUST visit ChocoMuseo if you are in Cusco! EAT/DRINK: Take a moment when you walk in the door and just inhale! Now look around at all of the chocolates and you'll understand why the staff here is so happy and helpful; who wouldn't be happy surrounded by chocolate, and customers who are happy because they are eating and drinking chocolate? You'll be given a little intro to the place and offered something you've probably never tried - chocolate tea made by steeping the cacao husk pieces in hot water. Sounds weird, but I like it. There are chocolates to sample and you can enjoy a Chocolate Pisco (a Peruvian brandy made from white grapes) tasting. There are several kinds, I got the Passion Fruit version and I'm still enjoying it! If you buy some to take home, pack it carefully; they will wrap the cap well with strong tape, but you may still lose a bit of the liquid.The Café menu is great; lots of chocolate temptations to enjoy at the tables set up throughout the facility. Chocolate fondue with fruit, chocolate lollipops to stir into your coffee or lattes, brownies, pastries, chocolate dipped frozen fruits, make-your-own-hot-chocolate (Mayan or European style) and all kinds of yummy coffee and chocolate drinks! We ordered a lovely sampling of 3 chocolates to taste with our latte for about $3 and sat at a table overlooking the little plaza. The café is a wonderful way to relax and enjoy the view of one of the prettiest plazas in Cusco. LEARN: Tour the exhibits and watch a good little film if you'd like to learn about how cacao becomes chocolate; it doesn't take long and I found it pretty interesting. The museum and tastings are all free of charge. They also offer a couple of chocolate making classes (about 2 hours), a "Bean-to-Bar" and a truffles and ganache class. I didn't have the time, unfortunately, to take one, but the students who were seemed to be having a great time and producing impressive results! These workshops only cost a little over $20 and you end up with about $10 worth of chocolates to take with you!SHOP: Now, these are my kind of souvenirs! All kinds of chocolates, bags of cacao husk bits to make tea with, nibs, 100% cacao paste to use for making chocolate, chocolate infused Piscos, cacao balls for making hot chocolate, cacao powder, cacao butter for skincare, aprons, earrings and a host of chocolate themed crafts...this is a really fun place to shop for gifts - for small, medium or big budgets!Check it out; you'll be glad you did!

Nice place for a hot chocolate. Somewhat mis-branded as a museum, ChocoMuseo is actually a combination of chocolate shop, cafe, chocolate-making kitchen classes, and a series of educational displays, the latter representing the "museum" aspect, and in my view comes very much in fourth place in terms of what the ChocoMuseo has to offer. If you're looking to buy authentic Peruvian chocolates either to eat or for gifts, you probably won't find a better place, although it does very much cater for the tourist market. There's a very wide selection of flavours available. Beverage-wise, in the cafe area at the back, the chocolate tea is interesting, but the best drink on offer must be the hot chocolate. Try to bag a seat, if you can, on the first floor balcony for a nice view over the adjacent square and up the hill towards Sacsayhuaman. However this may be easier said than done as the cafe area is quite small and - at least on our visit - the ChocoMuseo was extremely crowded. The entrance is also a little hard to find: you have to go into a courtyard full of small tour operator kiosks and up some stairs.
Good fun. My friend did chocolate making class and loved it. Shop got lots of yummy things. Nice way to spend couple of hours.

Bean to bar workshop. Very enjoyable workshop. It's very interesting learning about the chocolate making process and getting to make your own. The teacher made it happy and fun for everyone and the singing wasn't as bad as I thought haha.The quality of ingredients is outstanding. Our chocolate tasted seriously amazing! If I had to give some constructive criticism I would say that the room needs to be closed off, as during the beginning of the session when the teacher was talking I could hardly hear what she was saying as there were so many tourists making a racket in the museum.

Forastero Tour: Highlight of our trip!. My sister and I loved the tour! Our guide, Abel, went above and beyond to ensure our comfort and safety. It was great to stay with Julia at her farm; she and her family were very welcoming. What a great opportunity it was to pick, roast, and grind our own coffee beans! For those who love to eat, this tour is perfect. Julia's cooking was some of the best food we ate in Peru. She cooks hearty healthy meals with all fresh ingredients. The next day, we went to Raúl's chocolate farm. Again, it was a once-in-a-lifetime experience to roast, peel, and grind our own chocolate. It was chocolate like we had never tasted before. We would also highly recommend doing the Machu Picchu tour extension. It was a great price, and we enjoyed our private tour with our guide. Finally, at the very end of the tour, we were able to visit the chocolate museum. Try out their cocoa tea! It's the best!! The staff was very friendly and helpful from start to finish. We highly recommend doing the Forastero tour!

If you like chocolate, and who doesn't . . .. Fun place on the southeast part of the main plaza that will surely satisfy every choco-holics craving. You can even make your own chocolate at a class offered three times a day (by appointment only and fills up quickly) to take home with you. Though anything made by customer will likely be consumed before leaving Cusco, if not the premises.

Tasty but not very informative. Not much of a "museum" more of a store with some history posted on the walls. Very nice selection of chocolate items, samples of chocolates and chocolate tea made from the husks of the cocoa beans. A good way to kill a little time, if you are a chocolate fan.

bean to bar great experience!. Signed up for bean to bar and had a great time! Very engaging experience and tasted great! Made choco drinks and are own bars! Loved the chocolate tea! If you can not fit the class in definitely try the chocolate breakfast!

Awesome insight in to the creation of chocolate. Did the "Bean to bar" workshop. Really got to see each step along the way. Was lots of fun and instructor kept a good humorous and fun atmosphere the entire time. Chocolates that I made turned out great and I ended up buying the chocolate tea, it was so good!

Tasty but full of tourists. I ended up here on the back of a free walking tour of Cusco and, hardly to my surprise, the place was full with other gringos. The staff did their best to accommodate everyone and the people doing the chocolate making classes seemed to be having a great time. The main body of the building is indeed a shop trying to sell everything from cocoa tea (not coca), to solid bars of the good stuff. And it is good. I don't quite see why it's in Cusco apart from as a place for the owners to make money. Considering this as it's main reason for being, our 'guide' didn't have a great level of English, and the talk was a little short. I'd give it another shot though, but not good enough to warrant a 'very good'. However, the produce is high quality.

Chocolate class was fun. I had been to the ChocoMuseo in Guatemala, so the information on display was nothing new. My friend and I had wanted to do the truffle class, but nobody responded to our emails. We were able to register for the "From Bean to Bar" class in person a day ahead. It was fun, informative, and reasonably priced. Gladys, the person who led the class, was good natured, and seemed to really enjoy her work. I'd recommend this class, it's a fun break from all the churches!

Loved the CHOCOLATE MUSUEM. Really cool store/small museum. You can take a tour inside and classes to see how they make the chocolate. We looked around and bought chocolate coffee which is pretty good but they also have chocolate tea which was amazing.

Very interesting Museum of Chocolate (really a store), but you can learn something. We went in and a "docent" quickly described the full layout. They served us free chocolate beans (much better than I thought they would be), and chocolate tea samples. This is not to be confused with coca. There is a short movie on chocolate making and a few displays. They sell nice affordable gifts of chocolate. A very quick place that is interesting and educational.Unfortunately we didn't have time for a cooking class.

Do the chocolate making class. Out of my traveling group, only myself and one other person was interested in the chocolate making class so we ditched the others one evening to take the class here. I have to say, this was definitely their loss. This class was one of the highlights of my trip to Cusco coming in only behind hiking the Inca Trail and Macchu Picchu. The class was very informational, teaching us lots about how cacao is grown as well as the history and evolution of chocolate. As part of the "evolution of chocolate" bit of the course, you get to try three different drinks that represent how chocolate was originally consumed by the pre-Columbian cultures. After going through the steps of transforming a cacao seed/pod into chocolate, you get to make and flavor your own chocolate bars. After the class, you have to come back at least 45 minutes later to pick up your chocolate. We were a bit concerned about this as technically that meant the store would be closed before our chocolates were ready and we were leaving at 5 the morning to hike the Inca Trail. But turns out, if you take the last class of the day (4pm) you can come back after hours to pick up your chocolate. I believe they gave us until 7:30 that evening to return. Our class was filled with people in the young adult age range, but I think that was just coincidence as I'd recommend this class for people of all ages, including children. If we had had more time in Cusco, I would have come back for one of their truffle making courses. That is how awesome this experience was. If you like chocolate, consider a class here on your list of "must do" things in Cusco!
Very interesting and lots of fun!. Janet was a gracious and delightful hostess!! We enjoyed her workshop and also the chocolate we made! This is a must do visit in Lima!

Sweet Little Museum. Great place to stop and learn more about this favorite plant and the folklore attached to it! Great tidbits of information regarding how it grows, the history of familiar products such as coca cola and more are outlined and made fun.

Great way to spend some time. I did the chocolate making workshop here with my 7 year old yesterday and I would highly recommend it. We had a good laugh, learnt a lot and came away with our own made chocolates! !! I advise putting Chile in if you don't want the kids to eat it all!!??

make a reservation if you want to make chocolate. We were recently in Cusco and attempted to attend a class at the chocomuseo; unfortunately they were fully booked. We did enjoy hot chocolate and chocolate fondue.

A Chocoholics Dream. We reserved our class several weeks prior to our trip.We originally scheduled the 1pm class but I requested to change to the 4pm class. The email response was quick and the change was made with no problems.As soon as you walk in, the smell of chocolate fills the air...heaven! The class was completely booked.They are very knowledgeable about the history of chocolate, right down to the variety of cacao trees and seeds. The instructor was fun and kept us interested.We were able to taste Cocoa tea (made from the roasted cacao shells) and two different types of cocoa during our class.In the end, after the seeds are roasted, shelled, ground up, you get to make your candy.We did truffles and were able to choose between dark or milk chocolate as well as a variety of things you can mix into them.If you are planning a trip to Peru, take this class. it's well worth the money and you get to take your chocolate home to share...if you don't eat it all first :)

Really fun day!. My partner and I participated in the chocolate making course and had so much fun. The staff are really friendly and teach you so much about the history of chocolate and how to make some delicious treats. I'd definitely recommend doing this course, great for all ages.

Chocolate Heaven. We came across the ChocoMuseo as we explored the side streets and squares just off Plaza de Armas. Whilst we didn't take part in a workshop we did have a delicious cup of hot chocolate and shared a very chocolatey Brownie, before picking up some supplies of choclate bars to take with us on our travels. You can see the chocolate museum on the first floor above Regocijo Square, the entrance however is off the adjacent side street in to a quiet courtyard and then up the stairs. To seek it out for some delicious chocolate, even if you don't have time to take part in a workshop.

Great little place. My hubby and I did the chocolate making workshop on out first day in Cuzco while acclimatising.Really knowledgeable tutor and we came away with two bars of chocolate each as well as a history of how it was made and various samples of each stage of the process. It worked out around £15 each which was pricy for Peru but not a bad way to kill some time

Hair in my chocolate. . The museum was a neat way to spend 20 minutes or so, so I decided to splurge on an expensive "special edition" bar of 100% cacao. I'll say special edition- I found at least two hairs it in. Disgusting!! I'm hoping they'll refund as I'm turned off from wanting more from there. Buy your chocolate elsewhere...

Tourist trap. We were taken here on a free walking tour of Cusco and decided to come back to sample some of the treats on offer. How disappointing. This place doesn't know what it wants to be. Part museum, part cooking class, part cafe, large part expensive shop, it is far too crowded and random and to top it all off the chocolate goods are very average. The 'make your own' Mayan hot chocolate was nice, but the brownie was awful - dry, tasteless, more like a day old cake, no density to it at all. We have visited Chaqchao is Arequipa many times and were pining for their treats while in this tourist trap. Go to Chaqchao if you're in Arequipa - brownies twice the size, cheaper, and full of real cacao nibs and choc sauce. As for this place, don't waste your money.

Interesting enough displays, largely a shop. Worth a 15-30 minute visit. We did not make our own chocolate but we did take in the sites and learned a bit about how cacao is grown and processed to make chocolate. They have a nice little gift shop that features all things chocolate (including condoms!) but the prices are really high.The people making the chocolate seemed to be having fun; our time was limited so we did not participate but I could see it being a fun activity for a family or those who have a particularly affinity for chocolate.

Fun!. I have to confess that I was skeptical but decided to visit anyway after reading the TripAdvisor reviews. We only did the free visit but it really was quite fun. Definitely worth 30-60 minutes of your time while wandering around Cusco. And the choco tea was great.

A great experience that was very educational and great tasting!. We had the pleasure of learning the process of making chocolate and all along the way tasting our progress. The entire visit took almost two hours but we were never bored. Bring plenty of muscle as you will cook, grind, mix, blend and eventually eat your work. Great for kids and adults. Only visit if you like chocolate!!

Great Chocolate. This museum was right across from our hotel. They had classes that you could sign up for. They offered chocolate Tea. I bought chocolate bars and chocolate covered orange pieces. Excelllent!!!

Fun and Educational. Our family (kids 12 and 14) really enjoyed learning to make chocolate. The instructor was easy to understand and had a great sense of humour. I was impressed at her ability to tease the 10 or so Israeli, Dutch and Canadian tourists knowledgeably. I was surprised to learn that we could take some raw beans and within 30 minutes of roasting and grinding be able to make a delicious hot chocolate drink. Making chocolate bars to take away was even better.

Not what I expected??. I feel awful because it seems like everyone loved this museum! I wanted to love it but I think I had different expectations. First off, the great thing is that it is free to enter but I felt a little claustrophobic as there were 30 other people and it is a very compact space. We (my hubby and I) were immediately greeted by one of the employees and offered us some samples of their chocolate and chocolate tea. While we appreciated his enthusiasm, we were more overwhelmed by the number of people there and were expecting more of a museum. Perhaps I would have appreciated it more if I had the chance and time to take the chocolate making class but if you're short on time, I would bypass this excursion. It felt very much like a tourist trap.

A must-visit in Cusco!. I visited the Chocomuseo and took the 2 hour "bean to bar" workshop, where you get to take part in every process from peeling raw coco beans to making chocolate bars. The workshop is relatively small so you get to know the other participants, and the instructor was very good! The museum serves every kind of chocolate imaginary, from bars to hot chocolate to fondue to chocolate tea and liqeur. The exhibits are informative and engaging. This really is a must, and be sure to reserve a place in the workshop, because you risk it being fully booked if you don't. The 70 soles for the workshop are more than worth it, as you get to take with you the 4 chocolate bars you made yourself.

Very friendly. Plan ahead.. We stopped in here on our last day in Peru while killing time before heading to the airport. Unfortunately we didn't quite have enough time to do the 2 hour chocolate making workshop. But the staff was very friendly and gave us a little tour nevertheless, explaining the process. We sampled some chocolate tea, raw coco beans and finished chocolates. We purchased some chocolate bars at the end. The chocolate was ok not great. But it was a good way to spend some time for free.

Make time for the Choco Museo. We had heard about the Choco Museo and decided to pop in. We enjoyed it so much we took my parents back the next day. Some of us did a 2 hour bean to bar session and it was definitely worth the 70 Sols. You can wander through the displays and the products available make great gifts to bring home.I would definitely recommend making time to visit in Cusco or Miraflores, Lima.

Very fun and different experience. This was a great find! We did a chocolate making class which took about 2.5 hours. They taught us the whole process, from harvesting the cocoa bean to using each part for a component of chocolate. In the end you get to make chocolates to take home, flavored any way you choose. It was a fun experience for the adults, teens, and kids!

Great place, great food. The people were wonderful and very helpful. We took a chocolate lesson and it was GREAT. Not just the chocolate was good, but so was our teacher. I highly recomend going there even if you're short on time because they have a cafe and information on chocolate to walk through and samples.

Tasty place for a quick visit. Definitely worth a stop if you like free samples of various chocolate products! Also interesting displays and info on the history of cacao and chocolate. If we'd had more time, we would've tried one of the chocolate making classes.

Neat place to visit. We knew of the place before we went to Cusco so it was on our destination list. There is a separate store around the corner from the museum that we went to first. The actual museum is full of information and goods to purchase. They offer classes to make your own chocolate as well but we didn't have enough time during our stay. The cocoa tea is delicious as are the chocolates we sampled and purchased. As with most Peruvian businesses, they have several employees around that offer samples and information about the store and its products and everyone spoke English very clearly. It's worth a visit while in the beautiful city of Cusco!

a good surprise. We accidently stumbled over a women handing out flyers for the ChocoMuseo.It looked very interesting so we decided to go there.The museum it self with the very service minded crew gave a good "look into" of the world of chocolate.But even better they held work shops of different kind. we took part in one regarding the choco bean transformation to chocolate it was very rewording and great fun, can really recommend this working museum.

Wonderful workshop!!!. We did the beans to bar workshop and it was great! Really fun interactive experience of actually roasting, shelling beans, crushing to a paste, etc. I was surprised at how much chocolate you get to actually make a bring home with you - for 2 people we got 12 bite size pieces and two big bars (all with nuts and other ingredients we chose). You also get to try different drunk during the class- tea from the cocoa shells, Mayan hot chocolate, and European hot cocoa, all great. For the hour after the class waiting for the chocolate to harden, we got a few delicious snacks in the cafe and bought some more chocolate to bring home as gifts. (You can also come back anytime before closing to get your chocolate.) Super fun different experience!

Educational and delicious. A small museum, you will still find yourself learning about chocolate (even though we have been to other chocolate museums such as Hershey). We recharged by ordering a snack and sitting on one of the three terraces at the museum, sipping one European and one Inca hot chocolate. They made a really cute crepe for my son's birthday.

Kids and I enjoyed this class tremendously! Got our money's worth!. This was a great learning experience for all of us and hands-on from start to finish!It could have been a little quicker (making the various forms of hot chocolate and during the initial presentation in the cozy area upstairs with the amazing cacao tree made by hand). For the first time, I felt like we got our money's worth and were not being taken advantage of and rushed out once we had paid. It was an EXCELLENT AND FUN class. The instructors seem to enjoy their jobs and are enthusiastic. :)Thank you!

Loved my chocolate workshop!!. Firstly Manuel our chocolate making expert was a wealth of knowledge!! The workshop was intersesting, funny and delicious!! I had a great time with the others in my group. I would highly recommend this workshop to anyone travelling to Cusco, two hours at a reasonable price and chocolate to take home!

A Cusco must!. The Choco Museo was a nice sweet stop on our two day tour of Cusco. Our Museo visit was short but it was enough time to enjoy a cup of cacao husk tea and other sampling while taking in the view of one of Cusco's gorgeous squares. Had we planned accordingly, it would've been great to take a class.

Definitely worth a stop!. My wife is a chocolate lover, so we decided to take part in the 2 hour chocolate-making class. It was so fun! We learned all about the chocolate making process, got to try 3 different chocolate drinks (the European chocolate was DELICIOUS), and then made our own chocolates to take home. The instructor (Manuel) was great- very funny and energetic. It was really an enjoyable experience and we highly recommend it!

Try Peruvian Mocha. I am a chocolate fan. This museum is like a paradise. Staff is VERY friendly and fun to talk to! They let you try samples of different cocoa items: jam, liqueur, chocolates, etc. It's very fun.Tip: get an item they serve from the menu; it's not that expensive, and sit in a balcony for an AMAZING view.

Interesting facts and yum chocolate . Actually a proper museum (not just chocolate store) with really interesting facts. Great layout and really helpful staff. I had the coffee truffle which was delicious!!!

Delicious chocolate making class. What a lovely experience! The 2 hour chocolate class is well worth your time if you want to do something more unique and interactive than visiting the usual tourist sites. Gladys was adorable, informative, and had a great sense of humor that made the class a lot of fun. She also ran the class in both Spanish and English to accommodate all participants. Her English was great - very easy to understand. The class was interesting and delicious. And you walk away with the chocolate you make! Though it is a bit expensive, I highly recommend this class.

Super fun, super yummy cooking class. What fun! An hour at the local -- and massive -- market that sells everything from flowers to flours, fruits and fruit juices, meats, nuts, mushrooms....you name it. With recipes in hand, we fill up our bags with fresh ingredients for the cooking class featuring traditional recipes. Back at the kitchen, there's all sorts of preparation activities: washing, dicing, slicing. Maracuya sours are fun and delicious. We make creamed corn and lomo saltado. While we eat dinner the chef prepares a decadent fruit and chocolate fondue. On Sundays, because the market closes early, we shopped at the market from 2:00 to 3:00 and cooked and ate from 6:30 to after 9:00. A fabulous way to experience, food, fun and Cuzco. Loved it!
Good visit. If you have time must see. History of Chocolates, can try samples and shop. You could sign up for a lesson too.

Most fun museum in Peru. We thought it might be a worthy stop while looking for things to do for our 2 days in Cusco. Turned out that this was the most fun experience I had there!They have a 2 hour make-your-own-chocolate class, which is about S./ 60 but so worth it. You learn about the history and get to be hands-on with the chocolate-making process, culminating in creating your own chocolate pieces with various flavors that you get to take home. The woman who taught the class is very funny and keeps it entertaining as well!This is a must-see. It's near the Plaza square, and there is also a small cafe where you can order chocolatey-type foods and drinks, and you can also get a taste of some free chocolate alcohol or tea. I'm so glad we didn't miss this!

Delicious and fun!. Our tour guide recommended this to us on our free day in Cusco and it was so worth it! The admission is free since the inside is the store with their chocolate and little plaques around the building talking about the history, which was very interesting since I knew nothing about Peruvian chocolate, but I think you had to pay for the tour. If you do have the opportunity to do the tour, do it!! The introduction was more about the history and seeing a real cocoa tree, and afterwards you spent about 1.5 hours making chocolate drinks and your own chocolate. I was more interested in making our own chocolate than the drinks because I wasn't very fond of the drinks. Making your own chocolate was one of the best experiences out of our whole trip though -- you get to pick from milk or dark chocolate and what kind of template you want (little chocolate balls, big "jumbo bars", different shapes), and then there's about 20 different toppings including oreo, M&Ms, peanuts, raisins, sprinkles, etc. I highly recommend this to anyone visiting Cusco, especially if you love chocolate!

YUMMY!. If you like chocolate. This is the place for you. There are two of them one in Lima and one in Cusco. We visited the one in Cusco. It's located on the second floor inside a building with a courtyard. It is short walk from Qoricancha or the main square in Cusco. I believe the admission is free all of the time. Inside you will find workers making chocolate you can buy. They also offered free chocolate tea. I found it to be delicious. They have a menu that offers a variety of chocolate drinks and other foods. The museum is not very big, but it offers a lot of information about the history of chocolate. I found it to be a highlight of our trip. AWESOME chocolate! :)

Great educational trip for kids.. My 10yr old daughter and I visited and took part in the 3hr (ish) chocolate bar making session. My daughter loved it. It was a little expensive, and we obviously weren't able to make chocolate bars using the cocoa beans that we toasted at the beginning of our session, but it gave us a good idea of the entire process. Got to try a few free samples. Our choccy bars powered our inca trek! Was also a lively place to have a drink and sit on the balcony overlooking one of the Squares. Gotta say,that there wasn't much to dislike about cusco at all. You could dit by dustbins and still soakbup a beautiful viewM

Great Free Attraction. If you are looking for a break from walking around the Central City, this is a good option. Staff are friendly and the displays are interesting. The attraction is free and they provide you with a complementary cup of cocoa. There is also a small cafe in back where you can purchase a selection of chocolate drinks and goodies. While the attraction is free, there are lots of chocolate related items to purchase in the museum and nearby gift shop. So if you are unlikely to avoid temptation, bring your wallet.

CHOCO loco. hey !!! if you want to taste a delicious chocolate how to make you own one that's the place to be in Cusco.Come and just chi lout in this place with a delicious Hot Chocolate how so great… please give me more moment like this… :-) also the service is really good the staff very friendly and give all the information you need to know about the cacao from Peru, in English in Spanish and also a little in French cheers guys for all the moment I have been in this place Buen Provecho ;)
Good service and interesting reading.. Nice museum. Exciting menu, though the original inka drink was with milk and sugar so they have cheated big time on that one

Friendly, interesting, tasty cafe, and great workshop (class). One can come here for the shop of chocolate products, or for the small cafe of chocolate drinks and sweets, with its its windows open to the square below, or to take classes (with a fee). I have done all the above and recommend any of them. Note: although there is a small shop on the first floor around the corner, the main Choco Museo is on the second floor (and I don't know if there are any elevators in the building). The workshop class is about 2 hours long and costs about 70 soles ($25). The docent teaches the class (3 in my group) how the cacao grows and is harvested and then the class becomes a hands on endeavor. We tasted raw beans (with a damp, white, watermelon flavored coating) and then peeled and roasted a portion. After that, she made three different cocoa drinks for us: tea made from the shells (gentle and tasty), a Mayan recipe, with chili peppers, and a traditional Spanish recipe, with sugar and milk. Next, we saw how the chocolate beans are processed to make a delicious chocolate puree for cooking. Each of us chose either 42% or 70% chocolate, a plastic tray of shapes, and mixed our chocolate with a variety of toppings. My husband, who is by no means a cook, loved this experience. While we waited for the chocolates to cool and harden, we enjoyed a delicious brownie and hot chocolate in the cafe. The shop also offers cooking classes (for dinner, not chocolate alone) which include a trip to the local market to select the ingredients. I have signed up for that, too, (120 soles, about $40). The shop is owned by a French company which has several other Choco Museos in the region, one in Lima and others in surrounding countries.

ChocoMuseo. If you have young children and they love chocolate, take them here. It was a free educational tour on the cacao bean in Peru, how it grows, and how they make it into chocolate. My children even got to take cacao beans home to show their classmates. They have a chocolate menu which you can choose to either order from or make yourself. My children made their own hot chocolate and were very excited. I tried Cacao Tea for the first time and liked it so much I brought some home with me. They have a website where you can order from. They also have classes you can sign up for if you are spending anytime in Lima where you can learn to make any number of chocolate goodies. The staff spoke English well and were good with kids.

Loved the chocolate cooking class!. Visited for free samples and some chocolate history education as part of a Cusco free walking tour, then stayed on for a 2hr chocolate making course. Cost was 70sol per person, but we got a 5% discount with the 'D card' given to us as part of the walking tour. The class runs daily at 11am, 1.30pm and 4pm and goes for about 2hrs. Manuel was our head chocolate chef for the class, and he took us through the interesting history of chocolate, cacoa facts, and the steps of making chocolate, in a really entertaining, fun way. His English was great, as was his sense of humour, so we got along and could understand him well. During the 2hrs, we got hands on with roasting and grinding cacao beans, got to taste different chocolate products throughout, including a traditional Mayan spicy chocolate drink (which we helped to make), and we got to get creative with pouring chocolate and other ingredients into our own chocolate moulds at the end of the class. The delicious smell of being in this museum/cafe/shop/workshop kitchen really made me wanna eat chocolate, so, luckily, we got to pick up our own hand-made 120g of chocolate 1hr after the class (when it had set), and I couldn't wait to try it! If you're a chocolate lover, or just wanna do something a bit different, I would highly recommend this class! Also, if you just want to buy a chocolate treat or snack, the brownies, hot chocolates, and fruit covered in chocolate all looked amazing!

Not a lot to see, but its free and the staff are friendly. We visited late in the day when there were only minimal samples available for tasting. Desptie that the staff were friendly and did their best to add interest. There were too many static displays that required you to read. I would have prefered interctive or more visual aids - and of course more samples.

The free sample brought us in and we stayed for a chocolate lunch!. Great place. A highlight of our trip. Take the chocolate class (about $20); it is fun, entertaining, informative and you get to make and take home your chocolate goodies! We went back on the last day of our trip for one more chocolate splurge.

Stay for the hot chocolate. While the museum is tiny, it is free and the staff is friendly. They give you free cocoa tea to sip while you wander around. They offer an amazing hot chocolate where you assemble yourself from a small bowl of melted rich dark chocolate, a pot of steaming milk, and spices. We tried the honey with chili, which was amazing sipping by the balcony overlooking the plaza. Definitely coming back for the chocolate workshop next time we are in town.

learned so much about the nature & history of chocolate. Came here twice. First time was just to browse the goods and we ended up getting a drink / afternoon snacks. I had a hot chocolate where I was given hot milk, melted dark chocolate, honey, and chili powder to assemble myself. It was very good. Although the milk tasted different than back in the US ..... which is typical I think. Milk tastes so different all over the world. My friends had the fruit dipped in chocolate. We all enjoyed what we ordered. The second time I came back with one of my friends for a chocolate workshop where we learned about the nature of the cocoa tree / plant, its history, and the basic principle of how the beans are harvested and processed into the form that we know and use. Most everything was hands on and we got to "make" our own chocolate to take home. It costs 70 Soles per person to take the workshop. All in all very interesting and educational. I loved it!! The lady who conducted our workshop made it really fun too. Really recommend taking this workshop.

Noe a Museum. This was an optional excursion for the tour I was on. I wasn't too excited about yet another museum, but the chocolate making activity sounded fun. This turned out to be the perfect afternoon diversion. It really is not a museum. They have some pictures on the walls and a sample cocoa tree in one room but that is it for the museum part. What they have is a chocolate candy making kitchen where you learn to make chocolate candies from raw beans to the finished product. What fun and I had my own home made candies to take home with me.

Fun workshop. We had a great time at the "From Bean to Bar" workshop, lead by Manuel! He was very enthusiastic and engaging. A good way to spend 2.5 hrs, and sample lots of different chocolate products! Staff in the store was also very friendly and helpful.

ChocoMuseo. Small museum in a couple of rooms - more a cafe setting. They gave a free sample of chocolate tea and some liqueurs and we sat on the balcony and enjoyed. This is a good place to buy nice chocolates there to take home to friends and family.

Chocolate making class is great. Just like someone else on here said, my friend and I got to Cusco and were acclimating for a day before going on the Salkantay Trek. We went on a random city tour that left from the Plaza de Armas where someone told us about the Choco Museo. I agree with other reviewers that the store itself isn't anything amazing, really just an interesting chocolate shop, but we happened to get there right before they were doing a chocolate making class which was a lot of fun. Technically, you don't make your own chocolate because that takes a day, start to finish, but you do all the prep and finish off a batch they have waiting for you. You'll learn a lot of cool stuff about chocolate, have a great time and leave with some personalized snacks.

not a big deal. They sell chocolate, hot coca etc, with some classes in chocolate making, but this is hardly a museum, just a glorified store for chocolate. they were all about selling their products.

Fun chocolate workshop. While acclimatizing, my partner and I thought it would be a good idea to spend the afternoon on an easy activity. A chocolate workshop fit the bill perfectly. The workshop leader took us through the process from a raw bean to a making some chocolate bars/bonbons. We enjoyed seeing and doing parts of the process while get different cocoa drinks that were typical for different people (the Aztecs, Europeans, etc.), and also ending up with some self made chocolate to munch on later. There are workshops three times a day 11:00, 1:30, 4:00. We didn't reserve in advance and you probably can get in at one of the time slots.They also offer cooking workshops (I didn't see it on the website, but they had it on a bulletin board in the workshop area), which could be fun.Nice way to spend a couple of hours.

Very interesting and informative. This was a great place to spend and hour learning about the history, nature and processing of the cocoa bean. We weren't aware of the size of production of cocoa products in Peru. The entrance is free, there are free samples of the tea, spirits and jams that they produce and they have a cafe attached to get yourself a hot chocolate etc. worth a visit. They also have a shop selling jewellery, snacks, tea etc all product of the cocoa beans.

nice place. it´s a cozy nice place, with interesting goods like chocolate-and-apple and chocolate-and-strawberry jam. They also have a two hours course in which you prepare your own chocolate (but i didn´t do it). the museum is for free, so it´s worth the visit, even though it´s quite small and doesn´t feature soooo much information. and if u feel like, u can taste some goods and buyit or noit....

Best thing we did in Cusco. First, it should be known that this is more chocolate shop with some interesting plaques on the wall. Get past that and you'll be great. The plaques are really interesting, giving a lot of history of chocolate and information on its production. I'm not a huge museum person (this is the only one we visited in Cusco), but I found it fascinating. The highlight, though, was that we decided to come back the next day and do the 2 hours chocolate class. Best time we had in our 2 days in Cusco. They gave some more information on history and production, then let you go through some of the steps of production. There were many samples of teas and hit chocolate which were all great, and of course they then let you pour some into molds and bring it home. Considering the cost of the chocolate, the value of what you take home almost pays for the class. Can't say enough about how great a time we had. Plus their chocolate is organic and fair trade. Not to get on a high horse, but do some research on child slavery in the chocolate trade and you'll never buy a Hershey bar again. The fact that these guys are using high quality raw material and doing almost all the work in house is reason enough in my mind to support them as much as possible.

Fun diversion. we stumbled into this place and ended up taking the 2 hour chocolate making class. Totally fun and interesting to learn about cacoa and the origins of the chocolate bar. Also got to taste great chocolate. Fun diversion from Inca ruins and typical sights. The instructed was very knowledgeable and we enjoyed our experience.

Great with delicious treats. Did this museum on my free day, located near the square. Free admission.Front is where you buy the chocolate....the factory is around the back.I love chocolate so it was a pleasure to see how its made.Very informative session. And one can book a workshop to actually make chocolate.Loads of tasty treats and then you can buy some chocolate or even a hot drink and sit and admire the square from the 2nd floor. Lovely views.

Loved them in Guatemala, but better in Cusco!. It`s very interesting to see the different products they make out of chocolate. Didn`t like the chocolate spreads with fruits, but the chocolate flavoured tea is exquisit! definitely worth a visit while in Cusco.

learn all about chocolate. A delightful small museum on the main square. We learned about chocolate from the cultivation of the plants to preparation of the final product. You can also pour your own chocolates and buy products made from Peruvian chocolate. The chocolate tea was wonderful.

It's a chocolate place! How can you not visit.. Definitely worth a stop and visit. If you can take one of their classes, even better. We had a wonderful time learning about chocolate making and tasting. Even if you can't take a class, it is worth the stop for samples and education on cacao. Nice people, but a small shop/museum. special thanks to Elizabeth for her hospitality and wonderful conversations.
Chocolate making course was heaps of fun!. You learn a lot from the 2 hour course of how chocolate is made.very interesting, hands on and making our own chocolate was heaps of fun. Yummy too.

Free bits are good. Not so much the stuff you have to pay for.. We went here on the end of the free walking tour and yes it is mostly free. You are told about cocoa beans for a short while and invited to make chocolate. You are invited to sample cocoa tea, liquer and taste the beans. They make their money on selling goods though.I would not recommend buying anything. The chocolate is average and the brownies are basically cheap cakes.Average time here, would not go again.

If you have the time...visit.. A nice low key informative place with a friendly staff who are ready, and very willing, to answer questions and share information. And it's FREE including some samples!But when you leave go around the corner to the shop and buy some chocolate.
interesting and informative. Well worth a visit if only to find out the history of chocolate and try the free samples!Not so sure the chocolate is as nice as Cadburys :0)

Great way to spend a rainy or recovery day. After four days of intense sightseeing, climbing terraces, and exploring Machu Picchu, we were exhausted. Spending the afternoon in the "Beans to Bars" workshop was great. The class was informative and interactive. The instructor was fun and allowed everyone to participate. Not only do you get to make chocolate to take home, but you get choco tea, and two types of hot chocolate.

"delicious ending". One of the many museums that are within walking distance of the Plaza de Armas. The heavenly smell of chocolate welcomes you as you enter this small museum.After a basic introduction by a staff member, your left on your own to read the history and present day uses of the coca plant. Watching the women prepare the chocolates and being able to sample them was a delicious ending. Be prepared to visit the gift shop on the way out and purchase these fabulous chocolates to take home.

Free and delicious. The Museo has someone greet and give a brief overview of the cacao crop. The displays are OK and do a pretty good job of explaining the growing and extrication processes. I didn't have time to stay for the 2 hour chocolate making lesson. It was too nice outside. It would be a great rainy day activity though.

Fantastic!!. My friend and I really enjoyed our experience. It was a very nice attraction with not only great tasting and varieties of chocolate, but also fantastic service and staff. We were impressed by Janet, Gladys, and Elizabeth. They were friendly and charming. We look forward to coming back again and highly recommend checking it out!

Kind of generic. This place is fine, but the name is misleading. It's not really a Museum. It's more of a chocolate store, with great marketing and some educational items on the walls. It's not sloppily done or anything. The educational material is actually very interesting, from the history of chocolate to the steps in the manufacturing process. The fake cacao tree is neat too. My wife did not care for the free sample of chocolate tea, but I thought it was interesting.Ultimately though, it's a cafe. The desserts are probably great, but we only bought a couple small truffles. They were both good. The classes on making your own chocolate look fun too, but I didn't want to spend hours doing that when I was on vacation in Peru. It's fun enough to spend an hour or so. Probably better if you've got the money and calories to spend on dessert.

lots of educational fun. Great little museum. We learned all about the cocoa bean from start to finish. We roasted them, ground them, and mixed them. At the end, we were able to make our own chocolates, from a variety of molds and about 30 different flavours. The tour takes about 2 hours and costs 40 soles per person.

Great smell and tasty chocolates. Well established, organized. They offer chocolate workshop, which I haven't done it.Balcony gives a nice and pleasant view of the Regocijo square. Perfect for a hot chocolate.
Get some choco while you're there. Short visit but fun and informative. We also sampled some of their chocolate bonbons, they were good. It's a nice place for a coffee break.

Great fun!. Great fun and actually learnt loads about chocolate. The whole experience is interesting, you get to try lots of things and the learning is very hands on. Making your own chocolate is great fun and something different to take home to family.

Interesting. I must give kudos to the persons that thought of this attraction. It is mostly a chocolate business that has put up posters in different locations around the "store" to learn all things cocoa. The information is read while you walk around the different areas.Free cocoa tea is very good. They have a cafe, a kitchen that offers chocolate making workshops and cooking classes, a store there and a store down on the street level and around the corner. You actually see the store before you see the entrance to the "museum."Chocolate candies are pricey - and I can attest that the chocolate bars are fabulous!!! Their chocolate is much better than anything we have in the US. They do not use cocoa butter like our candy manufacturers and do not use as much sugar. Much more pure cocoa in the chocolate. YUMMMM!!!! I wish I had bought more.Walking around the "museum" is free, so it is interesting to learn about the Cocoa plant and processing the fruit into what e eat as chocolate.

Chocolaty fun. It was a late afternoon and a little cool so some hot chocolate sounded tasty. There is a little museum that explains about the origins of the cocoa been, Mexico, and a small demo kitchen. You can buy already made chocolates and hot beverages. We sampled some of the hot chocolate which was interesting how they served it to us. Cool place for a short stop for all chocolate lovers.

Chocotastic. You're made to feel very welcome in this little museum and chocolate centre, with the offer of free cacao tea as soon as you walk through the door. The staff are friendly and helpful, and the information boards are in Spanish and English, with good English translations. I really recommend joining one of the chocolate making classes - good fun, very informative and you get a bag of your own handmade chocolates to take home with you. Brilliant :-)
A fun place to get to make chocolate. I went to this museum as I was passing by, it was really cool and the tea was so amazingly delicious!!! You can also make your own chocolate! Try it out!

Surprisingly good. I had no idea what this would be, but if you like chocolate at all, you must go. It is free and has good exhibits about the processing of chocolate. Two windows have balconies where you can have you coffee and snack overlooking the plaza. It is a shop as well as a museum, but no pressure to buy, but I still bought a good bit. Great 70% chocolate bars in several flavors.

A must-visit for Cusco!. I enjoyed the whole experience! We did the chocolate creation tour and Gladys was a hoot! The environment was clean, warm and inviting. I now know where my chocolate comes from as well!

Fun place to visit. We visited the chocolate museum in both Lima and in Cusco. In Lima we took a chocolate making seminar and had a great time and now have a better appreciation of how chocolate is made. If you enjoy chocolate, I highly recommend taking a class. In addition, this a a good place to get gifts to bring home.

Pretty good crepes. In my opinion the museum part is not anything spectacular, but it's free entry so why not check it out? Better yet, they have a cafe area where I got crepes and coffee type drinks at least 3 times during my trip. They had these really great drinks that were made of mocha, pisco, and milk - delicious! They also have cool chocolate products for sale. I bought some chocolate bars and chocolate tea, which was available as a sample so you could try it beforehand. They also have things like chocolate jam, chocolate axe body spray, chocolate pisco, and a bunch more!

A great way to spend an afternoon. The museum part of this business is free and very well done. We then had a hot choc and bite to eat in the café which was excellent. We were able to book ourselves on to the next chocolate making workshop which started at 1:30 and lasted 2 hours. It was a great experience, crushing the cocoa beans and learning all about the different stages and processes. But the best bit was pouring the chocolate into moulds and flavouring them with an arrange of different tastes and textures. An hour later, after the workshop had finished, we were able to pick up our set chocolates and take them home!

There's nothing like chocolate. A small but interesting museum that combines both the history and cultivation of chocolate with a working chocolate confectioners. The staff speak English and the exhibits are also in English or English subtitled. Well worth spending half an hour and finishing off with a delicious hot chocolate drink or chocolate fondue.

Ended up buying more chocolate than ever and without regret!!. My family learned a lot about cocoa beans and chocolate! Many myths we had about chocolate were killed here and we learned to appreciate the use of 100% cocoa. We brought cocoa husks to make tea!! it's delicious.
Bit of a Waste of Time. Tourist Trap - go there warned. Not a museum, but an expensive coffee/chocolate shop. Better chocolate up the road from Jack's - better coffee just about anywhere

Lets be realistic. To start off, to clear up some confusion (at least some we had), was there are two locations, a shop on the 1st floor, and the "Museum", which is located on the 2nd, accessed via a street around the corner. Be advised that calling this place a "Museum" is a bit of a stretch.As a previous poster commended, this was a shop, that had some interesting factoids about chocolate.On our arrival we were greeted, and a "guide" gave us a quick tour (about 10 minutes) around the building, showing us some "exhibits" about the history of chocolate in the region, and some statistics about the consumption, We were given samples of some chocolate, some infused pisco, and a cocoa tea, After this, we browsed the shop and settled into one of the balcony tables that overlooked the plaza below. Here we did order some hot chocolate, which was the highlight of the experience. It came via a pitcher of hot milk, dish of chocolate ganache, and some spices (cinnamon, clove, chili pepper and honey) for us to assemble as we saw fit.We were informed about the chocolate classes they offer (it sounded like she said 70, but cannot remember if it was soles or US dollars.We spent about 30 to 45 minutes there, it was free (for the tour/tastings), and the hot chocolate was pretty good.It wasn't a bad experience and it's something to do while wandering around Cuzco.

really fun cultural experience!. My daughter and I took both the chocolate making class (beans to choc) AND the evening cooking class. Both were fantastic! I am a total chocolate snob. The choc. making class was really fun -- great to learn about growing & harvesting, differences in chocolates and actually making them. The teacher was fantastic and made the class really fun. Cusco cooking was also wonderful. We went to the market with our instructor on Sunday afternoon to shop for food. Really fun to go with her! and the actual cooking was great -- a fantastic cultural experience cooking very traditional, local food (no guinea pig, however). Our instructor was so nice & really fun. A must do in Cusco!

Educational, engaging and delicious!. Not to be missed, particularly if one has children ages 7 and up and 2 hours to spare on a chocolate workshop. Being in a chocolate producing region, a visit to this museum seems a very appropriate and educating experience. Well prepared and laid-out posters on the walls guide one through the rich history of chocolate. The friendly staff offers tastings of coco tea, coco infused pisco and a large variety of chocolate bars for purchase. The highlight, however, is the chocolate workshop, offered a few times a day and for which one needs to sign up ahead of time. During the workshop one learns hand-on all the steps of chocolate making, from cultivating, to roasting, peeling, grounding, mixing, cooling and shaping. Great fund and delicious for the small and grown-ups alike!

Chocolate Lovers' Heaven. There are flyers at the tourist information centre (off Plaza de Armas) about this museum about making your own chocolate - with discount. The museum is upstairs in an old mansion, overlooking one of the pretty squares in central Cusco. There are Interesting displays with detailed information about the history, production and marketing of cocoa/chocolate. You can also watch the experts make chocolate treats. There is also a cafe where you can indulge with sitting also on the balcony. However, sitting is fairly limited and was filling up quickly when I visited. A small shop stocks yummy goods.

Small museum, not much unless you're making chocolate. We stopped in at this small museum and spent about half an hour. There are some small exhibits about the farming and manufacturing process, as well as a place to purchase some cocoa beverages and food items. There as a group of 6-8 people making chocolate from scratch - this seemed to be the highlight of the place.

Nice little museum, but watch the bill!. My partner and I went to the ChocoMuseo a couple of times during our stay in Cusco. It gives you a good understanding of the South and Central American roots of chocolate, as well as how it is processed etc. DEFINITELY try a Mayan hot chocolate (s/9 at the time of writing) - yum yum! You order and receive food and drinks at your table, then go to the counter to pay. It all works on an honesty system, and sometimes the paper dockets with your order don't seem to migrate to the counter at all, so be careful when you are paying your bill. The second time we went, the couple in the queue before me had not paid for their food, only their purchases, and because my docket had not turned up at all, it took some time to convince the assistant that I had not ordered the couple's food as well as my own (ie that I should not have to pay for it).Otherwise, a lovely place and I highly recommend.

fun little side trip!. We had a couple of days in Cusco to acclimate to the altitude, and we found the Choco Museo. It was a nice little educational hour of chocolate and fun to see how it's made. We enjoyed making our own chocolates too-- tip: load up on the ingredients (like the nuts, sprinkles, etc...) to make it more enjoyable!

Good little museum!. First, I might be biased since I love chocolate so much. This is a little museum. The entrance is free. We went there just to have hot chocolate and buy a few things to bring back home. We ended up getting hot chocolate and chocolate cake. Let me tell you something...the chocolate cake was amazing. We also tried the tea and it was pretty good. We did this the day after Machu Picchu. We were looking for something relaxing to do and this was perfect. If you have kids or the time do one of their workshops. It looked really cool. The kids were having a lot of fun. Stop by if you have some free time while in Cusco.

We loved it!. My husband and I did a chocolate making class and a Peruvian cooking class here and they were both so much fun! The chocolate drinks here are delicious and the food we made in the cooking class was absolutely wonderful. I definitely recommend taking a class here if you have the time while in Cusco.

Less exciting than you might imagine!. A few displays but really a shop and café and a kitchen area where they will do a mini cookery course to teach people to make chocolate. Sadly we didn't have time for that. We sat at a café table for a while but never did get served.

How can you go wrong with Chocolate?. A variety of chocolate treats and products available to first sample in some cases and then purchase. I bought several unique chocolate based products. Worth the visit.

Good Chocolate History and Cafe. We walked into the Chocolate Museum after buying chocolate in the kiosk area below.The history depicted on the walls was very interesting if you area a chocolate lover only. I am and I liked it!After, we sat down and ordered a chocolate drink with spices, and a cup of coffee in a french press with 3 different chocolate candy flavors. JUST AWESOME! I had energy to spare until 6 pm that evening.We struck up a pleasant conversation with another traveler from australia thereafter and spent a brief and very pleasant hour there.DO IT!

Can't beat making and eating chocolate. This may be billed as a museum but all it comprises is 3 small rooms explaining the history, the process of chocolate making, and some interesting facts. Its free.It also has a cafe serving damn good hot chocolate and other foods.But the main attraction is the chocolate making class. Pay the S/70 per person for the 2 hour class. It is fantastic fun and very interesting. You will learn about how the cocoa brands are grown and fermented. But then you get to roast, shell, and grind the beans. Along the way you get to try chocolate tea and a couple of hot chocolates. You learn about how the chocolate is further processed before making your own. Pick a chocolate mould tray and from about 25 different ingredients ranging from cinnamon to Smarties to nuts, you make your own chocolates. Come back an hour later and they Arter yours to enjoy.We booked for the 11 am class and were the only two people. Maybe that was luck our the first class of the day gets you a more private experience.GREAT FUN

More museum than one name after regional drink ;). ...but not really a museum either--it's 1/3 informational/activity, 1/6 store, and 1/2 sit relax, eat, drink. Can't vouch for the chocolate activities that others appeared to partake in but the munchies are tasty and the view out over theplaza nice for enjoying beverage. Also a good place to grab a couple souvenirs; tried free sample of choco tea, ended up leaving with bag of it and some bars :) If you're not gonna eat or drink, or participate in a chocolate activity in the kitchen, you're looking at 15 minutes tops; enter from side of building and inside the plaza--steps up only to second floor, methinks.
Wonderful taste of Peru. Excellent location and a great place to learn about chocolate and the role it has in Peru. Great samples and fine opportunity to take a taste of Peru with you when you leave.

Chocolate is good!. Tis is a very small museum that gives you a brief explanation of where chocolate comes from. There is no charge to enter, so it's worth the 10 minutes you will spend there. If you miss it, you haven't really missed anything. I will say that they offer cooking classes for both chocolate and Peruvian cuisine. These are worth the cost ($40).

A sweet taste of Peru. We visited the museum and learned about the history of chocolate. Afterwards, we sat in the little cafe and had the most amazing drink....hot milk brought to you with chocolate, honey, chili and some other flavorings. Every cup was a different, but delicious taste

Nothing's better than chocolate!. My two sons and I had a wonderful time taking the Beans to Bars chocolate class. From roasting the beans to making our own chocolates, the experience was great and so very tasty!
Loved it!. You get to make your chocolate from scratch and eat it too! You learn about the history of chocolate and try chocolate tea, which was something new for us.

LOVED IT. For about 60 soles ($24) there is a beans to bar chocolate making class for 2 hours. At the end you make about 30 small chocolates with your own flavor combinations (about 20 flavors to play with). We loved their chocolate class so much we signed up for their Peruvian dinner cooking class!

Glorified chocolate shop. Three rooms to walk around with information on chocolate production in English and Spanish followed by a cafe to try some product.Nice view over the square but not much to it. A visit might take 20 minutes.

Great fun!. This was my second Choco Museo (having visited the other one in La Antigua, Guatemala). This is fun for couples, families or a group of friends. You'll learn about the history of chocolate, how it's processed and the many products made from chocolate. You'll even have a chance to make your own chocolates to bring home! Highly recommended.
Choco museo. We did the bean to bars workshop and had a great time learning about and eating chocolate. We also got to make our own pieces and eat them.

A little gem. This little museum was one of my favorite parts of my trip to Cusco. Welcomed by a very informed "chocolate specialist", we were given a brief synopsis of what to expect and where to find what-all while treated to a hot cup of freshly brewed cocoa tea! A must see to learn about the history of cocoa and current local efforts to establish free trade cacao farms-so interesting! A big bonus, my teenage son and husband also very much enjoyed the museum and we wrapped up our visit at the cafe indulging with so much cocoa knowledge-and chocolate fondue...argentine submarino...and...and a few other yummies.

Real yummy chocolate. I attended the chocolate making class in the choco museum before my flight back home. The class was fun and informative. Besides chocolate making, we also learnt how to make 3 choco drinks. The chocolate we made are very delicious. The class lasted for 2 hours and it took another hour for the chocolate get frozen. I think it's really good to do it relaxingly on the last day of the trip.

Yummy way to experience a Museum :). For 70 S the teacher went over how to make chocolate from where they cultivate the beans on the farm to actually molding and creating our own chocolate using over 15 different ingredients (oreos, salt, ginger, coconut...). We shelled the beans, roasted them, grinded them and had a blast doing it! THANK YOU Choco Museo, I had a great experience!

We took the cooking class and had a fun time. We went to the museum and also took the cooking class. We learned a lot in the class and really enjoyed making chocolate. It wasn't the best cooking class we've taken, but it was good.

Quick stop. The view of the Plaza Regocijo from the windows is nice. The information about chocolate is limited and somewhat difficult to access since about half of it is behind the tables in the cafe. The chocolate making seemed fun for families, but we didn't do it because it takes a full 2 hours.

Good place for edible gifts. We went here while acclimating to the altitude as an easy outting. It's small, but it is full of info. It was fun to get some gifts for family at home and learn things I didn't know about the chocolate making process.

Good, delicious fun. I didn't do the chocolate making course, but I found the museum interesting, with great information presented on the history and production of cacao in Peru. The chocolate is nice but the cacao tea is fantastic.
Charming place to visit or take class. We popped in here and it is well worth a visit. Educational and you can taste and buy chocolate. They also have classes everyday where you can make your own!

Fun little place. It was fun to get more information about chocolate and watch them make some treats. We enjoyed this visit, but it was just a quick stop, we didn't pay the extra to actually make chocolate.

Great little museum/cafe/cooking school.. Had a great time at this little museum. Very interesting to learn about the cocoa plant. The chocolate tea (brewed cocoa shell) is delicious as are the chocolates. I also rather enjoyed the pure chocolate kerns. The museum also houses chocolate - making classes and a cafe. The museum is free!

A cafe or a store but not a museum. I read a lot of good reviews of the ChocoMuseo and had some free time in Cuzco so I decided to check it out. There is no fee to look around but they do make up for it with the overinflated price of their products. There are some placards on the history of chocolate and some very nice views of Cuzco from the main sitting area. The chocolate making course is very informative but in the end this is not a museum. A cafe? Maybe. A store? Definitely. Don't get me wrong, the chocolate they sell is very, very good but you are paying for it. I can only recommend this for the very serious chocoholic. Other than that there are much better sites to spend your time in around Cuzco.

Pleasant Side Show. Let's face it, not many tourists would be in Cusco if it weren't for Machu Picchu. With all major attractions around the world other side shows open up to cash in on the tourism, & this is one one them. Yes, Peru is an important cocoa producer, so this business is relevant to Peruvian tourism. My family is in the chocolate business so it is always interesting to visit chocolate related businesses. Unfortunately, we came at a busy time so we were left out in the busy shuffle. The classes that they offered here were kind of pricey so we did not sign up. Also, we were heading to Hershey PA on a 3 day trip after Peru with a few chocolate making classes planned & paid for, so it would have made them redundant. Anyway, I'm sure it's a nice little stop at a less busier time. We did buy some chocolate nibs to take along. Not bad.

Great Free Museum. Great place to explore. We walked in and a nice gentleman offered us a cup on chocolate tea... yes please! This museum is quaint and informative. We spent about 45 minutes exploring the displays, drinking chocolate tea and trying a few different stages of the chocolate making process. There is a small store to buy some gifts and chocolate to go. We didn't take a class, but there was one going on while we toured and it looked like they were enjoying themselves.

Fun for chocoholics.... Great Hot Chocolate - hot milk with melted chocolate to add yourself, plus spices and honey. The brownie was a bit dry, but save some of your melted chocolate to pour over it. Chocolate tea? Pretty damn good. Four of the guys bought AXE chocolate deodorant/body-spray on the way out, thus buying into the idea that women prefer chocolate...!

Informative; delicious. This is a winner. Other revues say that it is just a store, but it definitely a museum, albeit a small one. The space is quite small, but you can learn a good deal about the history of chocolate. There are classes you can sign up for to learn about making chocolate. I didn't take the classes, so I can't speak about them. You can see where they make chocolate. They store areas sells chocolate, as well as things only tangentially related to chocolate. The chocolate bars they sell are delicious. My favorites are the dark chocolate and mango, and dark chocolate and coca.

Fun to see if you need to waste some time. nothing amazing about this except perhaps for young kids to see the chocolate being made. upstairs view nice of the park across the street and might be great spot to watch the parades in the town on sundays
It's just a store..... Don't be fooled. This is not a museum, just a store and a coffee shop. The prices are pretty inflated nevertheless.

interesting and fun. we did the workshop, had a lot of fun and learned many new things about chocolate, the way it is produced and about its history.the museum is interesting. reading everything there beforehand helped us understand the explanations that were given in the first part of the workshop which we asked to be held in spanish. (though our teacher could explain in english whenever we didn't understand.)thanks, manuel. you did a great job!
great. great place to learn how to make chocolate and buy some... im typing more because trip advisor wont let me post with out 50 characters
