Mayan Hot Chocolate. We are accustomed to drinking typical European style hot chocolate so this was a real treat when we tried it! It's so traditional, the ingredients are high quality and for chocolate lovers like us there's nothing better.

A very different choco tasting fun and eductaional as well!. I generally don't like educational or museum-like stuff on a fun vacation (unless its a field trip) but this place unlike any other edu place. It offers amazing decor; great for couples, family and kids. It can even be a date place! Food and beverages are quite different from other chocolate shops I had visited (I highly highly recommend their caramal choco and caliente choco. The latter is asuperb version of mexican hot chocolate). I recommend that you visit just before sunset and grab a table in one of the overlooking windows. Dont forget to grab few truffles for rest of the stay in Cusco and Peru.

If there is time...swing by. Entry is free. There is alot of information about chocolate and how it was used in the old civilizations, how it came to be adopted in Europe, etc. Also interesting tidbits about the plants. There is the educational factor.They offer chocolate making lessons (I think you have to book in advance). We didn't participate in it but we saw some groups doing it when we visited. There is also a chocolate shop that sells chocolate that is 100% from Peru, and a cafe that offers chocolate drinks. We ordered a hot chocolate thinking it would be made for us. But it was so cute, they brought out how melted down chocolate, a small pitcher of milk, honey, and some red spice that gave it a kick. We had fun mixing our own hot chocolate to our personal taste. Its not a large place but I think if you need a break from the sun and am tired of walking outside, this is a good place to unwind for a short period. Its also near the main square so it is convenient to find.

Awesome chocolate. If you have the time, this is a great spot to spend an hour, have some chocolate and watch the activities on the plaza. We brought home a lot of chocolate in multiple forms including in the bean.

Great chocolate for souvenirs. Exactly what it sounds like... free chocolate museum describing how to make it with chocolate-making classes offered. 15 soles for a chocolate bar makes a perfect souvenir before hopping on that flight from Lima!
Fun respite from the sun. This is a free museum where you get to learn about chocolate! Free samples are available of delicious chocolate tea and chocolate candy!

Good for the whole family. This was a nice little museum that is self-guided and offers choco tea (must try) and small chocolate samples as you walk around and learn. They also had couches and tables for cafe food (we didn't eat anything other than the chocolate). It's worthwhile stopping by, you could also make your own truffles etc. Staff were there if you needed them, but not trying to push the product, which was nice.

Interesting and educational. This was a very interesting morning, and super kid friendly too.I took my grandchildren there and we participated in the chocolate workshop, mostly adults, but there were a couple of other children and it worked out fine.A great thing to do on a colder or rainy day in Cusco! We thought it a little expensive at first but since you get to keep all the chocolate you make, it really works out quite well. The kids loved it and have asked to go again this year when they visit.Its also a pleasant little place to go for a cup of hot chocolate, from where you can view the lovely Plaza Recocijo, easy to find, you can smell the chocolate from several yards away from the entrance!

Simple but nice!. Nice information about chocolate, then take a hot chocolate or coffee with a nice view on a market place. You can taste various chocolates and even a tea! And... rare in Cusco... they have never tried to sell us something... it was free but how to avoid buying good stuff!? ;-)

Tasty Chocolate - Fair Prices. Took the 5-minute tour which was free, learned some interesting stuff. They have some chocolate making classes that I wanted to participate in but didnt have time. That being said the chocolate is very tasty and they have a big variety of flavors/styles for purchase in the shop so if you are nearby they make good gifts to bring back home!

House1899. A little hard to find, but well worth a visit. Staff were welcoming and happy to provide tasting samples. The products were good value. The story of chocolate is much more than previously thought, and the displays and video were informative.
Yummy!!!!!!!. Felt the chocolate was quite expensive but the hot chocolate and chocolate bun was delicious for lunch. The balcony overlooks the square and is a nice place to sit in the sun.

Fun way to spend an afternoon. I did the 2 hour "Bean to Bar" workshop. I was annoyed when I first arrived. I had to wait at least 10 minutes to check in and was greeted by the front desk with "Why are you here." I quickly got over that unpleasant experience after a couple glasses of chocolate tea but still.. The check in process could have been so much easier. I was told to have a seat and someone would come and get me. No one ever did, but when I saw a group congregating in the kitchen I asked if that was my group and joined. A little extra hospitality would have been nice, I didn't feel welcome at first. The class in itself was very interesting and fun. I learned alot about the production of chocolate, how to harvest the beans and got to make some chocolates at the end. Be prepared to wait 1.5 hours after your class ends in order to pick up your chocolates. You can pick them up the next day, but I was heading out of Cusco so I had to wait. The chocolates were delicious though!

Great chocolate. The chocolates here are SO good. The shop is very small, though, and seems to be very popular, so we read the chocolate process, bought a few pieces and left. Once we ate the chocolates, we wished we'd bought more, but it was too crowded to go back.

Amazing tour - great chocolate and other food!. We did the 2 hour tour where we learnt how chocolate is made and then made and moulded some ourselves. Highly recommended if you have the time/money. The cafe itself is great, and has a great selection of snacks and chocolate type foods/drinks. Ideal for chocolate lovers!!

DISAPPOINTING FOR WHAT IT COULD BE. Disappointing. This claims to be a museum, yet only has photographic displays, descriptions and a few short videos on cocoa bean cultivation and chocolate production. The museum is located on the second floor of a building. The entrance is difficult to find - down a side street, through an entranceway to an interior courtyard then upstairs. The whole museum takes up the space of a small apartment, spread over several levels. You get some chocolate tea on arrival (actually quite good, then you're on your own unless you want to buy their products or take a chocolate making session). If you have any mobility issues, I don't suggest even trying this (too many stairs). You can take a course in chocolate making (70 soles - $25.00), but it is quite expensive, you don't make much (more watching and listening than doing) or just buy some of their chocolate products. Their products are very tasty, but you will find just as good and much more choices in almost any store in Cusco and for a much cheaper price.

Free entry but.... It's hard to leave without a chocolate purchase! Wander around the small museum and learn all about chocolate production, varieties, world usage, etc. It's hard to leave ChocoMuseo without opening your wallet for the purchase of great chocolate. We especially enjoyed filling little ChocoMuseo jars with a variety of chocolate flavors in brightly colored foil cubes. A great memento of our visit, gift for relatives, and, of course, a heavenly treat! Thank you for hosting this lovely musuem/gift shop.

Good place to go on a rainy day. While I wouldn't go so far as to say this is a museum - more like 2 rooms with signs about the history of chocolate - it's a good place to escape to on a rainy day. There's some free samples of chocolate and cocoa tea and lots of places to sit and relax. We stopped in one afternoon to escape the rain and ended up staying for some delicious fondue and coffee. I wouldn't go out of my way to go here, but I would definitely stop in if you're looking for a way to take a break during the day.

Meh. Not super exciting. Had good information about the history of the chocolate industry in the Americas, but obviously a marketing gimmick to get customers inside buying their chocolate, which is not cheap. Saw some people doing a truffle making workshop inside which looked fun, but extremely overpriced. "Free chocolate sample" is a cup of cocoa tea (not the same as hot cocoa). Go only if you're nearby and have 10 minutes to spare.
Super friendly and fun cooking class. The cooking class was a wonderful option. And the food was not only fun to prepare but it was great. Unreal chocolate!
Chocolate heaven. Learn how to make your own chocolate , or just order off the menu. This educational chocolate museum has it all-

Fun experience but prices comparable to Europe. Interesting facts about Coco and Cocoa agriculture and production in Peru. No entrance fee. The staff was very friendly. They gave us complimentary coco tea and I ended up buying two bags! Prices were quite steep and shockingly comparable to the prices in Europe.

Chocolate Museum. A nice little free museum in Cusco that gives the history of Chocolate and how it relates to Peruvian culture. Not being a tea drinker, I didn't try the chocolate tea, but those with me that did said it was great.

Small but fun and tasty. Its a small place but have sal the info u need about the history and so on. Did not do the workshop since u had to book it which we didt know and it looked fun. Had the fondue and it was really nice, shard the big one among 4 and it was a lot to eat anyway. All in all everything we bought and eat was really nice. A good option including eating and relaxing.

a must see in cusco!. I had the opportunity to take in the beans to bar workshop at ChocoMueso and it was wonderful! we were greeted immediately with a chocolate tea and was told how the museum works and where to start. The museum was very informative but cannot compare to the knowledge we got from the workshop. We got to sample 3 chocolate drinks and saw how to make them, as well as the fun of making our own chocolate inspired treats! it was so much fun and the information I got from it was awesome! The guide was so passionate about chocolate and everything he had to say was interesting and well said.if you have the time to do a workshop please do it! oh and we also had the chocolate fondue which was AMAZING!!!

Fun diversion. This was fun, and I bought a lot of chocolate which was nice to have during my travels in Peru. We didn't partake in the workshop which I imagine is the real fun here. We just sort of stumbled on this place and decided to take a look. They offer a lot of good information about the history of cocoa and they gave us cocoa hot tea to sample which I ended up buying a big bag full to bring back and share. I think this is one of the better souvenirs I came back with.

Choc-errific! Dark chocolate lover's paradise. We were handed a pamphlet in the street for ChocoMuseo, with a 5% discount penned on it. We eventually headed upstairs to check out the museum / cafe that commands a view over the Plaza Regocijo for a hot chocolate, and ended up booking a chocolate making course. We were very pleasantly surprised and had what we would describe as one of the best experiences of our time in Cusco. Our host Gladys was very informative and very entertaining - cracking little jokes all the time. At the end of the chocolate making you have an hour to fill in while your chocolate sets. Fantastic experience, do it!

Unique!. Interesting, interactive, attractive, and full with optional activities which keeps the general entrance free. Great spot!! Great place to buy presents o souvenirs, too; special ones. I really like their concept, and know that they also work in a very responsible way towards their staff and providers. So: five stars!

Great little place to learn about chocolate. We discovered the ChocoMuseo from a map that was given to us at a restaurant. This quaint little place packs in a lot of knowledge in a small space. They have displays all around describing the history of chocolate and how it's made. An interesting little factoid that shocked us was that 50% of Peruvian chocolate goes to Switzerland! 0.oUnfortunately, by the time we learned about the chocolate workshops, it was too late since we were leaving the next day. I highly recommend this as a nice little excursion, especially if you are choco-holics like my husband and me.

Very well promoted!. We saw advertisments for the ChocoMuseo everywhere in Cusco and a number of people stopped us in the street to give us flyers. It took us a little while to find as it is upstairs within a small courtyard. The museum is a nice way to pass some time - there is a fairly interesting display about how chocolate is made and they gave you some nice Chocolate tea. The people running it seemed incredibily enthusiastic about what they were doing. You are able to do a class in making chocolates that looked quite fun but we didn't have time to do it.

What a fun time!!!!!!!. The Museum is FREE! right in the centre and very very interesting and makes a tatoal sense of how Chocolate is formed. They offer you "Chocolate Tea" on arrival. Here you can make your own Chocolates (cost 25 Soles). Mine was for presents, but by the time I had finished there were only 4 left and all eaten within 10 mins of leaving,. Very worthwile seeing, and deffinatley would reccomond this place.

I'd pass on this if you have a laundry list of things to see. When we arrived there were school groups. There really is not much of anything to see there except for hot chocolate and some gits to purchase.
Delicious!. Such delicious treats at Choco Museo. A unique spot in Cusco and lovely view sipping a hot choc in the sun. Definitely worth a visit.

Lots of fun, great staff. Happened upon this place when we had a few hours to spare in cusco and were glad we did! We too, the half hour chocolate making "course". My wife and I loved it! The instructor was really really friendly and knowledgeable. Great value for the price we paid. Would highly recommend.
Chocolate tea. Bought a bag of chocolate tea for the Inka trail. Amazing stuff just add to hot water with a bit of sugar and you have a clear hot chocolate without the dairy products. YUM !

Chocolate and wifi ~ what could be better !!!. A discount coupon to the Chocolate Museum gets thrust in your hands at the Plaza de Arms in Cusco, Peru - just a few short blocks from the chocolate museum. Being tired and ready for a treat, I ambled over to the place. Nothing prepared me for what a delicious and informative surprise awaited inside.Being a bit "touristed out" - and hungry and tired, I immediately opted for the day's special: Hot chocolate and chocolate-banana bread. Both were superlative. The hot chocolate was uniquely served: A generous dish of what looked like chocolate pudding: The waitress said that was to mix with the accompanying aqua caliente (hot water) in a pot. I had 3 generous cups of hot chocolate from this combo.The banana-chocolate cake bread was rich and also very generous sized portion.Both were served on nice dishes (no styrofoam cups!).I asked if wifi was available. Just like Starbucks, I was given a slip of paper with the secret password! Took out my little chromebook, and caught up with the news from home and friends while feasting in very lovely and pleasant surroundings. I sat in a big overstuffed very comfy chair, looking out the balcony window into a park.I would have opted for one of the two balcony windows, but both were full during my entire 2 hour visit.After getting refreshed and caught up with the news, I toured the quite well presented exhibits. They were all information story cards with good pictures and big print, so no squinting required to read in the soft light.There was a life-size model of a cocoa tree, and also beans and pods to freely touch and handle to get familiar with cocoa - from seed to goodies.There was no hustle to purchase anything. The museum is free. The coupon gives a small discount. The atmosphere was very friendly and slightly on the party side with all the tourists enjoying various chocolate goodies, and gathering info.There were classes offered by friendly staff, and lots of interesting choco items to purchase if so inclined.They also give a free very unique and extra delicious cocoa tea when you arrive (cocoa de mate). It was extraordinarily delicious. You can purchase some leaves to take out (but remember you cannot bring cocoa leaves in ANY form into the USA.)I definitely recommend this excellent attraction to my friends visiting Cusco, Peru.Yum! Yum! Yum.... 10+ Yum Stars for the Chocolate Museum :)

Small but tasty. The museum is small and the exhibits are just posters on walls. They do however offer some interesting classes in making chocolate and truffles and a small café menu in which you can try their version of Peruvian chocolate. The shop is excellent and has various tasty options including chocolate tea which was spectacular. The place gets pretty full so be patient.

Yum. We took a break from wandering Cusco and went into the ChocoMuseo, and enjoyed the information they had on Chocolate and then sat and enjoyed some chocolate tea and fondue. It was a nice break from walking and a good place to relax.

Chocolate Wow. I went to the museum on my last visit to Cuzco. It was really close to the central plaza just a few minutes walk across another small plaza with a fountain. The chocolate museum was terrific. We learn about chocolate. We ate it fresh and at various stages of production to the final product, chocolate bars! WOW! Then we sat on the balcony over looking the fountain and tried making our own Hot Chocolate. It was a terrific experience and didn't take a lot of time to take the tour and sit and enjoy and relax. Well worth the visit!

Fun and delicious. We signed up for the 2 hour chocolate workshop. It was so fun! They took us through all the steps of preparing chocolate, from roasting the beans, peeling them, grinding them, molding, etc. We got to try different chocolate drinks the Spaniards and Mayans used to drink and then we got to make our own chocolate to take home. Delicious. Very informative and fun. Highly recommend!

Learn where chocolate comes from and then enjoy. Very close to the central plaza in Cuzco, this is a cafe-museum which allows you to learn the history of cocoa and also offers tastings and sells chocolate bars and other souvenirs. There is a balcony and sitting area to enjoy the plaza while enjoying your chocolate!

Did evening cooking class - so good!. I HIGHLY recommend visiting this place while you're in Cusco. If anything, stop in for a free taste of tea made with dried chocolate leaves - very delicious! (I bought this for my sister as a souvenir). Also, I took the evening cooking class - we went to San Pedro market which was a great experience, and the food we cooked was delicious! We did menu #3 and everyone cleaned their plate. It's a longer class - about 3.5 hours - and worth every penny. The Chef was very cute and helpful. One of my best experiences in Cusco!

Great tea. You get some free samples including chocolate tea, milk and dark chocoate. They some small displays explaining the chocolate process in Peru. A cafe is located throughout the museum. Prices were steep for chocolate (almost 5 DOLLARS) for a chocolate bar. The tea was surprisingly good. Can get crowded because the rooms are small.
Great chocolate and souvenirs. Great place to sit down and drink some hot chocolate. Lots of different kinds of chocolate available for purchase.

lots of fun and free!. We were walking around the plaza and stumbled across this place. It was very informative and they have a great chocolate bean tea. I had 6 cups! Lots of other samples and fun people.

An educational experience. What an amazing museum! You get to see the production stages of chocolate right in front of your eyes after you are greeted with chocolate tea! Plus they have all these fun facts around the museum, you can make your own chocolate, and buy quality souvenirs. The best hot chocolate I ever had - Mayan - mixed with chilli - yummy

chocolate heaven. You can go in and just walk around for free and buy the chocolate items, or take a 2 hour "class" that includes a brief history of chocolate and very fun tastings and making your own chocolate bars. We did the class and it was a blast. I would highly recommend this tour for chocolate lovers!

Attention all chocolate lovers!. As soon as you enter this museum, you will be in heaven. The subtle smell of chocolate hits you and you are greeted with a delicious cup of Choco tea. You can read about the history of the Choco plant, agriculture and how Chocolate is made. There is definfitly a fun factor about this place. For 70 soles, you can participate in an artisan chocolate making expereince, which takes just under 3 hours. They offer a cafe and a small store to buy the best chocolate in Cusco.

Nice small museum. Interesting museum to visit where you get a free sample of choco tea. You can also make chocolate in workshops and buy chocolate goodies. If you arrive in Lima, visit the ChocoMuseo there as you are given a 10% discount for the Cusco museum.
Lots of chocolate!. Cosy place with lots of variety of uses of chocolate. Everything is delicious and there is lots of information about chocolate's history.

Lovely little museum cafe. Lots of information on the walls to read about how chocolate is produced. Free samples and Chocolate tea. I never heard of chocolate tea but I loved it! No caffeine, I've ordered some online from a tea company in Ireland since I got back. We purchased a couple of chocolate bars on the way out. It was definitely worth the visit.

Perfect spot on a rainy day. I arranged to take the 2 hour chocolate making class (70s, about $23). The timing was perfect due to the torrential downpour as soon as I walked in! The small museum was cozy, the staff friendly....and the whole place smelled fantastic. To simply visit is free.The chocolate making class was, not only informative, but very hands-on. We had four "students" and our "teacher", Gladys, let us touch, taste and feel through the whole process. After learning about the chocolate making process, we had the opportunity to make our own individual chocolates. We chose our molds and ingredient combinations and got to work. It was so much fun! After an hour, Gladys told us to return to collect our candy. I pressed each piece out of the mold and bagged it myself.I returned a few days later, due to an overwhelming chocolate craving, and the staff remembered me ....with detail. Impressive for a busy tourist location!I highly recommend slowing your visit to Peru a bit to enjoy some chocolate and great company.
Cute. A fun afternoon excursion, nothing amazing. Not much to say, its a museum about chocolate. My friend bought some chocolate, a bit expensive but tasted great.

Chocolate-making class was fun and informative. This is a nice little chocolate museum in a very beautiful location. When I walked in I was given free chocolate tea and invited to explore. There were informational signs on every wall, a video playing upstairs, an area to watch people making chocolate, and a delicious menu to order from. There was a little sitting room to enjoy your food in, or you could sit on the balcony (which I highly recommend) and look out over the small plaza.I opted to pay for the chocolate-making class. It was a bit more than I would've liked to pay, but I walked away with a bag of hand-made chocolates to enjoy, plus a free bag of cocoa husks for making chocolate tea since I won the bean-grinding competition! Also, as you round the corner to get to the entrance on the side, look for someone handing out pamphlets for the museum - they usually have a 5% off sticker on them! The staff were all very nice and interested in me and my travels. They all speak English, but they responded very positively when they found out I spoke some Spanish. I would definitely go back to this place!

Fun and informative. We dropped on here by accident as we were trying to kill an hour or so.We were pleasantly surprised.Informative and very interesting.You can actually take a class of making chocolate - a bit pricey for Peru but still good.Be careful when sampling - you get charged at the end.I asked if the wrapped chocs were complimentary as I wanted to try before buying the big bars. The lady clearly didn't undersatand ás she said yes. Upon leaving me were charged for each sample. Heaven knows how she was counting and talking at the same time.That said the staff were lovely and the chocolate special!
Fun!. The chef joined us for cocoa seed sampling. We just had to buy bags of the cocoa tea. Delicious! A fun little place to learn about chocolate while sampling;)

Worth the Visit!. Some other travelers recommended this place to me, and I was not disappointed. All the staff is so welcoming and wants to give you the best service possible! They have free chocolate tea that they serve to all their customers, and their food prices are very reasonable. This is a great place just to stop by and relax if you've been traveling for awhile!

Don't miss the ChocoMuseo in Cuzco. We loved this little museum. They offer workshops and we saw people making chocolate during our visit. Looked fun. Bought chocolate for friends on our visit. We watched the video presentation, which was interesting but maybe outdated given Peru's and the world's movement toward more sustainable practices. Very enjoyable and the staff are really great too. Helpful and had a sense of humour!

Good stop for chocoholics... Nicely located, 2nd floor overlookingone of the many squares in Cusco. You can get a tour, make your own chocolates ore just have a coffe on the balcony. Owner Alain is. Very hospitable and speak a number of languages. He has another location in Miraflores.

Free, excellent information. First of all, loved that it was free, and would have been willing to pay a few bucks since it was such a good museum (it's free to get you in to buy some chocolate). The information was in both Spanish and English, and was very thorough and very interesting. Covered plants and how they grow and hot the beans are turned into chocolate, what Peru does with it's chocolate, etc. I would definitely recommend going. We didn't buy any chocolate (a bit expensive) but weren't pressured to.

Free museum. My friends and I spent an hour or so in the ChocoMuseo on an afternoon of sight-seeing in Cusco. It was a small but well-organized museum that offered a good intro to the cocoa trade of Peru. Upon entering the museum they offered delicious cocoa tea, and had several areas for sitting an enjoying hot chocolate. It's a nice way to spend some time if you want to get off of your feet for a bit after touring. They also had a lot of chocolate souvenirs that make for great gifts that can be transported home easily. Recommend checking it out.

Chocoadicted!!!. Man, this place is great..... i always go for some brownie, chocolate banana cake, milkshake, some free chocolate samples, chocolate tea, chocolate founde!!!!! the best i have ever had!!!!! its a great place and i have learnt so much about chocolate! a must go on your stay in Cusco either for the chocolate workshop or just an afternoon looking at the plaza from one of the balconies and enjoying a mayan hot chocolate (they put some chili aside for you to make it more/less spicy)

Fun times in Cusco!. After being handed multiple flyers on the streets of Cusco we decided to check out the Choco Museo and boy were we glad we did! Well worth the money we came out of the place suggesting it to whoever would listen. We had a fun and delicious day learning about the culture of chocolate while creating our own creative treats! (which we were able to take home and enjoy for the days following!).The perfect way to spend a rainy afternoon!!Thank you to the wonderful and friendly staff.

OMG! Yum! Mayan hot chocolate and fondue FTW. This was probably my ultimate favorite as I am still dreaming about their hot chocolate and fondue. I wish had their recipes as I have bene trying to replicate their hot chocolate with no success. You must go here!

Fun place to stop by. We stopped in and bought some chocolate. Bars cost about 6 dollars which is a little pricey but hey are tasty... The museum of chocolate isn't really that elaborate or interesting. If you have time drop by but it isn't a must do...

cute!. Do the workshops, wish I did... They have 3 workshops throughout the day but you have to sign up by phone or in person. They sell fun chocolate that you can take back as souvenirs if you like... Worth a day trip, less than an hour of your time. Its also in front of a small park that is really pretty.

Loved it, interesting and loads of yummy chocolate drink and eat. If you like chocolate you have to visit. Not cheap by Peruvian standards but really well done with humour, great chocolate, plenty of tasting and choice to take away. Our 3 kids loved it!

Fun - definitely visit!. This does not take long, but this small museo is free, has a great, informative set-up, and has incredible chocolate! We had a couple of hot chocolates, which we sipped while sitting on the balcony of the museo which overlooks a pleasant square. You can buy chocolate for friends and family back home, and it makes for a popular gift. This will only take an hour (if that), but it's a lot of fun.

Loved it. take a class!!
It's a must great way to meet people and have a laugh, grinding the cocoa beans and making some drinks then making your own chocolates to take home
Fabulous sweet dark chocolate
There's only 1 word
DELICIOUS!
Yummy!. An excellent museum full of interesting facts about cacao beans. The view from the museum is great. If you love chocolate this is the place to visit and it's free!
Delicious. The beautiful chocolate aroma had us from the start. We loved reading the information and watching the chocolatiers at work. The chocolate tea was divine!

Excellent experience!!. Having been to chocolate factories in Australia, where they just try to sell their goods, it was refreshing to go somewhere with information, tasting and demonstrations.It put our factory in Perth to shame!The information was aimed at both adults and children. As we walked in we were given a cup of cacao tea (yum!!) all along the stages of the cacao process, there were beans to taste and videos to watch.I was very impressed and suggest anyone who comes should pop in for an informative and yummy 1/2 hour.We bought 2 bars with different fillings for 20 soles. Yum!

Good way to kill an hour. A very well put together if short museum about the chocolate trade (and of course the resulting colonial oppression). It is above street level off a very pretty courtyard on a lovely square. Very clean, smart and with plenty to buy if you so desire, plus a chance to fashion chocolate items yourself in their 'work' area. You get a complimentary cup of chocolate tea on entry (which is also free). And the toilets were the best we'd found in Cuzco!
Fun. Nice place to stop and Check out. Close to the center of town. We didn't have a lot of time but got to taste ( and buy) some great chocolate. Fun little thing to add to your time in Cusco

Fun and Informative. Do the small chocolate making experienceDoesn't take long and you have fun along the wayYou learn how mayans make chocolate and even get to design your own too - funky little place with tasty chocolate and nice coffee also

Very Good visit!!. We were given discount fliers in the street to visit this.  And we almost didn't. I'm so glad we did, learned all about chocolate.They give you the most wonderful tea.It was soo good.If this was the end of our trip we would of bought chocolate to bring home as gifts We did buy the tea and I wish I had bought more. i left there high on the smell of chocolate!!!

Lots of fun; great alternative to ruins!. There are a lot of ruins in the Cusco area, and after a couple of days, we were ready to try something different. The ChocoMuseo smells incredible as soon as you walk in the door. We signed up for a "From Bean to Bar" chocolate class, and it was so much fun. There were four people in our class - 2 from America, 1 from Germany, and 2 from Australia. The staff person who led the workshop spoke great English, so it was never difficult to understand what she was saying. We got an overview of chocolate in South America, and then we started making our own. It was a great experience to roast and mash the cacao beans ourselves. We made three drinks with it and then used a different chocolate (already tempered) to make chocolate bars or pieces. I would highly recommend this to anyone.
Fun place. I have done the chocolate cooking class and the night cooking class here. Both quite fun and worth doing. The food is good and the staff are very pleasant.

Didn't make it to the workshop. We booked the day before for the chocolate making workshop and arrived on time the next day. On the day, There was a guy at the reception area on the phone who pretty much dismissed us. We spoke to a young girl who gave us a chocolate cocoa tea and we explained we were there for the workshop. We were shown to a table and asked to wait. After 1/2 an hour we became aware there were people in the workshop area and when we asked about our class the guy at the front counter had a bit of "a go" at us about not being there on time and when we explained we had been there for half an hour he had "a go" at the young girl. A bit unfortunate as we were looking forward to the Peruvan style of chocolate making. We were offered a discount on another booking which we accepted but unfortunately we got caught up in wandering the lovely old city of Cuso.
Chocolate course. My 9 year old daughter andI did the chocolate making course. It was finger licking good and we had delicious chocolates to take home wh us. Well worth the time and the money.

Ok but don't do the 4 pm session!. We attended the Chocomuseum today. Didn't realise when we turned up at 11:10 am that there were only three time options - 11am, 1:30 and 4:00 pm. First was booked so we opted for last one to get some shopping in. At this point I will mention that we were still exhausted after doing the inca trail yesterday. The tour is 2 hrs long and you stand the entire time. It was fully booked and that was too many people - they should have restricted each workshop to no more than 8-10 people (we had about 15?). The first half hour was talk about the tree the beans come from. The room was hot and thick with the scent of chocolate (initially not so unpleasant). The next hour was hands on with the beans and we made two drinks with the bean paste. Interesting, but not to my pallet. So what was left was only half an hour to fill molds with pre-tempered chocolate and flavours. The shop shuts at 6:30 but you have to come back an hour later to get your goodies. The door to the complex in which the museo was located was shut and we were lucky someone came through while we stood trying to work out how to get in. My suggestion is to avoid the last session and don't do it if you're really tired already. I LOVE chocolate but I was not enjoying myself. If you've made chocs before you will be disappointed that the molds are the flimsy plastic ones not proper hard/durable ones and you don't learn how to temper it or produce a really top quality product (appearance wise). If you've never made choc and are just generally interested in the process this is the one for you.

get a chocolate tee for free!. the chocoMuseo is a great place to hang out for a while and get to know everything about chocolate while enyoing a free chocolate tee!...not cheap but well worth the money: make your own chocolate! you also get to try differnt typical kinds of hot chocolate made of your own grinded beans. it lasts about 2 hours and the chocolate tastes delicious!!!!!...(if youre not a sissi but enjoy the taste of dark chocolate!...thats the real taste!!)...btw: if you participated in the free walking tour before the workshop you get a chocolate fondue for free!

This class was a real treat!. Cusco's Choco Museum classes are informative and super fun! Smiley Gladys was our chocolate-making teacher, and not only she guided us on the task of making chocolate from scratch, she also gave us a crash course on the origins of chocolate and the historic use of cocoa beans. After a brief introduction supported by the exhibits on the museum, we were all hands in action!We started by preparing and tasting different drinks prepared with cocoa beans. Then, we proceeded to make our own chocolate, from toasting the beans, grinding and mashing them… until we molded our own chocolate mixes with nuts, spices, and a lot of other "toppings" provided to add your personality to your treats.We had such a great time making chocolate with our group and Gladys and, of course, tasting different treats at the Museum as well. Their chocolate is top notch, particularly the bitter one: dark, so intense and sustainable, as it is locally grown.I'd absolutely recommend a visit to Cusco's Chocolate Museum when you are in town. You can buy a lot of chocolate related products in their shop (movies, toiletries, condoms, merchandise, jewelry made with cocoa beans), you can also have a sweet treat form their menu (coffee as well!) and, of course, take a class to enlighten you in the beauty of the chocolate making art. Loved it!

Excellent afternoon. Peru is known for coffee and chocolate internationally, but it can be difficult to find coffee beans, and chocolate from the region. ChocoMuseo offers a wealth of information about the rich history of chocolate and it's economic role in Peru, South America, and worldwide. Definitely worth an hour of your time.

A fun Activity!. The ChocoMuseo is a fun activity! We learned about how cocoa is made, where it's grown. We had the opportunity to grind cocoa beans into powder. The powder was then used to make different flavoured hot coco. We also made our own chocolates. You can choose from an assortment of molds and fillings. It was quite the interactive workshop! We really enjoyed ourselves! I would recommend it to any chocolate enthusiast!However, the chocolate isn't very sweet. It's not milk chocolate. But, it still tastes really good!Other details: There is no fee to go into the museum. However, there is a fee for the chocolate workshop. The storage space for your belongings is under the counter where the workshop takes place. It's fairly safe, as I would assume that people who leave things typically only pick up their own things. There is no secure locked area to place belongings.

Take a chocolate making class!. My friend and I spent one of our mornings at the ChocoMuseo, learning all about making chocolate and preparing some snacks for our upcoming Inca Trail Trek. It was fun from beginning to end - not to mention delicious!
Tasty surprise. Cozy and informative. The Choco Museo was a real treat. Highly recommended for chocolate lovers and curios travelers who want to experiment a charming and tasty experience.

Delightful educational and hands on experience. We checked out ChocoMuseo for the chocolate making class. It was nearly 3 hours of fun! We started with a brief education of the cocoa plant, processing of the beans where each person in the class had to test roasted beans and subsequently grind the beans into the paste. Then we topped it off with creating our own chocolates!The staff was incredibly attentive, noting when one of us began to suffer altitude symptoms and brought over a chair, created a fun competition for grinding the cacao beans, and answered questions with ease. A lovely 3hour activity in cusco.

Best chocolate milk ever. My husband said that this was the best chocolate milk he's ever had in his life (and he's had a LOT of chocolate milk). The museum staff is very friendly. When you first walk in, it's a little difficult to tell if you are in the right place. You walk into the shop and cash register and there are usually a lot of customers there confusing things, but if you walk past the shop and into the cafe/museum, it begins to make more sense. They offer you some free chocolate tea (very yummy) and you can wander around the different displays or sit and have some chocolate refreshments. It only takes an hour or so, but it's well worth the visit.

More of a cafe than a museum, but the class was fun. As a museum, there isn't much too it, though really, how do you make an extensive chocolate museum. Given what they had to work with, they did a nice enough job. There were drinks/food for purchase, though I expected much more for sale by way of chocolates. We (two adults) took the chocolate making class and it was fun. It was hands on and good-humored. We were rather hungry when we started but quite full by the end; you get to make a fair amount of chocolate (and you can make many flavor combinations), but you need to come back an hour or more later for it, so plan accordingly. I thought the chocolate was average tasting, but my partner thought it was quite good. The class is only 3 times per day, we took the last one at 4 pm. Oh, there was someone handing out cards in the plaza in front that gave you 5% off, so get one of those!
so so. not extremely friendly..acted like we were doing them a favor by visiting...Asked after their famous chocolate bread and just responded they were out..not alot of character.

Make your own chocolate candies!. I took the bean to bar class at the ChocoMuseu and had a great time. I learned about the process to grow, harvest, and process coco beans. The chocolates that we made were some of the best I've ever had - a result of the freshness and purity of the product and certainly not any of my efforts. I loved the cocoa husk tea and wish I could find it in the U.S. One thing to note - it takes an hour for the candies to set up and you have to come back an hour after class is over to pick them up, so make sure to plan accordingly.

Great Experience!. The chocoMuseo is a definite must when in Cuzco. The chocolate-making course is great fun and knowledgeable, and there is an informative museum attached to it where you can learn everything you might want to know about the history of chocolate

Chocolate Stuffed Bread to Die For!. Although the museum lacks some information it has a very delicious side to it! After looking to past chocolate publicity and reading some interesting facts clearing out misconceptions that we still have about chocolate (that it causes acne, cavities,etc...) the only thing you want to do is get a taste of this adictive product. They offer 2 specialty hot chocolates: Mayan or European style. Both are served in a "build your own chocolate" style. With the mayan they bring you the milk, the melted chocolate in another glass and in another recipient the secret ingredient: "aji picante". I lived in Mexico quite a time and learned that hot chili can be mixed with everyhting, so I loved this combination! Plus, since it comes separated you can control the amount of heat you want in it. My friend ordered the European which is a more classic option. The chocolate and milk are served separated as well so you can mix, but instead of "aji picante" the additional ingredients are cinnamon sticks and cloves. Both were delicious and perfect to help you deal with the cold weather. Please don't forget to accompany your chocolate with their specialty breads: raisin stuffed & chocolate stuffed. Both melt in your mouth! They are so good we went twice to get them!They offer chocolate workshops where they teach you how to transform the cocoa into the yummy chocolate bars we eat. I would have loved to take them, but they last 2 hours and we were tight in time.They sell all sorts of chocolate. A little expensive, but way delicious! My personal favorites were the unique flavors: aji picante, coca, saltine & oreo stuffed! A delicious way to start your day in Cusco!

Amazing Chocolate!. If you are in Cuzco, you must go to the ChocoMuseo! The museum itself is great and very informative. However the best part is that when you go, you get a free taste of "chocolate tea" made from cacao beans. Also, their hot chocolate is amazing! It comes with liquid chocolate, cream, cinnamon, and cayenne pepper and you can mix it to your liking. The taste is incredible -you know the chocolate is extremely high quality. Plus it is fair trade, which makes it even better. You can enjoy your chocolate on the balcony overlooking a plaza which is a great experience. I was in Cuzco for several months and visited this place several times.

A delicious way to acclimate to altitude. If you need to stay in Cuzco to acclimate longer than you need, the ChocoMuseo is a really fun way to pass the time. They have small groups where you see how chocolate is made from scratch all the way from the bean and you actually make the chocolate yourself! You then get to personalize your flavors and take it home which could make a nice gift if you don't eat all of it first!

Good for a short visit. A fun little place. Good if you are traveling with kids. Situated inside a private courtyard, it's more like a little cafe, where you can read the history of chocolate on the displays. The have chocolate workshops for the kids, but they were ridiculously expensive so we skipped it. It's free to go in and look around, they give a free sample of cacao husk tea. Everything else is for sale, at tourist, not local prices. You can buy local fair trade chocolate bars at the local market for much less. Nevertheless, a good stop for a mug of chocolate!

Good quick visit. This is a good place to visit if you want to kill 30 minutes before your next activities! The exhibit about the the origins cocoa to present day chocolate was most fascinating. We get to sample their chocolate tea, and some small pieces of dark and milk chocolate. You can also participate in their workshop on how to make chocolate (for a hefty fee, of course!). There is a cafe there, and lots of chocolate products to purchase (bars, incense, deodorant and even condoms!). It is geared towards tourists and so the prices are on the expensive side. It is free to visit and like I said, it's a good "filler" if you are in the area and just want to check it out. Unless you're a huge chocolate fan, I wouldn't go out of my way to schedule a visit here.

Great little museum to visit and DO take the chocolate making class. I came here for the chocolate making class and had so much fun! It was very educational and enjoyable at the same time. We were given a short lecture on cocoa plants, the history of chocolate (Incan and Mayan), and then peeled our cocoa beans, ground them up, and made a few different drinks. The chocolate tea (made fr the husks of cocoa beans) is really interesting and yummy! We were given lots of different flavors to make our own chocolate from and went at it. The next day we came back and picked up our own chocolate to enjoy. I would highly recommend this to anyone of any age. P.S. Try to get a discount card from someone outside, it gives you a 5% discount!
Visiting ChocoMuseo. It was a pleasant time visiting the ChocoMuseo. They offered tea and smiles and i had a very good time there. I recomend it.
Sally, great chocolate museum. My friend and I had a lovely afternoon visiting your establishment. I am still enjoying the chocolate tea I purchased. Very educational.
GOOD CHOCOLATE. They sell cacao to make tea. Delicious! Very nice if you just want to walk around and relax a little eating good chocolate.

Super Free Museum with everything you never knew about chocolate.. Just one block from Plaza de Armes this wonderful museum is packed with information all about chocolate from the 12th century to the present day. Entry is free. And on entry you recieve a free welcoming drink, which is a lovely gesture. They also have workshops where you can make your own chocolate from bean to bar. 11.30, 1.30 and 4.00 daily. They last 2hours and cost 70 soles. The chocolate is delicious.

Okay place, don't go out of your way.. If you are walking around the Plaza de Armas stop in and look around. Some information about the history of chocolate. They sold chocolate here that was very good. You can take a 2 hour "class" where they show you how to make chocolate from cocoa beans. They have you roast them and grind them, etc. We did not take the class because it was somewhere around $27 per person which we thought was pricey for four of us. Didn't really seem like a museum to me, more like a chocolate store. If you are in the area, stop in but I wouldn't go out of my way to go there.

Nice relaxing venue to learn about chocolate. From what I've heard, this is a French run establishment. There were people passing flyers on the street for the ChocoMuseo and the flyer had 5% off on purchases so we went in for a stroll. Free admission. There are lots of wall presentations about growing cocoa. The employees of the museum offered us samples of cocoa tea along with milk chocolate and dark chocolate. The chocolate bars were a bit pricey but make good souvenirs. Also on site was a kitchen/lab for chocolate making classes.

2 people minimum. The 2 hour chocolate making was very unique. You need to have at least 2 people signed up, so I paid for someone else. It was 70 soles per person, but you also get about 40 soles worth of chocolates you make yourself to take home with you. I thought Miguel was a great teacher!

A MUST do!!. One of my teenage daughter's favorite experiences in Peru. We not only took the chocolate class, which was a lot of fun, but we came back that night and took the cooking class. Excellent!!

It's a sweet way to know how the chocolate is elaborated. Been in this place was a interesting and a sweet experience to get more knowledge about how the chocolate is made. We found a huge variety of flavors such as Lucuma, Coca, and Sauco which are tipical fruits and/ or products of the area. Also, every visitor has the change to take a class to produce his or her own chocolate which was awesome.

Great little museum. The ChocoMuseo is a great little museum tucked away on the second floor of a building on Calle Garcilaso 210. The museum was very informative and they also had space to host workshops. We didn't get to try a workshop, but would like to in their new location in Lima. They also had a space to purchase different chocolates they had made.

Very educational and provides a yummy treat. We did not make chocolate but enjoyed the museum and enjoyed some chocolate. The service is slow and relaxing. There is no urgency to order or to finish or to pay just enjoy the experience of the chocolate. We also appreciated the free entrance fee. It's a fun outing to take.

Interesting and Delicious. Cute little place with interesting facts and yummy treats. Try the Chocolate Tea! The hand made chocolate bars make great treats to bring home and they offer chocolate making classes and have a desert cafe

Kids loved it! Fun and interesting DIY chocolate adventure!. We took our three kids (14, 12 and 9) to the "make your own chocolate tour" and they loved it! You have to book in advance and the "class" accommodates about 12 people. It is a fun and educational 2 hour experience, and you get to take home and eat what you make!

A fun afternoon. My wife, five sons (13, 11, 8 and 6 year-old twins) and I took the chocolate making class at the ChocoMuseo. Our kids loved it. We peeled, roasted and ground the beans, made two or three different kinds of hot chocolate and made our own chocolates with a range of add-ins. Our instructor (sorry, I can't remember her name) was very good with our kids and spoke English fluently. For our kids, it was one of the highlights of the trip, and the chocolate was delicious.

ChocoMustseeo. We signed up for the cooking class to fill the time while acclimating for the Salkantay Trail hike. We had soooooo much fun that we signed up for the chocolate making class the next day!! This proved to be a blast also. The staff was very friendly and knowledgeable, the environment was great and the participants made the experience even better. Don't use this as a filler...it's a main event!! ...unless you don't like chocolate and great food!! (we also mixed in some wine...BONUS!!)

Educational and fun two hours for chocolate lovers. Three of us went to the 4pm class on a Saturday afternoon and found it informative, hands-on and fun, if a little hot at times. There were six in the class in all, 5 English and 1 Spanish speaking; this did mean the explanations/instructions had to be given in 2 languages. Six is a good number for getting everything done on time, and if you go to the 4pm class you do need to come back about 7pm (or the next morning) to collect the chocolates you have made once they have 'set'; there are lots of shapes and fillings available for you to 'design your own' chocolates. I found it a well run and imaginative diversion from the 'standard' sightseeing attractions, fun for any age/sex. There is a lovely smell of good quality chocolate, the staff are welcoming, polite and well trained and you drink chocolate tea and hot chocolate you have had a hand in making. There is a little cafe and chocolate museum on the same floor, and both standard and unusual chocolate items are available for purchase.

Yummy. Never realized Peruvian chocolate is so tasty. I'd recommend taking their workshop called "from bean to bar" where they teach you how to make your own chocolates literally from bean to bar and you get to take them home ;). About 2 hrs in length and 75 soles (about $28)They also sell the most amazing choco tea (tea from roasted cocoa husks). Even if you don't want to buy it they offer it as part of their daily samples...can also ask to sample some of their chocolates.
Great chocolate. Nice chocolates, you make, etc. Fun activity for the kids. We preferred the historic and art museums to this more touristy hit.
Delicious visit. Terrific variety of outstanding homemade chocolates.Watch it being made, wrapped, and labeled. Our favorite was dark chocolate with maras salt, a local specialty item.
Yummy and Inviting. Loved the free chocoalte tea, it was delicous and the smell in the museum is great. Coffee was good too.
Take a class!. We took the chocolate making class and had a great time! Learned a lot, and got to play with and eat chocolate. Staff there is incredibly nice. Highly recommend it!

What a great day!. I did I this with my mom today and absolutely loved it! We attended the 1:30 workshop and we were only 4 including us... And we were so happy because the late afternoon class had over 15 people. Because we were small we did so much, we made tea, roasted the cocoa beans and started from scratch to make or own chocolate bars. We had a great time and I found it refreshing from the typical tourist attractions. I would just recommend going early for a smaller classes to have more one on one chocolate making!

Sorry but rather boring. I went and it was a bit boring. It's based in a two storey apartment. It's tiny and there is very little to do.There is one room of facts, another tv room with a video playing and some more facts and that's it. There is a cafe bit and a kitchen where you can pay s.70 (£20ish) to make chocolate.It's free so worth taking a look but not recommended if you're short on time.

A must for a chocolate lover. This museum also offers chocolate 'cooking' courses which, if you are a chocolate lover, absolutely must make time to do the 2 hour course. You learn to make chocolate from the very first step of roasting the beans and get to make your very own and take it with you. They offer courses in a number of languages. ChocoMuseo is conveniently located near the Plaza des Armas.

A very special treat in an amazing city. My wife is a big fan of all things chocolate, so of course she loved ChocoMuseo. But I loved it, too.First of all, the young women who were in charge the day we arrived were so happy and welcoming when we arrived early and they let us in anyway. The educational part of the tour is well worth the time. Who knew that midges did the pollination? We also learned about the sustainable agriculture movement for cacao that will help the land and the people of Peru.We sat on one of the small balconies to enjoy the hot chocolate and watch the festival taking place in the plaza below.So, we give this a high rating for the location, the cheerful staff, educational value, and excellent chocolate.

Best part of CUSCO. when you walk in the smell of fresh chocolate overwhelms you!!!! They served us free samples of hot coco TEA, which was wonderful. The drinks are a little pricy for Peru but worth it. Such a wonderful location and beautiful views from the balcony. LOVED this place!

Excellent!. Sitting down now waiting for our chocolates to cool while my hubbie reads all the intersting facts on the Walls!We came in the morning -it opens at 10.30 - and we were able to do the 11am workshop which was fantastic (I was worried you had to pre-book)Gladys was good fun. The workshop was really informative, we got to taste chocolate tea,maya style hot chocolate and spanish style hot chocolate. We even got creative making our own chocolates at the end.Definately worth the 70soles for 2 hours!!

Disgusting. We found out about this museum purely by accident, wondering along the lovely roads we were handed a leaflet. We decided to pay a visit and it looked brilliant and we thought we'd give chocolate making a go!. So we waited an hour and paid our £20 each and went back. They crammed so many of us in and had to translate in Spanish and English so the whole thing over ran and we got hotter and hotter crammed into the kitchen. We were given tasks to do and tea to drink that we had made with the shells, unfortunately they didn't wash the cups and everyone had to drink out of dirty cups which made us feel sick. The tops of the counters were filthy and people were able to come in and watch us working and breathing over us whilst making our chocolate. People were blowing their noses and sticking fingers into the chocolate which they expected us to then make into bars of chocolate for ourselves to eat. People were fighting over the flavours to add to the chocolate as their wasn't enough to go round. After making the chocolate you have to spend another hour and 20 minutes waiting for it. We had to wait for ours as we were leaving Cusco in the morning, but they had shut the kitchen and would not even make us a drink. We had a headache and were really tired by the time we got the chocolate which hadn't even set. The idea is good, but the place isn't hygienic at all, so many people washing their hands and using the same handtowel to dry them, even the actual chocolate makers themselves were using the same surfaces to make the chocolate sold in the shop. Everyone is allowed to wonder in the kitchen to have a look, hair, dirty hands, blowing noses, the lot in a food preparation area. We thought it would have been a good idea because we had seen the plants in the Amazon and thought it brilliant to see the end product, very saddened by staff that didn't care about people once they had your money and didn't care about customer satisfaction. Disgraceful attitudes, dirty and unhygienic and a lot of money, I wish I would have checked it out more before going back to make the chocolate. I thought they would have been more careful about who goes in the kitchen.

Cooking Class and Pisco Sours-Perfect Evening in Cusco. What a wonderful introduction to Cusco. We walked with Chef Noami to the San Pedro Market to buy our ingrediants for dinner. This was a wonderful experience. Chef was knowledgable about the indigenous fruits and vegetables. We walked back to the ChocoMuseo to begin cooking. We had so much fun especially when we learned to make Pisco Sours! We also were able to sample some of their chocolates and finished the meal with a chocolate fondue. This was a perfect first evening in Cusco.
For Chocolate Lovers.... This is a nice stop if you want to indulge your sweet tooth and have a little fruit & chocolate fondue or a candy bar, hot chocolate, etc. Fun for kids!
Excellent Small Museum. Very nicely done museum on chocolate and the history.. plus small cafe and cooking class options... We did not get to try the cooking but the chocolate was excellent

An "Alright Experience". I had the chocolate fondue. It was alright--dark chocolate, but nor enough of it. Nothing to write home about.
The atmosphere was nice and there were 2-3 balcony seats that faced the plaza.

Chocolate cafe ++. ChocoMuseo has some nice programs and tours on offer, which are probably worth it if you are a chocolate lover. For me, the museum was more of a nice cafe with an exhibit included. When you enter, you´re given a free sample of cocoa husk tea which is delicious. Buying some chocolate there is also a real treat. I didn´t get to experience everything that ChocoMuseo had to offer, but I would definitely recommend it if you´re in Cusco.

Academic. Interactive. Entertaining. Yummy.. Indigenous to the Americas, the cocoa tree and its associated seeds are used here as a springboard to educate and inform tourists about the history and making of chocolate. We signed up for a “bean-to-bar” workshop previous to visiting and arrived about 30 minutes early to see the museum. The ground floor starts the process, covering the use of cocoa by the Mayans and Aztecs and explaining its introduction into the Old World and role on both sides of the Atlantic with an emphasis on religion. The scope of the topic is a bit broad obviously, but I learned quite a bit going through the explanations.The workshop followed, starting with a quick didactic session on the upper floor with a life-sized model of a cocoa tree. Growing and harvesting are explained and we were then brought downstairs in the kitchen to start working. The workshop lasted a little over an hour and was exactly as advertised: from bean to bar. Longer parts of the chocolate-making process like fermentation and refining were explained on a theoretical basis, while aspects such as roasting, winnowing, and grinding the bean were completed by the group. Two types of chocolate drink were made using ingredients we had just processed, then “refined” chocolate was brought out and we made small candies with additional ingredients like nuts, salt, sprinkles (think Maggie Moos or Stone Cold Creamery but using chocolate and not ice cream…. Yeah it’s that decadent). These were then stored to be cooled until pick-up later that night or the following day. There is a store and café for purchasing the usual items during regular business hours as well.This was an enjoyable experience and I think the above title of the review sums up the process accurately. The only issues I had with the workshop was that our preceptor seemed a bit new on the job (and more interested in flirting with the college girls in our group) but a more experienced colleague helped with the process to smooth things out a bit. Additionally, we came back to pick up our treats later that night and the door was locked. After several phone calls from local businesses we were let in to retrieve our results. Fortunately both of these issues were fairly minor when viewed in the context of the entire afternoon. Thumbs up on this visit and recommended for all age groups.
Nice thing to do with your kids. It was a nice thing to do but not very it can be found in many other places as well. Friendly staff but expensive chocoate.
try to get one of the classes. They offer classes on making your own chocolate, but its also a really cute place to go for a cup of tea.coffee/chocolate, too.

Mmmm!!!. Do read the history of chocolate making thoughout the museum. Don't miss trying the delectable samples or watching the chocolate making in the kitchen. Yum!Oh - and did I mention admission is free! Yum-Yum!

A sweet spot. Although we did not get the chance to take part in a chocolate making class, the chocolate museum was a nice break in our roaming. We got to learn about the history of chocolate and sample some free cacao tea. The museum is a great place to pick up chocolates for friends at home. Peruvian chocolate does have its own unique flavor that any chocolate lover should try.

Great business idea, fun and engaging experience!. I visited this place shortly after it opened in early 2011. It's a very complete package: museum about chocolate production through history, cafe to drink chocolate tea and hot chocolate, chocolate making workshops, eco tours to visit cacao farms, and a little shop to buy chocolates, organic coffee (bought several packets of this. It's very good!) and chocolate memorabilia. I learned a lot from the museum and then visited two more times for the chocolate making workshops, once just for fun and once with a group of students I was teaching.The workshop was in English the first time and Spanish the second. It costs S/. 70 per person (but ask for discounts for groups) and lasts two or three hours (add the time that it takes for the chocolate to set in the refrigerator.) If you take the class at night you'll need to come back the next morning to pick up your finishedWe learned about the entire process of chocolate production from the cacao tree and pod to how to make my own pieces of chocolate with different additions like peanuts, chilli powder, and cinnamon. The teachers had great English and were patient as we tried our hand at roasting the cacao seeds and ground them to paste. It was very engaging and fun and the end result was delicious. One negative experience was that when my mom and dad did the class, my dad went back to get his chocolates and they'd been given away to another customer. All that time and attention to make his very own chocolates and he never got to enjoy them. Instead they gave him someone else's. Otherwise, I highly recommend this place if you need a fun activity while you acclimate to the altitude.

fun afternoon. I took a class where you learn the processing of chocolate and you learn to make different types of hot chocolate. At the end, you mold your own chocolates. It was really fun and interesting. You leave with the chocolates you make. You get to mash cocoa beans into chocolate paste. Tasting the different hot chocolates was fun. Unfortunately, there are not too many different types of chocolates to purchase.

Only if you have time and money to spare. The museum is set up nicely and you can read a lot on the history of the Cocoa, while enjoying a nice chocolate drink. We did the chocolate making workshop. I guess it all depends on the amount of people in your group (we were in a very large group) but we found it to be quite expensive (70 soles) for a 2,5 hour workshop (compared to local prices) because the personal attention was limited. But it definitely gives you a nice souvenir, because you can make chocolates to your own taste and take them home.

Great place to stop for a Coffee/Tea. We didn't try the chocolate making classes, however the chocolate tea they have is delicious and several other chocolate coffee / milk combinations were good too. Nice place to stop for a drink or to buy some delicious chocolate while touring around cuzco.

Choco-tastic!. Me and my friend came here to partake in the workshop which was educational and fun! We learned about the chocolate making process, got to taste some different versions of chocolate and then the fun part - making the chocolate. Gladis was our teacher, who was fun to learn with and had our group laughing all the way through. The session cost 70 soles each and was supposed to last 2 hours, but it ended up being nearer the 3 hour mark. This might have been because our group was so big - probably around 14. There should maybe be a limit for about 8 people to keep things moving. This activity is great for everyone who likes chocolcate. If you are not interested in the workshop, you can just go to the museum part for free, but it is quite small and you can buy chocolates and Choco Museo merchandise.

Fabulous!. This was a fantastic place to visit during our stay in Cusco. We are a family of 5 (ages 7-45) and participated in the 2 hour class - from cacao bean to bar. It was so imformative and fun. We learned so much about cacao and chocolate and truly enjoyed the class.

Fun to visit. You can learn a lot about the history and cultivation of chocolate at this modern little museum, and it's all free! A few blocks from the Plaza de Armas, it's worth finding. A little gem!

A Fun Place to Visit. This little museum tells the story of chocolate and you can even make your own. A great stop while you are strolling around Cusco and acclimating. Delicious hot chocolate with chile.

Don't expect much. The chocolate museum is more like a tiny cafe and store. The information about chocolate, while interesting, is set all around the rooms, behind the cafe tables and up and down a few staircases. It is very difficult to get a table to sit down, so most people spend the 10 minutes going around and sampling, and then have to leave or buy products. However, I did not take part in the chocolate making activities; I think that would have enhanced my visit.
worth doing the course if you are a chocoholic!. you get to make your own bars, with or without milk, there are over 30 different stuffings or flavoursing you can put in .

More to chocolate than you thought. Good for a brief visit. I am not much of a fan of chocolate so the visit was wasted on me, but I found the info boards very interesting and realised how little I knew about the cocoa tree.
WOW. this is a great place to sample the many different types of chocolat from the region
Fun with Chocolate. Do the 2 hour workshop! You learn a lot and you get to taste chocolate in several different ways.

YUMMY!!. We didn't do a chocolate making class but just stopped in for a quick peek to see what they had. My sister in law bought a couple of bars of chocolate and she quickly returned the following day for more. I ended up buying some and we LOVED it! You can taste the quality and freshness in their ingredients. It rates up there with the finest chocolate in the world. A must try!! Delish!!

Informative and Fun for All Ages. Informative guide who spoke English clearly and knew her subject well. We learned about the entire process of making chocolate and even got to make our own tray of chocolate as well with different flavorings and spices. Expensive, but a good experience if the cost doesn't scare you.

Good fun, and delicious.. Was great, the chocolate tutor was so friendly. Although i was feeling quite light headed from altitude, the class is fun. We didnt know anyone else in the class and so it was nice to laugh with other foreigners of all ages. Chocolate was so rich, you couldn't eat alot of what you got to take home at the end.

Absolutely loved this chocolate making experience!!. My husband had booked this for our 1st year anniversary and it was perfect! The perfect mixture of learning, culture and fun!! We did the afternoon workshop which started by sipping chocolate tea while reading about the history of cocoa...then you get a small tour followed by the chocolate making workshop. This takes you from bean to chocolate - really interesting!! The best bit was when you got to make your own combination of chocolates - you can get pretty creative! I would highly recommend this experience to anyone visiting Cusco - it was one of my favourite things and a nice break from all things Inca!!!

Fun at Chocomuseo. The name ChocoMuseo doesn't tell the whole story. The ChocoMuseo was the most 'modern' thing we saw among all the history in and around Cusco! Yes, they give a brief review of history of Cacao/Chocolate making, and the history is displayed as exhibition on the walls, but we also learned about today's cacao bean 'farming' in Peru, and some facts about the bean's handling from harvesting through the processes to the ready product.We learned that the quality Peruvian organic grown cacao is highly valued in the world marked.The entrance to ChocoMuseo is free; one only pays for participating in chocolate making class. And we were lucky, somebody on the plaza next to the Museum gave us a discount vouchers to the class. We as a group of three participated in the fun chocolate making class in April this year. We had a lovely and enthusiastic instructor, Gladys, who made the whole experience even more fun. She is a happy person, nice to be around. In fact she was sweeter than the chocolate we made:). We had some competition in grinding toasted cocoa beans, made Mayan hot chocolate, and own our chocolate. After the class we enjoyed a hot drink by a window overlooking the plaza, next to which the ChocoMuseo is located on a second floor of an old building. The whole class was truly fun, and we got something special - self made chocolate - to take home too. Also, one can buy the toasted cacao bean shells/husks in nice size packages to take home. We tasted the tea made from these organic & shade grown, fermented husks, and it was delicious – I ended up buying a couple of packages. Organic grown coffee beans are also on sale. All in all, it was a time well spent in ChocoMuseo, and I would like to recommend it to anyone, young and not so young!

Yummy experience - chocolate workshop!. My boyfriend and I were given a voucher on the street to see the free choco museum! It was cute and informative and smelled delicious, we sat down and had the most delicious hot chocolate I have ever tasted! Mayan hot chocolate with a side of honey and chili! We decided to book the next day for the 2 hour workshop! Very informative our teacher Gladys was very good and so sweet! We made our own chocolate bars by the end and got to take them home! I felt it was very good value for about $25-$30.

Interesting and informative. Nice museum, they show you the whole process how to make your own chocolate. They show the origins and history of chocolate and how it became so popular in Europe and in the U.S.

Make some Chocolate to travel. This small but nice museum/activity is a great find. If you have a spare couple of hours or if you just really like chocolate I strongly suggest paying a visit. Not only will you find out exactly where it comes from, how its made, and some other cool facts, but you can make a fair amount as well. My girlfriend and I did the shorter and smaller kitchen activity and it was very fruitful. The chocolate was great and the "guide" was knowledgeable, funny, and bi-lingual.

Unique Experience. Enjoyed the process of learning to make our own chocolate. Great guides, lots of great information and interactive.
The chocolate is delicious!!

What fun (and we learned something too).. My husband and I signed up to learn about chocolate and make some chocolate candies and drinks. First, we learned about the cacao tree. Then, we roasted cacao beans, made cacao tea, two kinds of hot chocolate, and then got to make molded candies using about twenty things you could add to the chocolate, like nuts, coconut, sea salt, mint, etc.Carmen, the person who gave the talk, was very personable.Just be sure you have an hour or so AFTER the experience to come back and pick up the chocolate after it has hardened. Yummy, and worth a trip even if you don't take a class. Just have a hot chocolate or enjoy the candy.

Fun Fun Fun!. We enjoyed a 20 minute chocolate making demonstration at the ChocoMuseo. It was really fun to try our hand at it (and we got to keep the product!). This was an excellend afternoon activity to get out of the soon for a bit. Highly recommended.

For the cocoa lover. Must try the hot chocolate served as a pot of chocolate sauce, pot of hot milk, jar of honey and some pinches of cayenne pepper all to be mixed to your own liking. Fabulous but rich.

Choco-licious!!!. Once you enter into the Museo your senses will be infused with the delight of chocolate! Gladys our fabulous and well informed instructor brought her passionfor the art of chocolate to our table. We all shared in the various techniques roasting, grinding, blending and creating individual chocolate treats for our own. I encourage all chocolate lovers to indulge, you won't be disappointed!!

So much fun. It was a bit pricy, but well worth it. We spent over three hours learning about chocolate and then playing with it. The teacher was informative and fun. We ended up with quite a bit of candy to bring home. It isn't the finest chocolate, but it was a great souvenir.
it's ok. interesting to while away a few hours if you are in the city with nothing on. I will not make it a destination.

Great place where you can make your own chocolate treats. The place is up some back stair but well marked. When you enter; your nose is assaulted by the wonderful smells of chocolate. Their hot chocolate is wonderful! You can enjoy the posters about chocolate, sit in comfy chairs or sit at a table on the balcony. You also can sign up for a time; it does have a fee attached, but you learn to make chocolate in different forms and then you get to take it home with you. We chose to just buy some bars to take home...they do let you sample!
good good good. Very good chocolate and cool worshops, must be tried if you like chocolate and alternative activities :D
try it. We visited it and did the workshop. It wasso fun and at the end we get to eat everything!!!!!

For chocoholics!. Small but cute museum in Cusco, explaining the origin of chocolate. Wish I had known they also had chocolate-making workshops before! But you can always buy some delicious chocolates to take home.

A must go to for some yummy fun!. We discovered this place while walking around Cusco and we had heard other tourists talking about it. We did a chocolate cooking class which was really great! totally worth doing! and a very nice place to relax in as the sun is setting over Cusco! We loved this place!

Great quick stop in Cusco, get the tea!. They have a lot of features that we didn't take advantage of, including making your own chocolates, but even without doing that, we had a great time! Its a good place to learn about chocolate and try fresh, unprocessed coco beans. Also, they have a chocolate tea that is made from toasted coco husks alone and we all bought some!
A delicious visit. Hard to find but worth the time if you like chocolate. It's on the 2nd floor of a small off the main road little plaza. Chocolate tea...delicious.

delicious!. I didn't get a chance to take one of their workshops, but the hot chocolate I had (while enjoying the view from the balcony) was delicious! The owner was very friendly and came over to chat with us. The museum was interesting and informative. We were even offered a free sample of chocolate tea when we entered!

Fun and educational. My wife and I were in Cusco at the beginning of May 2012 and had a free afternoon.
