We decided to take the chocolate making workshop at the Choco Museo.There is really a lot of information here - the history of chocolate cultivation and use, the various types of cacao plants, and the process of turning cacao pods into chocolate.The workshop starts with cacao beans that have already been removed from the pod and fermented. (This takes too long to do during the class.) In class, you roast the beans, separate the nibs from the hulls, and grind the nibs into cacao paste with a mortar and pestle. The teacher makes some traditional drinks from the paste and everyone gets to try some.Then it jumps to prepared cacao that has been ground for 24 hours in a commercial mechanical grinder. You choose fillings for your chocolate candies and pour the prepared chocolate into the molds with the fillings. You come back about an hour later to pick up your chilled and solidified chocolate. It's very good chocolate!The staff was very friendly and helpful. Ours was the last workshop of the day, so they had to stay late until we came back to pick up our chocolate candies.

Can't Get Enough Chocolate? Go to ChocoMuseo!. As a fellow chocolate lover, this place was a great start to my visit in beautiful Cusco. The same day I arrived at Cusco (11,000 feet above sea level), I participated in their chocolate workshop. It was the best decision I made. Not only was I learning the process of making chocolate, our workshop instructor made cocoa tea (great for altitude sickness) and Peruvian hot chocolate. Amazing! A cute twist to the class involved singing while whipping the chocolate. So, get your song ready and stop by ChocoMuseo!

Great activity for the kids. Our kids (11 and 13) loved the 2-hour chocolate-making workshop where they made (and kept) chocolate from scratch. Great, lively professor who spoke wonderful English. Highly recommended.

A new museum in Cusco. Chocolate is a recently flourishing industry in Peru. And Cusco features this new, modern museum in a strategic area, a couple of blocks away from the Plaza de Armas, on a first floor and with a beautiful view. Group lessons can be taken for "make your own chocolate". Or you can just make a tour in the museum and learn about the history of chocolate, techniques on chocolate manufacturing etc. Or just buy yourself a bar of delicious chocolate, among the wide variety of flavors, even Chocolate with Salt from the Salt Fields area near Cusco.Entrance free.

Take the Chocolate Making Class!. The museum is free to browse and is very imformative on the history of chocolate, especially as it related to Peru. However, spend the money and take the chocolate making class - you will not regret it!The teacher of our class was an incredibly sweet and knowledgeable lady and took us through a demo/hands-on experience of the entire chocolate making process. We even got to make our own chocolates and take them home at the end of the day. You definitely get your money's worth after all the tastings of hot chocolates and the chocolate making that you perform! It was a fun and delicious way to spend a few hours of our day in Cusco!

choc-tastic. the musuem is free to look around and you are able to sample the cocoa husk tea and cocoa beans as you look around. if you manage to grab your self a flyer on the way in you will recieve a 15% discount in the store and cafe. i recomend teh chocolate fondue.

Fun!. We took the whole chocolate making workshop one afternoon and had a blast making chocolate candies from the pod to the product. Delicious and entertaining. Also a great way to spend time if you are acclimating!

Excellent Chocolate Workshop. We had the good fortune of a private workshop where we learned about the history and significance of Cacao in Peru. We were thoroughly taken through the entire process of making chocolate, which culminated in making our own chocolate at the end of the workshop. It was a great way to pass our time while acclimatizing for our trip on the Inca Trail and thank our instructor Sharon, a university student studying tourism, for the wonderful experience! Try the chocolate husk tea, which is free upon entry and can you found directly behind the reception desk. Delicious!

Smells good. Tiny place, some history about cocoa beans and chocolate making, process of chocolate making is long but they can walk you through (hands on?) steps. And of course, the chocolate shop, but they not forcing you to buy.

Educational, Fun, & Tasty (ChocoMuseo in Cusco). Even our teenagers loved it and we did too. It was a nice break from the regular sightseeing and easy to sign up for a session on-line. Everyone was very friendly and they had a variety of activities for us to do as we learned the process and history of making chocolate. We loved the chocolate tea! Fun for all ages.

A great way to spend an afternoon in Cusco.. We had a wonderful time attending a chocolate workshop at the ChocoMuseo in Cusco. We learned the entire chocolate-making process, from bean to chocolate bar, and it was a lot of fun. Great value. I highly recommend.

A Thorough. This place is wonderful. If you want to get a thorough understanding of the history and processes that goes into making one of the world's favorite treats, then this is the place to go.The museum is free and open to the public. And my family and I signed up for the make your own chocolate class, which was reasonably price considering how much chocolate we got to take away at the end of the class.If you're looking for a sweet place that your whole family will enjoy, then definitely check this place out.
Chocolate museum, need I say more?. Great little free museum that had lots of interesting facts about cocoa and all it's glory. You can also make your own chocolate there if you like!

A pleasant surprise. This place won't knock your socks off as an eatery or drinkery, but it illuminates the interesting history of cacao and chocolate in Peru (and Peru has some very good chocolate.) You can make your own or buy from their range of excellent and intersting recipes.

Interesting and tasty experience. Located in the center of Cusco the ChocoMuseum is worth a short visit if you wish to do something interesting yet relaxing. The museum-part is composed by facts and stories on wallpapers, but the more interesting part is the walk-in kitchen in which you can taste different chocolates or even make your own. Also their coffee and cocoa-tea is excellent and the latter prooved to be a great souvenir :-)
Good Chocolate. This was a nice diversion to help us get use to the altitude in Cusco however it was a bit pricey.

Exactly what it promises to be. Lovelly staff, great hot chocolate and interesting history lessons available.
Well worth a trip

Taste everything, take the class, bring your kids. I took our three kids (ages 11, 9 and 5) plus my MIL to ChocoMuseo for the chocolate making tour in March '12. The kids and I had done a chocolate making tour with a micro shop in Costa Rica so we had high expectations, and we were mostly satisfied. ChocoMuseo took us through the entire production process: we roasted the beans, shelled them by hand, crushed them (my 9 yo son loved the mortar & pestle competition!). During each step we tasted various drinks made from the cocoa bean or husk products (tea, etc) making the drinks ourselves. In the end, we poured our own chocolate bars after selecting mix-in ingredients like mint or peanuts (we chose from over a dozen items). The end result is delicious and we are still enjoying he chocolate bars days later. The only shortcoming in comparison to our Costa Rica tour is the lack of fresh cacao bean pods to sample; you simply must try tarting the fruit jelly that surrounds fresh unroasted cacao beans, the flavor rivals passion fruit for sweetness!ChocoMuseo is located only a few blocks off Plaza de Armas in Cusco, it's a bright and airy shop with plenty of chocolate options to purchase, great bathrooms - our kids went there from our restaurant they were so clean - and a variety of additional local touting options available. If you can find your way here, it should rank as a Cusco must-do activity.
Cute, well worth the trip. Nice, friendly atmosphere. Good explanation of the process and history of chocolate.Worth the trip. They also offer a chocolate making experience we hope to go to.

Great for chocolate lovers!!. Workshop was well worthwhile for chocolate lovers!!!! Very informative and interesting, and you get to eat the chocolate you make in the end!!! Otherwise great shop for Peruvian chocolate and associated products, and great hot chocolate and cafe menu... Not too pricey - hot choc 8soles...

Interesting to see, located very close from Plaza de. Nice setting, enable you to see a traditional house of CUSCO.(patin and balcons).The muséum in itself is interesting Especially if you do not know much about chocolate origin and fabrication.

Tasty Fun!. My husband and I done the chocolate making workshop at Chocomuseo during our stay in Cusco. We really enjoyed ourselves and would strongly recommend it! It lasted about 2 hours and during that time we learnt how chocolate is made from the Peruvian cocoa bean, drank a Peruvian version of hot chocolate, had a cocoa bean crushing competition (my husband won - his prize was a bag of chocolate tea leaves!) and eventually made our own chocolates which we collected later on that day after they had set. Overall we had a really fun time - it was interesting and something different to do in Cusco - we're glad we done it and the chocolates we made were really tasty and unusual - I opted to make salt flavour chcolate (so delicious!) and my husband made a mix of oreo chocolates, coffee flavour and almond.

Good way to spend half an hour. The museo is very small but filled with lots of info about chocolate. You can taste test some different kinds and even try chocolate tea which was really good. Then you can buy some to take home. It is free to get in and located right off the Plaza de Armas.
Cute place. Had posters and explanations about how chocolate is made, history of chocolate, etc. Free admisson. We got there just before closing time; plan on an hour.

Chocolate heaven in Cusco. We had so much fun at ChocoMuseo one rainy afternoon in Cusco when Gladis showed us how to roast and grind the beans to make choclate. We also made tea from the toasted husks which was yummy.It was a wonderful experience sipping their hot chocolate with cloves and cinnamon sitting on the balcony over looking Plaza Regoclio whatching a snapshot of Cusco life pass us by.Thanks

Small but interesting.. I wouldn't go out of my way to visit here, but if you're in the area and have a few spare minutes then drop in. There are a few interesting exhibits explaining the history of chocolate. The gift shop sells many varieties of chocolate made right on the premises.
Excellent. Even me, not a great fan of chocolate, liked it a lot! They mix information with practice (there is a chance to make your own chocolate).

Great free attraction. Cool little museum that is free to go in. Although you do have to pay if you want to do a chocolate making class. You´ll also probably be tempted into buying something. A complimentry cup of cocoa husk tea is on offer which is surprisingly nice.

Amazing workshop. We have done a few food workshops around the world and this one is great and very reasonably priced for what it is.The lady who does the workshop is very knowledgeable and speaks excellent English. You learn all about cacao and how it is processed. Then you roast some beans and grind them. With the cacao liquor that it produces, you then make two different drinks. You make a Mayan cacao drink and a Spanish chocolate drink. You also get to have a cacao tea made from the husks of the beans. You learn about the pressing process and the chocolate making process. After this you get to make your own chocolate bars/pieces with a variety of flavours. You go back an hour later to pick up your chocolate.I cannot recommend this place highly enough. We did the workshop and also came here twice for hot chocolate (delicious). The workshop takes almost exactly two hours and is a great break from Inca stuff.

Great as a cafe!. This place has great coffee and iced/hot chocolates, definitely recommend these. The museum is mmeh, but you do learn a bit. I would have liked to make my own chocolate which is part of the museum, but it was too expensive, even when converted to £/$.

Fun place. Wouldn't have known this existed unless the man on the street in the main square handed us a pamphlet. It is a small museum, but was nice to go to and read about the history of chocolate and what it means to Peruvians. They also have a workshop where you can help make chocolate. Order something off there menu. It was a nice little spot to stop and get a chocolate drink while out and about in the city.

Plan extra time if you are taking the class. The museum is small, but informative. My wife and daughter took the chocolate making class, while my son and I ate in the cafe and watched people in the square below until they finished. The class seemed to take a few hours, and then you come back to pick up your chocolate the following day after it hardens. I recommend this for cooking or chocolate affectionados.

Such a great experience!. The information is set out great in both english and spanish, helps with brushing up on your spanish vocab! We stayed for the chocolate making workshop, which was quite expensive (about £20 each) but laughed so much! was very informative, and making your chocolate from bean is rewarding, even if it didn't taste great! the chocolate you come out with is about 80%, not everyone's taste!
Went there twice!. It's a museum dedicated to chocolate. Enough said.

So much unexpected fun!. We did the cooking class with Gladys (the English speaking teacher). She was incredibly lovely and her English is fantastic. It was really interesting learning how chocolate is sourced and made, especially because we eat so much of it. You get to make three different kinds of chocolate-based drinks and and a tray of chocolates with your favourite fillings (milk or dark). It's a two hour class for 70 pesos and was so worth it!Thanks Gladys!
Good choice if you want to take a rest of historic places. Interesting experience! You will learn about how the cacao is grown in our lands and how it is processed to become the delicious chocolate.

great chocolate tea. great chocolate tea sample was given when i visited - it tasted really good! chocolate making classes are also available if you have the time. not an easy place to find in my opinion, make sure you ask a local who can speak english!
Pretty Fun. It was interesting but if you have to cross something off of your list this would be it. I would check out other museums or other parts of town before you come here.
Chocolates too expensive. This was okay, found the chocolates too expensive and not much to see.

The ChocoMuseo is 2 hours of delight. We are a family with kids 11 and 13. This was a wonderful sensory-filled experience. Our instructor was experienced, playful, and created a camaraderie among our multi national group. We each left with our own bag of personally designed chocolates. So fun.

A chocolate lovers dream!. Went here after a bit of a down day whilst travelling and walked out feeling on top of the world again! The chocolates are excellent, and the history and farming technique fascinating! I'll be going back for more chocolate after my Matchu Picchu trek!

Fun for the whole family!. Our family of 5, ranging in age from 18-77, loved this 2-hour workshop. It's a really fun history and cooking class in one. Our teacher spoke great English. There's a small museum which you can wander through while you wait for your chocolate to chill. Note that even the milk chocolate is very bitter--so manage the expectations of your kids if necessary. Highly recommended!

Good Source Of Chocolate Products. My wife and I chanced on the ChocoMuseo while wondering around Cusco. We found the information provided to be informative, and the Chocolate products to be high quality. I enjoyed the refreshing chocolate frappuccinno. I think you would to...

Interesting Free Museum worth a peek. An interesting look into the history of cacao production in Latin America and consumption throughout the world. They gave me a free cacao tea and I saw that there were chocolate making classes, a cafe and best of all its free entry.

Chocmuseo - a free surprise. It is a nice little place and it is free, so it is great to see how the chocolate is made. However, they do push the chocolate making, and there isnt really enough to call it a museum, more a factory.

A tasty place to spend a couple of hours!. This museum is very centrally located and is free! It offers lots of interesting info on the history of chocolate, and its current uses. You can attend chocolate making workshops (70 sold for adults, 50 sold for kids) which our daughter loved (and we loved the chocolates she made). There is a café which serves chocolate-themed drinks and nibbles. Great fun and not at all like most museums.

Worth a visit. Its a worth a quick stop to learn about the history of coca. We did not have the time for a class but we saw people take the class and seemed like fun. They have a small menu from which we ordered the chocolate fondue which was great.
Chocoholics united. My daughter and I did the full tour and made our own chocolate. Great experience and we learned lots.

Very fun!. We loved the ChocoMuseo- it's a 2 hr chocolate making class and is only $27 U.S. We roasted beans, and then made chocolate tea and two types of traditional inca and Spanish hot Chocolates! We then made a tray of our own personalized chocolates to take with us. Overall we learned a lot and really enjoyed this experience- if you are going to Cusco, definitely check it out!
a hidden gem with the bigger gem!. best chocolate I've ever had in my life in a very nice building close to the main square.

Cute little museum. It was a great little place to visit. The displays were interesting and they have chocolate making classes that you can sign up for. The chocolate in the gift shop makes nice souvenirs for people at home.
Interesting.. Particularly enjoyed learning about the history of chocolate making. Didn't particularly take to the taste of '70% cacao' chocolate
Worth a Visit. This was a chance to find out more about Peru and a nice change from ruins. Very well organised. It was pleasant to sit on the balcony drinking hot chocolate

Very tasty and interesting. Due to the hidden location I think many travelers miss this sight and I found it a nice place to relax with some coffee and chocolate samples. You will find very interesting information about cocao production and comfortable chairs to rest. I sat in the balcony window enjoying coffee and the sights of Plaza Regocijo. You can even join a class on how to make chocolate. If you are used to the sweet American chocolate, you might find this a bit bitter but it is fun to taste many of the flavors.

A must in Cuzco. A self guided, at your pace tour. No entry fee. A great place to get gifts for difficult people. (who does not like chocolate?) They have a balcony so you can drink your hot chocolate and admire the views. So much to learn about the cacao plant ,God's gift to chocoholics all over the world.

Small, quite interesting museum. On arrival you are offered a cup of cocoa husk tea. There is a small area that tells you all about the chocolate process, a cafe to drink various forms of hot chocolate and a chocolate making class for 70 soles, plus a small shop to sell their produce.As this was two doors away from our hotel we stopped in, it is quite centrally located, but I am not sure I would have bothered to hunt this place down if I wasn't on the door step.
Hot chocolate to Die for!. Nice oasis in the city to learn about cocoa and chocolate. The hot chocolate was amazing.Really laid back atmosphere.

Great little place!. Very cute, interesting facts in coca and chocolate. Museum part is well laid out. Nice little cafe to get a great hot choc on the balcony overlooking the plaza. Had choc making classes which looked interesting but we didn't do due to time. All in all a great chocolate respite from our walking around!!
Great tour and lovely chocolate. Cracking informative tour and chocolate making experience, this was a really fun thing to do for the day in cusco. Recommended.

Nice place to browse for some free fun.. Friendly staff. Good info on chocolate. Free to browse around (and they gave us a bit of free chocolate tea)We wanted to go on a trip to a cocoa farm, but were told that it would take 2-4 days to do. So we had to pass. Saw people doing a chocolate making class and it looked pretty fun (but it was 70 soles, so we couldn't afford it)

Great fun, and you get to make your own chocolate!. We did the two hour chocolate making course, a family of four with two children aged 10 and 8. It was great fun, we got to do almost all the steps from cocoa bean to finished product. Only the very technical tempering and conching were done by the museum, but we did everything else.Our chocolate was very high quality, and absolutely delicious! We also learnt a lot about how difficult it is to get tasty chocolate out of a cocoa bean; I don't think we will ever look at a Mars bar the same way again!Although chocolate isn't an Incan tradition, the cocoa beans are grown locally, and the tram who run the museum are enthusiastic abut promoting the chocolates of Peru! A great thing to do in Cusco for anyone who loves chocolate.The museum itself is free, with an attached cafe where you can try their delicious hot chocolate (Maya or Spanish style).

Delicious. Very nice place ! Museum is very interesting : Explanations are precise and activities are fun ! Take time to make a workshop and realize your own chocolate : people are gentle and you will not be disappointed by different flavours !After your workshop, take time also to drink hot hocolate or other drinks by having a look on Cusco city.

Delicious treats & lots to learn. Not in Lonely Planet since it's fairly new, this is a great spot to spend an afternoon! Once you've learned all about the history of chocolate in Peru, and how it is made (lots of surprising facts!), you can grab a seat and order off a delicious and cheap chocolate-only menu. There is a cozy ski-lodgy couch area with leather sofas and a balcony, or a small cafe area with another balcony, tables, and floor cushions. You are greeted at the door with chocolate tea and a welcome in Spanish, French, or English by the French founder of the museum. Very popular and busy but still accessible and fun! We didn't get the chance to take the class (2 hours plus an hour wait for your handmade treats), but the group when we went was clearly having a great time! When class is not in session you are free to wander around the kitchen and inspect each step of the process (and get free samples!!). Everyone should go! It's free!

Great, fun activity for couples. Me and my girlfriend were in Cusco for 4 days. I read the reviews here. Excellent place to spend 2 hours, learn about making chocolate, have some fun and some laughs with fellow students of the class. Our instructor as great and fun. Delicious chocolate. Location is not far from Plaza de Armas...Try to get the instructor in the photo that I am attaching

Lovely free museum - definitely do the workshop!. The museum itself is very interesting but the workshop is the best part. Learning and participating in the stages of chocolate making is so much fun as well as being able to try various chocolate drinks etc. The chocolates you produce at the end are amazing and it's easily worth the money you pay for it. A nice change from the usual tourist activities.

Interesting and Fun day activity. I read reviews on the Choco Museo and had to try it out during my stay in Cusco. It was interesting to learn about the growing and production of chocolate. The teacher was knowledgable and was entertaining as well. The chocolate product itself was a little bitter for my liking. I believe this was because it was all organic, but nonetheless a fun way to spend the day in Cusco.

A fun find!. I brought my 3 kids here, ages 7, 9 and 11. Very educational and fun. They let us roast the cocoa beans, sip hot cocoa, try cocoa bean tea and at the end of the class we got to make chocolates. Note- the only chocolate they have here is dark chocolate, the chocolates we made were 60% cocoa. My 7 year old got a little bored with it, but my 2 older kids loved it! There is also a little cafe with fondue, chocolate croissants, hot cocoa, etc. If you're in Cusco, especially with kids, this is a must!

If only I knew earlier!. When you walk in, its like walking into chocolate heaven!! The smell was amazing and the hot chocolate was just as good. However, I did find another store where I like the hot chocolate a little better but this was a close runner up. The ChocoMuseo made up for it. with great seating areas and fun information.Since we stopped by near the end of our Cusco trip we missed out on what looked like awesome classes and even some tour packages. They take you to the farms and show you around. I wished we went earlier so we could have partake in the funness!!

Such a Surprise!!. Some people on my Inca Trail tour did this and let us all taste some of the chocolate they made and it was DELICIOUS!I totally forgot about it until I was wondering around town one day and saw the sign and immediately went in, arriving just in time to start the class! So much fun, great info and instruction and being able to taste and try as you go. I am totally recommending this to EVERYONE, as it's something you don't always think of to do while in Cusco. A great activity in town, even if you don't do the class, the info is well laid out and in perfect English.

After Machu Picchu - this was our favorite!. This museum shows the history of chocolate (in both Spanish and English) - the museum is well laid out and has a great video about different parts of the process. The best part is paying the fee to make your own chocolate- from roasting the beans, to trying Maya hot chocolate, to making your own chocolate and filling them with all the different mixtures they supply. Our guide was fantastic, me and my children - (ages 11 and 13) learned so much and enjoyed every part of the process. They have two times, (when I was there it was 11 AM and 4pm.) We had so much great chocolate to take home. They also had a note that they do cooking classes, so you may want to inquire about that as well. It overlooks a plaza, so if you don't have time to make chocolate, just learn about chocolate and order a chocolate drink or buy a candy bar and enjoy. (They make all their own chocolate there- just like we did, but there bars looked much better!)

Excellent place to visit with kids. Loved this workshop. Very hands on and lots of sampling and an excellent presenter. Would highly recommend it for somewhere to go if you have kids ( and the adults enjoyed it too)

fantastic. We were told about this place by people we met in the Sacred Valley...they said not to miss it. It's a little hard to find but definitely worth it. There is a factory making chocolates which you can buy. You are given a hot chocolate drink...very nice. And the information about the history, growth and production of cocoa and chocolate is excellent. When we got to the Amazon jungle later, we recognised the trees with the pods growing on the trunk and branches.

What a fun thing this would have been. Who can resist the sign on a building that reads "ChocoMuseo"???? I wish I had learned about this before we went to Cusco. They have available (with reservations) a 2 hour class and you can make your own chocolate. However, since we just stumbled onto this, we wren't able to do the class. But they have a very interesting room with the history of chocolate, and chocolate in Peru, in particular. And the aroma just walking into the place!!!!!

Cool experience making chocolate. When you arrive there you don´t think much about the place.Looks like a small coffee shop, not much.You pay the entrée to the chocolate workshop and the process is really cool, you begin roosting the bean then you smash it and do it all the chocolate process.Is a entire afternoon and is really fun, you can take kids with you to, they will have a great time. In the end you choose the toppings and create your own chocolate.

A Fantastic Experience. We signed up for the workshop on how to make chocolate. It was fun, informative, and a great time altogether. Through the 2 hours, you'll participate in each step of the chocolate making process. Highly recommended!

Choc full of fun and fascinating facts. Having a group of sixteen teenagers to shepherd through Peru would make a lot of people nervous, but places like the ChocoMuseo make travel fun. The four chaperones of our school group and the sixteen teenagers (ages 16-18) loved this place. From the time you open the door and the smell has everyone swooning to when you leave with your own hand made chocolates, the entire two hours is fast paced, infinitely fascinating in the history, and always hands-on.  The folks here know how to interact with all age groups. Lots of touching the ingredients, tasting them, playing with them, and all in a homey setting. What a great place, and as a history teacher, I loved how they explained the history of chocolate, showed a cocao tree with pods, and made every part of the tour fascinating and super sensory.

Workshop highly recommended - Alain is great. Just got back from Peru. My wife and I did the workshop and Alain was enthusiastic, energetic (must be from all the chocolate), informative, fun and hilarious. As much as learning the process of making chocolate and actually making/tasting chocolates made it fun, Alain made the experience with his personality. Experience drinking cacao as the Mayans/Incans did...then in the more modern and palatable way. The museum portion is informative and the workshop is enjoyable and informative. Alain is something to be experienced.Make sure you have time 2 hours or so after the workshop to pick up the chocolates you make.

What a surprise. I had read some reviews before went to Cusco, well is a fantastic experience to drink a hot choco on the balcony facing facing the plaza. Lovely place, very good idea and excellent hot chocolate and what a surprise to know the origins of the owner parents, Portugal, that says all.

A Delicious Afternoon. My husband and I took a Chocolate workshop while in Cusco and absolutely loved it. They take you through the entire chocolate making process, letting you taste it along the way and wrapping up with creating you very own chocolates. They are in a great location, overlooking the square. Even if you don't sign up for the workshop you should stop by for a hot chocolate on the balcony.

A Visit to Paradise. I spent two days and one night at the home of Julia and Jose, coffee farmers in the Quillabamba area. Choco Museo arranged the tour and provided a Spanish and English-speaking guide who was perfectly suited to my personality. Julia, Jose, and family made me feel at home. In addition, I received quite an education; they showed me coffee, tea, fruits, and medicinal plants around their home. The accomodations were perfectly comfortable and meals very tasty. I hope to visit these people again and would not hesitate to use Choco Museo to make the arrangements. The only negative part of the trip is the drive time from Cuzco. If taking public transportation, visitors should be certain to empty their bladder before leaving on the journey.

Informative in a fun atmosphere. We did one of the chocolate workshops and it was alot of fun learning about the beans and having a turn to produce your own chocolate. The best bit was of course making your own chocolate. Delicious. Great hot chocolate too!

Fun, delicious, and a great learning experience!. Such a great activity to do while you're in Cusco. It's easy, fun, and you get to be creative. Friendly staff, convenient location, and you get to take chocolate home with you! We definitely enjoyed it!

Believe The Reviews & Hype - Amazingly Fun & Educational Experience!. Visited while in Cusco with family last week and all I can say is...WOW! Great cafe with delicious drinks, chocolate, snacks et al -- but far more in terms of the history, use and making of all things chocolate.Truly a novel and fun experience for all ages -- whether a family with young kids (would say 7 and up); single or young couples, or older travelers. We took the 3-hour chocolate making taller (workshop) which was awesome. Lead by Alain, who is hilarious and a true pleasure/joy to be around, everyone in our group had a blast -- and learned how to make chocolate from scratch. This was a surprise highlight of our most recent visit to Cusco. If you have a few hours of downtime in Cusco (after/before the trail, before a flight et al.) -- based on our experience, we could not recommend a visit to the ChocoMuseo more highly. If you have the time, sign up for the taller -- you won't be disappointed - you'll leave in hand with Chocolate you've made from scratch -- and a will have had a blast at the same time.

Great Experience: the chocolate workshop. Did the chocolate workshop and it was great fun. From cocoa beans to your own chocolate. The museum is very informative, staff is friendly and helpful, great hot chocolates. The workshop is really worth it and I have learned a great deal. A really fun time. Highly recommended!

Yum. I didnt even look at the displays, though it all looked very nice. I just wanted to record here. as a Cusco resident and certified chocolate addict, that this is the best hot chocolate I've encountered in Cusco, and a really nice, relaxing place to drink it.

If you do one thing in Cusco, this should be it. The Choco Museo is very accesible and easy to find. It sits right on the plaza and is only one block from the plaza de armas. The museum is free and offers samples of some of the most delicious chocolate in the world, and it is all locally made. The owners are fun, friendly and so helpful and offer all the chocolates you want! There is educational information and chocolates to buy. There is also delicious coffee and hot chocolate. It is something completely different from what you'd expect to see while sightseeing. We were there only 5 days after it opened, and everything was delicious, unique and unforgettable. Lonely Planet and other travel guides WILL notice this soon enough, but get in on the action before it becomes the most popular spot in Cusco.

Chocolate Workshop is a must-do. We had a wonderful day at the chocolate factory. We knew that the factory was very new, but we didn't expect to have such a professonal operation, since we knew that it been open only about 3 weeks. But the young French couple who run the museum/workshop had the entire operation down to a science, having build a similar museum operation in Nicaragua. Our guide was an incredibly friendly American, a trained chocolate maker who studied in New York, who walked us through the entire operation of chocolate making, from roasting and husking through to pouring the finished chocolates into the moulds and helping us select the ingredients to add to help us customize our chocolates (raisons, nuts, etc). It was an amazing afternoon. Highly recommended!

Best place for chocolate-lovers. The choco-museo is located in the first floor of park-side-building. Besides the museo it also has a nice kitchen and a coffeeshop with park-view-balcony!We joined the 2 hour chocolate-workshop which was very informative, fun and yummy - well worth the money and time!!The staff is very creative and friendly... they clearly love their job.Try the great chocolate-tea, we loved it.Highly recommended =)

Who said you can't balance education with chocolate?!. We visited ChocoMuseo whilst in Cusco, we were amazed at the Museo, very professional and some to die for chocolate drinks! We didn't get the chance to do a chocolate making workshop, but from watching some other workshop attendees they were loving it - plus they got to take home their own chocolate!I would mark this as a must for any visitor to Cusco!!!!Muy Bien!!

A must for chocolate lovers!. We visited the Choco Museo and were surprised that the business only opened a couple of weeks ago! A great introduction to the chocolate industry with very knowledgeable and friendly staff. We participated in the chocolate making workshop which was great value, being able to take home the goods we made. Their product range is focused on dark chocolate, although there is vision to expand their range as the company grows. Great location and inviting modern shop, highly recommended!

If you love chocolate you must go there!. It is not only a Museum but you can also buy chocolates, drink hot chocolate (they have many tioes of that one), and even drink a chocolate tee. The place is very well located and it is really cozy, te prices are reasonable, the service is really good they took the time to talk about the museum and to answer all of our questions about the place and the chocolates they sell, they also where asking us if we where ok with everything, the place smells amazing and I think it is imposible to walk in to this place and do not buy chocolate or feel happier than usual because it smells so good and of course to see the museum you do not need to do any payment but if you are a chocolate lover you are for sure buying or drinkink something in the Choco Museum.

mindblowing !. Hey,I wanted to post here because I discovered this "kitchen-museum" by chance when they just opened and I've been so surprised. With the museum I learnt many things and with them in the kitchen that was so interesting and cool !We made chocolate :)You should try the tea of chocolate skin.I apreciated they explained to us how they work with local producers of cacao and how they learn from each other. That seems respectfull.You should go and spend 2 hours in the kitchen.Recommanded, good surprise !Vincent, Fce
Tours to Machu Picchu. i went last mouth with my family. i enjoyed full, i doing inca trail to machu picchuthanks so much Peru for this oportunituy for know your places
